PETITION.TITLE: Diabetics: Insulin
PETITION.PARA: Sir William McMahon-Before petitions are read may I draw attention to the lack of people on the Opposition benches. I think they should be given an opportunity to come into the chamber and listen to the business of the House.
Mr Lionel Bowen-What about the Government's attendance? It is about one-fifth.

Mr SPEAKER-I take it that the right honourable gentleman was not drawing attention to the state of the House. I take it that he was seeking an indulgence from me, as distinct from calling for a quorum.
Sir William McMahon-That is so.

Mr SPEAKER-I should point out that hitherto on the opening of proceedings of the House, at the ceasing of the ringing of the bells there was invariably a full attendance in the House. What has led to the paucity of attendance at the end of the ringing of the bells is the fact that petitions are read out at that time, a procedure that invariably takes anything from 8 to 12 minutes. That has led to members arriving later in the expectation of petitions taking that time. I think it is for the House to consider whether petitions should be read at the opening of the sitting. In fact, the Standing Orders Committee has recommended to the House that petitions be read after questions. I will have discussions with the Leader of the House (Mr Sinclair) to see whether that matter can be brought on for discussion. I am indebted to the right honourable gentleman for drawing attention to the position. The point made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was a natural response from him, but it has been overtaken by the whole course of events now that I have set out the circumstances.
The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers.
Diabetics: Insulin
To the Honourable, The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in view of the recent standardisation of insulin and insulin syringes, having the effect of increasing the cost of both items to the Diabetic in general, and as every insulin-dependent Diabetic must use the same, daily or twice daily according to medication.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that syringes be made available on the N.H.S. and that insulin prescriptions revert to 10 bottles as previously supplied.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Charles,Mrs Child,Mr Cunningham,Mr Duffy,Mr Mildren,Mr Milton,Dr Theophanous and Mr Willis.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia who respectfully showeth their anger and condemnation at the Fraser government's decision to abolish all Community Youth Support Schemes on the 31st October 1981. Further they denounce the decision for the disastrous effects it will have on growing numbers of unemployed young people around Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal government immediately and fully reverse its decision and restore complete funding to the Community Youth Support Scheme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the decision of the Government to abandon the only tangible form of direct assistance to Australia's young unemployed, ie., the Community Youth Support Scheme, will have a serious effect on the thousands of young Australians presently benefiting from the operation of the scheme through almost 300 decentralised CYSS centres around Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will reverse this retrograde decision before due date of termination on October 31st.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the Budget imposition of additional sales tax to both existing sales taxed items and to previously exempt goods:
(a) will add to the regressivity of the tax structure by imposing a similar burden on all sections of the community-regardless of the capacity to pay tax;
(b) will be highly inflationary and a disincentive to economic performance in key sectors of manufacturing industry, e.g. car manufacturing; textiles and footwear; boat-building;

(c) is yet another breach of Government promise, given the Treasurer's undertaking in the Parliament on March 12 of this year that there would be no increases in indirect taxation (without at the same time giving personal tax relief)

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to repeal the budget amendments to sales tax legislation and to withdraw its sales tax amendment bills which add sales tax to presently exempt goods as from January 1, 1982.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned residents of the Electoral Division of the Northern Territory respectfully showeth our concern at Federal Government budget proposals to impose new or increased sales tax on a wide range of essential consumer items. We particularly protest at sales taxes imposed on:
1. Building materials which will exacerbate an extremely bad housing situation in the Northern Territory.
2. Stationery and books which is a tax on knowledge and a means of communication.
3. Footwear and clothing, which are essential items for all persons.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the 1981 Budget amendments to sales tax legislation be repealed and the Sales Tax Amendment Bills be withdrawn.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Speed Limit Adjacent to Schools
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:

There is a need for a speed limit of 25 kilometres per hour adjacent to schools, one hour before school starts and one hour after it ends. A speed limit should be implemented for kindergartens and playgrounds during daylight hours.
That Parliament put these views to the House of Representatives 'Standing Committee on Road Safety' with the idea of making the speed limit in these areas unified throughout Australia.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament should take urgent action on this matter so as to save the lives of children.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Copyright
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
The Copyright Act as amended by the Copyright Amendment Act, 1980, places unnecessary restrictions on the education system.
All photocopying and videorecording used exclusively for education purposes should be exempted from the provisions of the Copyright Act.
Any amendments to the copyright law which affect the education system should not be made operative during an academic year.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Motor Vehicle Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the proposed changes to assistance to the passenger motor vehicle and components industries after 1984 shall lead to the collapse of the vehicle manufacturing industry in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the industries Assistance Commission report be not given effect.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Toxic Shock Syndrome
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned by the threats to women's health and lives posed by Toxic Shock Syndrome, and urge the following steps to be taken as a matter of urgency:

(1) Tampons, sanitary napkins, vaginal deodorants and similar sanitary products to be re-classified under Therapeutic Agents (not under ''Cosmetics'' as at present), in order to bring them under the scrutiny of the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee. We believe manufacture must be under the strictest hygienic conditions.

(2) After re-classification, we urge an immediate government-funded inquiry into all aspects of manufacture and content of these products. This must lead to: (i) contents of product and instructions for correct usage to be shown on packaging; (ii) removal of synthetic fibres, chemicals or ingredients that are potentially or actually harmful to users.

(3) Allocation of extra funding for ongoing research by the National Health and Medical Research Council into these products, results of this research to be made public to ensure all health workers and potential users are fully informed. This campaign of public education would necessitate multilingual distribution of the information where appropriate.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action to avert possible threats posed to women's health by implementation of the above measures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the Government's Sales Tax legislation imposes an unreasonable burden on the community generally, especially pensioners, families, those in receipt of smaller incomes and small businesses.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will withdraw or repeal its Sales Tax Legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. The Government proposes to impose a Sales Tax of 17 1/2% on manufactured pet foods which were previously exempt.
2. That this new tax will impose an unreasonable burden on pet owners, many of whom are pensioners and citizens in receipt of a small income.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will withdraw or repeal its Sales Tax Legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Brisbane Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That noise levels created by aircraft using Eagle Farm Airport already constitute an annoyance and inconvenience to those residents living near the airport and along flight paths.
That relaxation of the Eagle Farm Airport curfew to allow any aircraft including TAA's airbus to fly into and out of Eagle Farm Airport between 11 p.m. and 6 a.m. would-
(a) Substantially increase the inconvenience and annoyance caused by aircraft noise because the operation of aircraft at this time would seriously disturb people's sleep;

(b) Contradict and negate a commendable undertaking made by the Commonwealth Minister for Transport, the Honourable Ralph Hunt, in reply to a question on notice in the Parliament, that the curfew will remain on the runways at the existing site at Eagle Farm Airport.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will not approve the application of TAA-or any other airline-to relax or withdraw the curfew at Eagle Farm Airport.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the pressure of cheap imports, the high cost of new homes and the effects of the credit squeeze are seriously weakening consumer demand for furniture.
That an increase on sales tax for furniture and mattresses would be a complete disaster for the furniture industry causing widespread bankruptcy and unemployment.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will not proceed with an increase on Sales Tax for furniture and mattresses.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telegram Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Government and Telecom management have presided over the deliberate scaling down of Australia's telegram services, to the disadvantage of those poorer people in the community who cannot afford telex or telephone facilities and rely on the telegram service in time of emergency.

That the Government and Telecom management have undermined the telegram service by increasing the unit cost of telegrams by over 130 per cent in four years with the result that the use of telegrams as a form of communication has fallen by approximately 60 per cent in that time.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government and Telecom management retain the telegram service at a standard cost that will not disadvantage the ordinary citizen.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Government's decision to impose a tax on books, magazines and newspapers is abhorrent to the notion of the right to information, and
That no such tax is levied on any other country with which Australia is usually compared.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray
That the Government will withdraw its announced intention to impose a sales tax on books, magazines and newspapers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the single parent is part of the most disadvantaged section of the community, that 73 per cent of single parents will not be assisted by the restricted increase in family allowance, that neither the guardian's allowance nor the child allowance is indexed,
That sales tax increases on such basic essentials as clothing and shoes will severely disadvantage single parents,

That a single parent with one child receives $66.65 per week plus $6.00 guardian's allowance, plus $10.00 child allowance and $3.80 family allowance (totalling $86.45) compared to a married pensioner couple's combined weekly income of $111.10,
That the means test for a married pensioner couple is $34.50, compared to $26.00 for a single parent with one child,

That a married pensioner couple's income, if shared, will not be taxable, whereas a single parent, even with the lone parent rebate, will pay $386 tax. And finally that, while agreeing that pensions are inadequate to meet rising prices, comparisons between age and invalid pensions and widows pension indicate even greater disadvantage being suffered by single parents.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That the Government will increase the amount of widows pension and supporting parent benefit, index the guardian's allowance, child allowance and family allowance, raise the tax-free threshold for income tax, and remove the sales tax increase announced in the Budget from essential items.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned that the Government is increasing Interest Rates on Home Mortgage Loans without due concern for its impact on the general community and ask that the Government re-consider its attitude to low and middle income earners.

Your Petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action to avert any further effects of increases in interest rates on Home Mortgage Loans which cause financial, social and psychological pressures on families.

PETITION.TITLE: Potato Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that potato growers of the North-West of Tasmania and people associated with the industry express their deep concern at the possible effect on the industry and employment within the industry of any changes affecting potatoes that might be agreed to in negotiations for closer economic relations with New Zealand. We request that the present protection levels remain; also, that if any new measures are to be considered the Government consult fully with representatives of the potato industry.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled will accede to this request.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Child Care Expenses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:
Taxpayers who incur child-care expenses in order to earn income should be able to have those expenses exempt from income taxation in the same way as other business expenses.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aspect House for Handicapped Children
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. All children in Tasmania are not treated equally.
2. Persons with intellectual, physical and multiple handicaps in particular will be denied access to ASPECT HOUSE, 6 Warragul Avenue, New Town in Tasmania if the house is closed.
3. ASPECT HOUSE is faced with imminent closure because of lack of Government policy and on-going funding.

4. ASPECT HOUSE is the only community-based facility in an ordinary house in an ordinary suburban setting which provides relief to parents and families engaged in the onerous and demanding task of rearing their handicapped children in the community.
5. That the rights of all children to live with their families should be respected.
6. That we seek Government to take immediate action to prevent the closure of this unique facility.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

(i) the financial situation of students enrolled in Australian post-secondary institutions is already extremely difficult (as indicated in the Commonwealth Department of Education's 1979 survey of student incomes and expenditure) and any substantial increase in the financial commitments of students would gravely worsen their financial difficulties.

(ii) the imposition of post-secondary tuition fees of comparable levels to those imposed prior to 1971 would force many currently enrolled students to discontinue their studies and deter many persons willing and able at present to undertake post-secondary study from doing so.

(iii) those students and potential students from social groups currently under-represented and disadvantaged in the post-secondary education system would be most severely affected by the reintroduction of fees for post-secondary education.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
1. post-secondary tuition fees not be re-introduced for any courses or for any category of students
2. the visa charges upon private overseas students be removed immediately
3. the Minister for Education immediately clarify the government's attitude to the re-introduction of post-secondary tuition fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Trans Australia Airlines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Many Australians depend almost exclusively upon Trans Australia Airlines for the provision of essential air services.
The Federal Liberal Party policy objective of selling Trans-Australia Airlines within 4 years is contrary to the national interest.
Sale of Trans Australia Airlines would inevitably result in:
(i) the creation of a private monopoly of major airline services in Australia;
(ii) higher domestic air fares.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will reject outright any proposal to sell Trans Australia Airlines.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Motor Vehicle Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled. This Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that
(1) the automotive products industry is vital to the livelihood and well being of many thousands of Australian workers and their families
(2) if imported automotive products are allowed to flow freely into the Australian market it will deprive over 100,000 workers in the industry of their work opportunities.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament recognise the rights of Australian workers in this industry and that proposals to reduce the level of protection in the future be rejected.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth.
That the burden of interest payments on housing loans is now at such record levels that most citizens paying off their homes are becoming severely financially distressed.
That the burden of additional expenses together with increases in health insurance and hospital charges is putting increasing stress on family relationships.
That the policies of favouring overseas private investors to buy up our resources are causing inflationary pressures, declining public services and ever higher intrest rates.
That we support all efforts to give relief to people making house repayments, particularly in the first five years of purchase, but also when expenses are higher after the first years of marriage.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will give interest rate relief by way of tax concessions or a subsidy on mortgage repayments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth- That the allowable amount of income to be earned by people receiving social security benefits has not been adjusted since 1972 and in the case of unemployed not since 1969.
That the $20 allowable for beneficiaries in 1972 was at a time when the benefit was $18.25 p.w.
That if the same principle applied and if the amount earned had been indexed the amount now allowable would exceed $63.20 per week.
That Family allowances have never been indexed.
That heartless, insensitive, frugal and anomalous social security benefits, allowances and rules are causing severe financial distress to many citizens and causing the break up of families.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will bring all allowances and benefits up to the levels which would make them equivalent in real monetary terms to the time when they were set.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Subsidy Payments for Nursing Home Patients
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. The majority of pensioners in nursing homes are currently not receiving any significant rebate after all fees and laundry expenses are paid. This situation does not allow for a basically acceptable quality of life and undermines the dignity of people who are unable to fend for themselves. We call upon the Federal Government to investigate the plight of these people and guarantee them at least the opportunity to financially support their own basic needs.

2. When residents of nursing homes go to stay with friends or relatives for short periods (e.g. weekends) they are compelled to pay the Commonwealth subsidy for the period of their absence. This expense is obviously not able to be met by the majority of nursing home residents or their friends and relatives. The result is that people who would benefit from short periods away from the nursing home are restricted to its confines because they are not in the position to pay for their release. This situation causes emotional trauma on festive occasions such as Christmas and birthdays.

We feel this is a hardship that should not be borne by nursing home residents and call on the Federal Government to relax its policy regarding subsidy payments for nursing home residents on short leave.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Government policy on subsidy payments for nursing home residents on short leave, be relaxed.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This humble petition of citizens of this country are concerned with increased house interest rates and that this Government has not taken action to peg increases in such rates. We ask that the Government establish a maximum fixed interest rate on a First Mortgage that would cover the entire period of time for which the loan is taken out. The rate of interest to be set at the time of signing the contract.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned members of parents and citizens associations respectfully showeth:

That retention of the Schools Commission and the Curriculum Development Centre in their present forms is essential for the balanced and progressive allocation of educational resources and facilities in the Australian community.

That serious concern has been generated by the decision within the School Commission guidelines, to cut funds to the general recurrent and capital programs by reallocation to transition, the decision not to implement the School Improvement Program; and the division created between government and non-government schools due to increases of $43.25 million to non-government schools while government schools' funds have not increased.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That the Government will reverse these decisions-will retain the Schools Commission and Curriculum Development Centre in their original forms; retain the Schools Commission proposals including recurrent and capital funding proposals; basket of services and the Schools Improvement Program.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ian Cameron and Mr Cross.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Division of Mackellar respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to downgrade postal and mail services throughout Australia, will place in jeopardy the existing services and the security of the mails by:
downgrading a large number of official post offices;
reducing the number of post offices open for business during the lunch period;
reducing the number of street posting boxes;
delaying telegrams by reducing the number of delivery offices;
downgrading post office services by employing untrained and unqualified staff; and
using private contractors for mail cartage.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission implementing any plan which will downgrade the postal and mail services of the citizens of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Division of Werriwa respectfully showeth:

That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to investigate the downgrading or closure of Milpo, Ingleburn, N.S.W. 2174 post office places in jeopardy the existing postal and mail services to our community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission taking any action to downgrade the Postal and Mail services of our community.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telephone Exchange at Coomba Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain residents of Coomba Park, New South Wales respectfully showeth-

That the Minister for Communications consider and act upon our urgent appeal for the installation of an automatic telephone exchange at Coomba Park whereby servicing the needs of residents requiring telephones and the general needs of the public.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that steps be taken to ensure the installation of an automatic telephone exchange at Coomba Park, N.S.W. in 1981-82 fiscal year.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned students and staff of the University of Tasmania respectfully showeth that the introduction of tuition fees for second and higher university degrees would:
1. have substantial ill effects on the Australian economy in particular and society in general, by limiting access to education for Australians,
2. be a barrier to increased equality of education for Australians,
3. directly inhibit the ability of Australians to undertake retraining in response to the changing demand for skills within the Australian economy, and
4. curtail the substantial contribution to research and teaching that is currently made by postgraduate students within Australian universities.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will:
1. not allow the introduction of tuition fees for second and higher degrees, and
2. ensure that any tuition fees are not charged at Australian tertiary education institutions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Housing Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Division of Ballarat respectfully showeth.
1. That the proposed imposition of 2 1/2 per cent sales tax to building materials will have a disastrous effect on the already seriously depressed industry.

2. That the latest interest rate rise of 1 per cent to home mortgages will now end the hopes of many intending first home buyers. We believe the Federal Government must initiate a scheme of assistance to first home buyers, as proposed by building industry representatives.
In conclusion we reject the Federal Government's lack of genuine interest in the home industry. We also clearly state that the effects of points 1 and 2 above are not acceptable to us.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government give immediate attention to an already seriously depressed industry.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives, Federal Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned residents of Hindmarsh Division, State of South Australia.

Petition that: Competition between banks and finance companies by giving ever increasing interest rates to obtain the investors' capital, is against the nation's best interest. It penetrates every form of activity by constant demands for higher wages to meet these explosive conditions.

It is an intolerable burden to the younger generation of family life, that by necessity are the recipients of these excessive interest rates that are catastrophic to house purchase and natural living.

We therefore respectfully petition for an urgent annual realistic controlled reduction right 'across the board' on all existing and future interest rate agreements. With a maximum interest percentage ceiling on investors' capital, and a scale of interest charges for loans as appropriate.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will give effect to our submissions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Communications in his capacity as Leader of the House. I refer to the announcement made outside the Parliament yesterday that this House will go into recess next Thursday for about four months. Is it a fact that the Government is introducing some 10 new pieces of legislation today? Is it further a fact that the Senate has indicated that it will not pass at least 10 of the Bills which will be before the Parliament? Is it also not a fact that some of these Bills are very important, relating to defence, social welfare and other such matters? What is the Government's position in respect of legislation that is not passed by the Senate and referred back to this House when this House will not be able to deal with it? What is the reason for the Government not continuing to sit to allow this House to complete all of the business and deal with many other matters which are on the Notice Paper? Is this because directions have been given by the Prime Minister that the House is not to sit? If so, why do we have to take note of the right honourable gentleman's directions? Why cannot this House determine the business that it ought to be dealing with? Should the House sit until the business is completed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is, obviously, always an interest by honourable members in when the House will sit. It is quite apparent that Government members need to plan their programs forward. I know of some of the uncertainty of honourable members of the Opposition. Perhaps they are not in quite the same position. But in order to project where we were going in our legislative program, early in the session it was indicated that we would be seeking to pass through the Parliament before the House rose all those Bills that related to the Budget. There is, in addition, a program which embraces quite a number of other Bills, many of which we believe would be better left on the table of the House for honourable members to peruse. Some relate to matters that are non-party political in character-for example, the amendments that have been recommended to the family law legislation. Others relate to matters of very real public interest. It is felt that there is no necessity for them to be rushed through the Parliament before the House rises.

ANSWER.PARA: It is the Government's intention to finish dealing with those Bills related to the Budget which have been introduced and which have been designated for passage. I can, at this stage, give nothing more other than an indication that the House may well have finished those Bills by Thursday of next week. Of course, if it has not done so and if the other place decides that there should be amendments, it will be necessary for the House to meet to consider those amendments. I did no more than give an indicative trend, and that is what I do now. If the Budget legislation, which the Government feels it is necessary to pass, has been dealt with and concluded in the House of Representatives, the House of Representatives may be in a position to rise by next Thursday night. If it has not done so or if measures need to be returned from the Senate, of course it will be necessary for it to sit subsequently.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McMahon The Rt Hon Sir W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Prime Minister, concerns the participation of Australia in the Sinai peacekeeping force. Will the Prime Minister now inform the House whether Australia, as one of the real leaders in the Association of South East Asian Nations area, will provide leadership in agreeing to participate in the Sinai peacekeeping force because of our special relationship with the United States; the need to strengthen the bonds that keep the two nations together, including recognition of our obligations under the ANZUS treaty; and also to acknowledge the very high regard and support for Australians by the great mass of Americans? Does he accept the fact that leadership and approval would be welcomed by very nearly all back benchers on the Government side of the House?

—I am happy to be able to advise the House that I will be making a statement on this subject later today. The Government's position and the reasons for it will be very plain. In addition to that I draw the attention of the House to page 2177 of the daily Hansard because there were some words inserted by Hansard, and accepted by Hansard as having been inserted by it, in an answer I gave on Tuesday. They appear in the fifth line of the second paragraph. The words 'the making of' and 'decision'-the 'that' remains-will not be appearing in the weekly Hansard because it is accepted that I did not use them. They are not on the tape. They do, to an extent, alter the meaning of the answer I gave on Tuesday.

—I draw the attention of the Minister for Defence to the fact that the United States Navy has been advised by the Government that the main contract for our purchase of the F18 would not be placed until a clearance was obtained from the United States Department of Defense in respect of weapons still being tested for the F18's air to surface attack role. A decision is anticipated about this time next year. What additional barriers have been placed upon the purchase of all or part of the anticipated procurement? In particular, are there any barriers entailing restrictions on an escalation of the cost of the basic aircraft or its electronics or weapons systems? Further, has the Minister sought and obtained the concession granted to the Canadian Air Force waiving the research and development costs associated with each aircraft's price?

—The honourable gentleman is quite correct that limitations are placed on the FA18 in an air-to-surface role. Those limitations relate to the carriage of particular stores in some configurations. I am advised by the Chief Defence Scientist, Professor Fink, who is pre-eminent in the field of aeronautical engineering, that this represents no substantial problem. It is merely a matter of obtaining final clearance in the sense that the aircraft measures up completely to all specifications. I am not aware of any other limitations relating to the aircraft. With respect to the last part of the question of my honourable friend, namely, that relating to the waiver of research and development, I will seek precise information on that. The matter is not free of considerable complexity. Because of their relationship with the United States of America, as I am presently advised, I think the Canadians were granted a concession. I do not know whether there would be any scope for Australian participation. If my honourable friend will be patient, I will attend to the matter immediately Question Time finishes.

—Is the Minister for Administrative Services aware of recent reports that the Government will soon consider proposals allowing the Australian Federal Police to have access to taxation records and to intercept mail? Can the Minister confirm to the Parliament whether there is any truth in these claims and whether any protection for the private citizen should be included in any broad proposals?

—Yes, I am aware of those reports. Honourable members will be aware that the Williams Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs did recommend, amongst other things, that in order to enhance the police powers against drug traffickers operating in this country, consideration should be given to allowing the police powers to intercept mail and to have access to tax records. In making that recommendation, Mr Justice Williams went to great length to say that if that was considered to be something the Government should introduce, it should be introduced under very strict controls-controls no less than now operate in respect of the intercept powers of the police in such things as telephone calls. Having the recommendations from Mr Justice Williams in front of us, the Government is considering the powers regarding the interception of postal matters as well as access to tax records. As the Government considers those recommendations it will have to keep two things very much in mind: Firstly, that there is a need to protect the citizens of this country from the people who are at the centre of drug trafficking and other organised crime activities-we will be looking at that very carefully-and, secondly, that it is absolutely essential to protect the honest citizen and his rights when we are looking at the controls that would have to operate if those powers were introduced.

—Is the Prime Minister aware that the Queensland State Cabinet has decided to proceed with feasibility studies on the proposal for Queensland to stage the 1988 International Expo and that a firm proposal on the Expo will be presented-possibly by the Queensland Premier himself-to the December meeting in Paris of the International Bureau of Expositions? Has his Government been contacted by the Government of Queensland seeking an indication as to whether the Commonwealth will enter a cost-sharing arrangement with the Queensland Government to meet the estimated $200m plus cost of the Expo? If so, will the Commonwealth assist and to what extent? Finally, will the Prime Minister suggest to the Queensland Premier that the State capital, Brisbane, and not overdeveloped National Party strongholds in other parts of the State, is the logical site for such an Expo?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Premier has been in contact with me on a number of occasions about this matter and a response has been delayed because of a need and a wish to establish an overall strategy for celebrations throughout Australia in 1988. Whilst I think most honourable members would want some focal point for that year, there are a number of other matters to be determined, because I would have hoped and believed that we would want 1988 to be a year in which Australians, wherever they may live, will be able to participate in celebrations throughout that year. That will involve very much more than having an Expo in one particular place, whether that happens to be Sydney, Brisbane or somewhere else. It is a question of establishing that overall strategy which has been before the Government's mind.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Bicentennial Authority has given a great deal of attention to it. The Minister responsible has placed submissions before the Government and as a result of our discussions of the matter the Minister and I will have discussions as soon as they can be arranged with the Chairman of the Authority. That might well lead to further Cabinet consideration about our overall strategy. But I hope when that does unfold it will be one which State governments, local governments and, as broadly based as possible, the whole Australian community can participate in and feel that they are very much a part of. So it is not just the grand projects that we are interested in; we are interested in grassroots involvement in something which will be very important for all Australians, old or new.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Housing and Construction considered the possibility of eliminating the waiting time for payments to beneficiaries under the Homes Savings Grants Scheme? Does the Minister agree that payment of the grant at the date of final settlement or soon after occupation of a dwelling would enable a reduction of repayments by purchasers as well as a considerable decrease in the interest payable over the life of a mortgage?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Curtin on his intelligent interest in all matters of housing and for his positive contribution to the Government back bench committee. In answer to his very precisely expressed question, I advise him on the first part that the Government is reviewing its total housing policy. In answer to the second part, of course if it were possible to do as he asked those very desirable consequences mentioned would follow. But I point out that the need for the waiting period was occasioned because of the disastrous economic climate we inherited and the fact that the expenditure to catch up would have placed very serious pressures on the Budget at that time. At the present time, on account of the initiatives developed by the Government with particular reference to a family commitment of help, we find that the number of applications this year has increased by 50 per cent over last year. They are running at the rate of about 1,000 a week.

ANSWER.PARA: Consequently, to do as the honourable member requested would require an injection of funds this year of $60m to $70m. Quite obviously that would be contrary to the Government's policy and one could not countenance that. However, one must remember that in the overall Federal Government commitment to housing in the Budget last year we allowed $555m; this year there has been a substantial increase to $660m-an increase of 18.9 per cent. I think that indicates that this Government is concerned for Australian home ownership. It is concerned about housing and accommodating all Australians and gives the lie to those who, for cheap political purpose, seek to downgrade our contribution in the area of shelter and accommodation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations by reminding him of his refusal on 15 October to table the letter to him of 13 May from Mr Searby relating to the Minister's request to Messrs Searby and Taylor to undertake inquiries into areas beyond those mentioned to the National Labour Consultative Council on 27 April. I also remind the Minister that I am now in a position to understand his refusal. I ask the Minister: Does the letter from Mr Searby of 13 May disclose a desire on the part of the Minister to bring in legislation in three policy areas before the end of May? Was this approach and expressed desire of the Minister in complete contradiction of the Minister's undertaking to the NLCC some two weeks earlier? Finally, was the action of the Minister also a complete repudiation of a statement made by an honoured predecessor in that post on 1 April 1976? Mr Street, in talking about the proposed NLCC, said:

QUESTION.PARA: I have given repeated commitments on behalf of the government that we would seek to consult with the parties on major government initiatives such as our legislative program in the industrial relations field.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter has been rather exhaustively debated, firstly, in the Estimates Committee of which the honourable gentleman is a member and, secondly, in the House last week. I refer the honourable gentleman to my letter to Mr Searby of 6 May in which, quite clearly, I pointed out the matters under consideration and which I asked him to consider whether he could work on alongside his review. So that letter of mine is quite plain in its terms. The position regarding those matters was fully explained to the NLCC and it understands it. It has also been fully explained to the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions in both a telephone conversation I had and the correspondence which was exchanged between us. The reason I declined to table the letter was that it contains legal advice to me which I thought it was inappropriate that I should make available to the honourable gentleman.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Housing and Construction. Is work on the Omega tower continuing? If not, why not? When will the tower reach its full height?

—Work on the actual tower ceased on 15 July but work has continued on other structures associated with the tower. The reason for the cessation of work on 15 July was at the request of the contractors, Electric Power Transmission Pty Ltd, on account of the fact that the tower had reached the height of 346 metres. Very strong winds were prevailing and there were icy conditions. The contractor has advised the Department that work will resume on 2 November and that the total height of 427 metres-which, incidentally, will make it the highest structure in the southern hemisphere-will be reached early in the new year.
—Where is it?

—The Minister for Primary Industry asks where the tower is. I advise the House that the tower is situated in the most strategic situation in Australia as the eighth navigational aid in the world. It happens to be in what I am advised is a most delightful area of Victoria called Gippsland. The work on the tower will be completed, but other work will be necessary. It is envisaged that the whole of the work will be completed for the tower to operate as a navigational system in mid 1982. In conclusion, I pay a tribute to the men of all nationalities who worked with great dedication, with loyalty and efficiency, at those very dizzy heights. I include officers of my Department. I say to them: Very well done. I only hope that their example will be infectious to the rest of Australia's workers. If that happens we will have a really great country.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps the Minister for Communications can make Australia a better country by answering this question. I refer him to his announcement last Friday that the Australian Telecommunications Commission would not be allowed to establish a viewdata service. I ask the Minister whether he recalls making that statement and stating:

QUESTION.PARA: The decision was taken in the light of the major demands for Telecom for capital to meet its traditional responsibilities.

Is it a fact that the McKinsey report forecast a 20 to 25 per cent reduction in real terms on the 1978-79 level of spending on basic services during this decade? I ask the Minister whether the report concluded that:
The telephone infrastructure is nearing completion; new services show high growth potential; as a result, capital spending will shift to new services.

Do those conclusions flatly contradict the Minister's assertions about Telecom and completely deny the excuse used by the Minister for excluding Telecom from the viewdata area? Is it the Government's intention to restrict Telecom's ability to move into the new fields of service to business and other customers outlined by the McKinsey report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the honourable gentleman had been listening to some of the figures I presented to the House he would realise that there is an expectation that demand for telecommunications services will grow for at least the next two to three years. The projections are that after that time the saturation of the Australian market for telephones will be such that it is likely that demand for capital will ease off. It was essentially that sort of projection that was behind the McKinsey comments. The decision by the Government not to grant approval to Telecom to proceed with Prestel was predicated on the fact that the capital required to meet that projected increase in demand for Telecom's services was such that it would be better if capital were diverted into Telecom's line services, its network operations and its area of prime responsibility.

ANSWER.PARA: The general projection of capital requirement has certainly been reduced as a result of discussions between me and Telecom, but it needs to be remembered that there was still a negative cash flow for at least the first two years of Prestel's operation. The experience of British Prestel is not without some relevance, for British Prestel has not attracted the support that the earlier expectations of the service had led the investors in the system to expect. Our concern has been that Telecom, as a monopoly corporation, needs to relate funds, which are essentially public funds, to those areas in which a monopoly is required. The Government does not believe that viewdata is one of those areas. It is with that in mind that the Government believes that the private sector should be given the opportunity to invest in that new technology.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Resources: Is he aware of the concern that preliminary work on the Burdekin Dam project in Queensland is not proceeding as quickly as it might? Can he confirm the Government's commitment to the project and indicate when the first part of that commitment might be sought?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —The basis for developing the Burdekin Dam and the irrigation area has been agreed upon with the Queensland Government. The Commonwealth has agreed to provide all the funds required for the construction of the dam which will be approximately $85m in mid-1980 terms. The Queensland Government has the responsibility of providing the infrastructure and the preliminary work necessary for the construction of the dam, such as the access roads. That work is taking place. The Queensland Government also has the responsibility of providing the development of the irrigation area. I am told that the infrastructure work will cost about $15m and the irrigation area about $109m. Of course, the Queensland Government will have the advantage of returns from the sale of this land and also from the sale of the water. There is no reason for anybody to believe that the program will be delayed. It is on course and I hope it will be constructed within the time period.

—I ask the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs whether he has seen reports that a group of racist organisations, amongst them the White Australia League, the National Front, the National Socialists, the National Alliance, the Progressive Nationalist Party and the Immigration Control Association proposes to distribute pamphlets amongst the working class and unemployed throughout Sydney in a campaign against Asian immigration. Will he examine such literature to see whether the material is of a racist or hate nature? Can the Government take any action against propaganda of this type? If not, will he bring before Cabinet or discuss with the Prime Minister the possibility of Australia's following other countries that have legislation prohibiting the distribution of racist and hate literature?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Robertson very kindly drew my attention to an article which appeared in one of the Sydney newspapers a few days ago. I notice that there is an article in today's Sydney Morning Herald along the same lines. I will carry out the investigation he has asked me to make and have a word with the Attorney-General in the immediate sense. Judging from recent comments of the Leader of the Opposition, this House would be unanimous in condemning that sort of literature and in condemning the sentiments behind it. I notice in the article the honourable member gave me that a State member, Mr Aquilina, has said that the literature is rubbish. Referring to Mr Thompson, the organiser, he said:

ANSWER.PARA: I don't think he will get any support at all. The public reaction will be very adverse I should think . . .

I also believe that that would be the case. I will certainly investigate the matter and see whether we can eliminate some of the really pernicious, blatantly racist and unfounded statements that are made. Many of them, I might say, are made against me, including still, I regret to say, by the Victorian President of the Returned Services League, who continues to repeat what he knows to be lies. Despite that, I believe this country is now mature enough to be able to ride out those vocal minorities. Democracy is so well entrenched and our compassion and tolerance are now so widely demonstrated that this kind of lunatic fringe will remain a fringe. I do believe that.

Travelling the country, one sees a lot of examples of both sides of the coin. For example, in Perth it was fashionable to paint on bus sheds a lot of anti-Asian sentiments. It was also a fact, though, that at midnight many people who would never ever speak out on issues such as this would go down and paint out those slogans. I remember that a Vietnamese barber was sacked in Queensland last year because he was Vietnamese and one customer complained. Within an hour my Department had had 80 phone calls offering him a job, and as a result of that many other Vietnamese were employed. Indeed, that went on for days. The Courier-Mail got the same sort of response.

For every example of racism and matters about which the honourable member has complained there are examples of basic human decency and compassion many times over. I am informed that the gentleman about whom the honourable member is complaining, Mr Thompson, is in fact part Aboriginal. Certainly, judging by appearances on colour television he would appear to be so. It certainly is curious that he is standing for a white Australia party. But in any event Mr Thompson, along with Mr Cameron said--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about his mate, 'the Skull'?

—And 'the Skull'. On a Four Corners program recently he said that he would not care if the Asian refugees were to die if they were sent home. In his view that was obviously the appropriate thing. That kind of person is a mischief maker. He must be causing great anxiety to Asian citizens of this country. Certainly it behoves all of us to do our best to eradicate this sort of thing. I will examine the matter but I believe that our country will ride this minority storm and that ordinary Australians will go out of their way to demonstrate their warmth and compassion to those who are suffering this kind of insult.

—I ask the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs whether it is true that in 1980-81 about 111,000 people migrated to this country. Is it true that out of that figure a total of 19,570 came into this country under the family reunion policy and only 1,269 of them were actually unskilled? Is the Minister aware of the criticism that is sometimes directed to the Government for being ungenerous in terms of family reunion? Would the Minister agree that these figures support the view that the Government is considerate and compassionate in relation to its migration policy?

—I do not have the relevant figures before me, but I have no reason to doubt the accuracy of the figures mentioned by the honourable member. Certainly, I do not believe that under the Numerical Multi-factor Assessment System the Government has got credit for the extent of family reunion. In fact, under general eligibility migration something like 62 per cent of people who come as general migrants have family here. But as it happens, I will be taking before Cabinet very shortly proposals arising out of the review of NUMAS which I believe, if accepted-I have no reason to think they will not be-will reflect a very considered approach by the Government to meet the aspirations of the Australian community regarding family reunion and to meet also the labour market facts of life. One of the most important facts for this House to understand is that the general trend of family reunion applications is in the semi-skilled to unskilled area. Skilled migrants are employment-generating but many of those whom families seek to bring in as family reunion migrants are, in fact, likely to be unemployed or are likely to disemploy other people here. No Government could--
—There is no evidence for that at all.

—There is ample evidence for that. But I hope to be able to make a statement to the Parliament before the House rises which will illustrate the compassion which the Australian Government has for the aspirations of people for family reunion and also the regard and concern which it has for the rights of persons already here to be employed.

—I refer the Prime Minister to an answer given to Senator Walsh in the Senate regarding members of parliament and their employees. Has the Prime Minister's attention been drawn to the fact that some members of parliament are now employing their wives on their staff? I ask, firstly, does the Government have an attitude on this question? Secondly, as both a staff member and a wife of a member are given certain travel entitlements, if a member of parliament has his wife on the staff does that mean that they can duplicate entitlements such as travel to Canberra or must he select the travel entitlements of a staff member or of his wife and use only one of them?

—So far as the Ministry is concerned, there are very strict rules in relation to these matters, which are adhered to, I believe for very good reasons. So far as members of Parliament are concerned, I believe that honourable gentlemen would need to use their own discretion and common sense in relation not only to what they think is appropriate but also to what the wider Australian public would regard as appropriate and right in all the circumstances.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr Tambling proceeding to address a question to the Minister for Industrial Relations-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman's question is out of order. He is asking for an expression of opinion.

—I refer the Minister for Communications to his answer yesterday to a question from the honourable member for Sydney. In particular I refer the Minister to the Hansard typescript record of that question which records the Minister as referring to videotex. This was confirmed in the Australian Broadcasting Commission broadcast of Question Time yesterday. Did the Minister subsequently alter the word 'videotex' to 'teletext'? If so, does the Minister regret having laid the blame for the terminological confusion at the feet of the honourable member for Sydney? Has the Minister resolved the confusion which is apparent in his mind concerning the difference between these two systems? If he denies having altered the Hansard record, can he provide one of his ready supply of handwriting experts to discover exactly who did?

—The high moral tone of the honourable gentleman quite enthrals me. Certainly, a number of different words are used for the various sorts of view data. Teletext, videotex and viewdata all refer to systems which are now technologically possible. I thought that the questions asked yesterday and the day before by the honourable member for Sydney referred to that which is operated by Channel 7 Studios. I gather from the honourable gentleman's question yesterday that in fact he was concerned with the viewdata system which is called Prestel. I believe, if the honourable gentleman would like to read Hansard, he will see that the question was answered correctly.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Dawkins

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. I simply seek leave to have tabled a photocopy of the typescript version of the Hansard record of yesterday's question.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Transport aware that the report of the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares highlighted the fact that Bizjets was forced out of business by cut throat competition from the national airline operators? Does the Minister agree that the two-airline agreement gives protection to the major trunk operators against other prospective competitors. Using that precedent, will the Government agree to give operators introducing a no-frills service at a lower cost to the travelling public sufficient protection to allow the service to become properly established and viable?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The new two airlines agreement will come into operation very shortly. The air services over the trunk route will be operated in accordance with the provisions of that agreement. There is a provision for other operators to provide specialist services or to offer to provide specialist services over sections of the trunk route but both airlines in the first instance are offered the opportunity to provide those services. If they do not provide those services it is up to the Minister of the day to decide whether another operator should be approved to operate a specialist service. It needs to be remembered that the trunk route generally is basically the province of the two airlines. While ever the two airlines agreement remains in force, that will remain the case. I think it is very important to recognise that fact.

ANSWER.PARA: Indeed, when East-West Airlines Ltd made its application to fly a specialist service between Sydney and Canberra it was warned that either Trans Australia Airlines or Ansett Airlines of Australia, or both, could exercise a right to fly a similar service. Both airlines have licences to fly F27 services. In the event, Ansett chose to exercise its right under the licence to make an application for approval of a fare structure that actually mirrored the East-West service. East-West then took a commercial decision not to fly the service at present. But the opportunity will remain for East-West to get into the market should it so wish.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TESTING OF GAS DURING WORLD WAR II

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Is it a fact, as claimed by people who are interested in these matters, that the Minister for Defence is now the longest serving and surviving Minister for Defence in the Western world? Despite the Minister's well-known modesty, will he have this fact communicated to the editors of the Guinness Book of Records? In view of the Minister's long period of service, and the fact that he cannot be heard to say that he does not know, can he now confirm to this House that during World War II the testing of mustard gas, lewisite and other poisonous gases took place in Queensland and New South Wales? Will he say in which other States such tests took place? Will he also confirm information available from Pentagon files which confirmed American experiments upon Australian soil using Australian Service personnel in 1944?

—As to the indulgence in levity by my honourable friend, I am indebted to him for his generous reference. As to the more serious part of his question, I am not advised as to whether there was any testing with mustard gas during the war. I must say for myself that in those days I was a very simple-minded flight-sergeant air gunner. I say to the honourable gentleman that I will make prompt inquiries, but this information has never been communicated to me in any shape or form. I do not know whether the Prime Minister or any other person who has served in this place is aware of it, but I will treat the honourable gentleman's question with both celerity and seriousness.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ASSOCIATION OF SOUTH EAST ASIAN NATIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of Japan's growing interest in the member countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations and of the highly successful Japan-ASEAN symposium held in Jakarta on 3 to 5 September this year? Bearing in mind the economic and particularly the strategic significance to Australia of any future ASEAN-Japan axis and the importance of mutual confidence and trust with ASEAN countries, I ask the Minister: What efforts are being made by the Government to further good relations with ASEAN countries? What prospects are there of Australia eventually becoming a member or associate member of ASEAN? Has any consideration been given to Australia hosting a special top level symposium to discuss closer political, economic, social and cultural links with our neighbours in South East Asia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government places a high priority on its relations with ASEAN, as I have made clear on more than one occasion in this House. I set out in detail on 9 April the various aspects of that relationship in the Government's response to the report on Australia and ASEAN by the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. The honourable gentleman might be interested to look at that reply. We have established a structure of regular meetings at all levels of government. Regular meetings are held at ministerial level. In June I met ASEAN Foreign Ministers in Manila and I was pleased to note that they were generally satisfied with the Australia-ASEAN relationship. At the official, as distinct from the ministerial level, there is an annual Australia-ASEAN forum, the sixth of which I opened in Canberra in April this year. At that meeting ASEAN representatives told me that they believed the Australia-ASEAN economic co-operation program was going well and that, incidentally, it was greatly appreciated by ASEAN.

ANSWER.PARA: Relations are not limited to ministerial and official contacts. It is our view that a broad relationship between Australia and ASEAN requires contact in many areas, not all of them involving government. For example, a successful Australia-ASEAN business council has been established and trade promotion and cultural activities are making steady progress. Australia has a wide and expanding relationship with ASEAN, and we are pleased with the progress that is being made. We are not seeking membership or associate membership of that organisation, but we are interested in considering all possible ways of improving the relationship with ASEAN. I am prepared to look at the suggestion put forward by the honourable member to see whether there is anything we can do about it.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Human Rights in Chile-Queensland Roads-Bicentennial Celebrations-Government Assistance to Handicapped Persons-Natural Disaster Insurance-Ringwood Project: Community Youth Support Scheme-Housing: Operation of Certain Building Societies-Perth Airport-Death of Mr Pat Farrell

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join the debate this morning to raise the question of our relations with other countries and particularly how those relations may be affected by our trade with them. I refer firstly to the statement by the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Resources (Mr Anthony) on Tuesday of this week, which is recorded on page 2184 of Hansard. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Chile now has a sensible regime under which the economy is moving and working well. The present regime has the respect of the people. It has the confidence of investors.

It seems to me that the Deputy Prime Minister is influenced by the fact that we export almost $8m worth of goods to Chile and import almost $7m worth of goods from that country. His whole mentality is guided by the fact that we have some trade with Chile. He is prepared to submerge all the things we think are important in Australia, such as the right to vote, the right to assemble, the right to protest and the right to worship. All those things are sunk by the Deputy Prime Minister because of a certain amount of trade we have with that country.

I think it is important for us to put the record straight. Firstly, in September 1980 the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) asked the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), a question about Chile. He asked:

(1) Has his attention been drawn to the International Commission of Enquiry into the Crimes of the Military Junta in Chile Report, published following the Enlarged Secretariat Meeting at Elsinor, Denmark, 7-9 December 1979; if so, has he instructed his Department to make any investigation . . .
(2) If an investigation has been carried out, does the result confirm or deny that statement.
The then Minister for Foreign Affairs answered the question as follows:

The Government is actively involved in following developments in Chile both through the Australian Embassy in Santiago and in such international forums as the United Nations. Most recently Australia supported a draft resolution at the 36th Session of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights in March 1980, calling on the Chilean Government to respect human rights. However, the Government has been made aware of a deterioration in the situation in Chile in recent times following an increase in terrorism and agitation and allegations of the use of torture. Australia condemns the use of torture and the practices of arbitrary arrest, detention incommunicado and 'disappearance', wherever they occur.

The Australian Government regrets that the new constitutional arrangements in Chile adopted in the plebiscite on 11 September do not represent a meaningful step towards the return of democratic rule in Chile. The new constitution institutionalises the present regime's rule until elections in 1989 when the government retains the right to nominate the presidential candidate. The recent plebiscite was conducted in an atmosphere of government intimidation and opponents were not able to express their views freely and publicly. We regret that the Chilean people were not given the opportunity to vote on a plan for the genuine restoration of democracy in Chile.

It is important for members of the Government back benches to understand the way in which the Deputy Prime Minister has committed this country with his off the cuff statement on Tuesday this week about that country. Let me add to that an article written by Jean-Pierre Clerc in Le Monde on 5 April 1981. It states:
The regime's sympathisers-
Like our Deputy Prime Minister-
never let go about the modernisation of old Santiago and its new air of opulence and American-style bustle which they talk about to visitors.

But downtown streets are more than ever overrun with beggars cadging a few centavos in exchange for a tune on the accordion or flute, with pathetic old men obviously at the end of the line, with children in rags. Buses are ambushed by women who stretch out their hands after a rendition of some popular song, or by adolescents hawking caramels and fruit. In this dignified land, such changes are particularly noticeable.

In a little over seven years, Pinochet has not only turned the ''England of Latin America'' into a state where human rights are a mockery, but he has also in record time converted a rather ''Victorian'' country, where dignified paternalism tempered social inequality and wealth was never ostentatious, into a museum of man's exploitation by man and a temple to tawdry consumerism.

That is the explanation given by Le Monde for what is happening in Chile today. Chile has become notorious for its abuse of civil and human rights. Violence in Chile is neither arbitrary nor accidental. It is an important part of Government practice and it has been in use since 1973 to serve the interests of the ruling clique under President Pinochet. Over the past eight months leading up to the middle of this year the Pinochet regime has curtailed civil liberties even further. The power of the judiciary to release prisoners has been suspended and the Government now has the right to hold citizens without explanation and without the right to legal representation for up to 20 days. Formerly this power was for five days only. The universities have been brought under the most stringent controls and over the past 18 months over 300 academic staff members have been dismissed.

Amnesty International reports of 1978, 1979 and 1980 reported on the high incidence of the use of torture in the country whereby any person who is even suspected of opposing the Government is arrested and subject to the most brutal kinds of torture. Amnesty International's report for 1980 states that as many as 2,000 people have been arrested and tortured over the preceding 12 months. Amnesty reports that in the town of Talca 30 people were seized. All were subjected to water torture and electric shocks. The bodies of 15 of the victims of the Pinochet coup turned up last winter in a mineshaft west of the capital, Santiago. The soldiers who were found guilty of the murders were subsequently granted amnesty. In October of the same year, 1980, another grave containing 18 bodies was found also.

Those who dare to challenge the Government in Chile are subject to exile under the decree which prohibits public criticism of the Government or which may create tension and division within the ruling armed forces. Former Christian Democratic Party Leader, Andres Zaldivar, was banished from the country in October 1980 for attacking the Pinochet regime. Chile, under Pinochet, has employed a rigid economic program, which might be attractive to the Deputy Prime Minister of this country, loosely based upon the work of Milton Freidman. This has entailed balancing the budget, liberating interest rates and lowering tariff barriers. The immediate result of this was that during 1976 and 1977, there was a sudden rush of bankruptcies, a dramatic rise in unemployment and a sharp drop in the purchasing power of the working and middle classes.
The costs of Pinochet's social surgery were borne by the poor and by sections of the middle class. Thousands of civil servants and Government office workers were dismissed.
