Officially, over 10 per cent of Santiago's work force is unemployed. The real figure is probably twice that. Unemployment in the rural areas runs as high as 40 per cent while almost 4 per cent of the total work force-that is, over 130,000-have been reduced to what is euphemistically referred to as the 'schedule of minimum employment'. These are the workers who earn the lowest wage of $30 a month. One survey estimated that as many as 70,000 people lost their jobs as a direct result of the removal of import barriers and the opening up of the country to foreign imports and foreign investment. During the squeeze of 1975-76 real wages slumped by one-third. Today, Chileans are estimated to have roughly the same purchasing power that they had in 1970. A little over 20 per cent of the population live in conditions of dire poverty.

Since the coup United States investment has indeed flowed back into Chile. The reason is that the terms governing foreign investment are extraordinarily favourable. From the outset firms can repatriate all profits and after as little as three years they can repatriate all invested funds without restriction. Since the coup, approximately 77 per cent of all funds have come from the United States of America and 15 per cent have come from Canada. Since 1977, 14 mining projects worth a total of $3.7 billion accounted for 90 per cent of all foreign investment. These figures indicate that the United States investors have been the real beneficiaries of the coup while local manufacturing industries, farmers and small businesses have all suffered severely from the free inflow of foreign capital. So it is for the great change in the economy which has attracted the support of the Deputy Prime Minister of Australia.
Let me take the matter and refer to the civil liberties question. An article which is headed 'Chile's bishops to Excommunicate torturers-Santiago, January 15, 1981' states:
At least six of Chile's Catholic bishops have issued excommunication decrees for any official or person working at the official's behest who tortures political prisoners.

The excommunication decrees have been promulgated as Chilean human rights groups have asked General Augusto Pinochet's military Government for an investigation into allegations of torture by the National Information Centre . . . Chile's secret police intelligence organisation.

One could go on and on about what has happened in Chile over the past eight years. It does not do any justice to Australia at all to have one of its leading politicians, or any politician for that matter, singing the praises of Chile because we have a little trade with that country. Unfortunately I did not obtain the permission of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) to incorporate this document as he was not here but I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the 1980 report of Amnesty International on Chile which I do not have time to read to the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have not been consulted. We have not heard anything.
—The Minister was not here. I am sorry, I would have asked him had he been here.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

There was a marked deterioration in the human rights situation during the year. The major concerns of Amnesty International were political killings, political imprisonment and torture. There were many arbitrary detentions, allegations of torture and harassment of trade unionists, members of youth organisations, human rights activists, members of church organizations, political opponents and the poor. Amnesty International issued numerous appeals concerning such cases, prepared and distributed information about its concerns in Chile and submitted information to appropriate inter-governmental and non-govermental organizations.

The government has stated several times that its new constitution, currently being drafted without participation of or consultation with independent lawyers, will have no place for political parties. A group of independent lawyers, known as the Group of 24, which prepared alternative texts for the constitution has been harassed and forbidden to hold public meetings. The new labour code has been enforced amid strong criticism from the few remaining independent trade union federations. Several trade union leaders have been arrested and charged with involving themselves in politics because they signed a petition concerning the ''disappeared'' prisoners whose bodies were found in Lonquen.

On 7 February 1980 the state of emergency was again renewed-this has taken place as a matter of routine every six months since 1973, when President Pinochet came to power as a result of a coup. All political parties remain banned and, according to Decree 3177 of 9 February 1980, all political activity connected with the banned political parties is to be considered an offence under the jurisdiction of ordinary courts. Before this decree was promulgated, this type of offence was dealt with by the Court of Appeal. Independent lawyers consider ordinary courts to be even less independent from the executive than the Court of Appeal, and delays are longer.

During the year two other decree laws were promulgated which further restrict the right to defence and fair trial of political detainees. Decree Law 2621 of 28 April 1979, the so-called Anti-Terrorist Law amends articles of the Law of Internal State Security, the Penal Code and the Code of Penal Procedure. The law has been widely criticised by members of the legal profession on legal and political grounds because it assumes an organization is illegal if one or more of its members-even if they were not acting in their capacity as members of that organization-commits an offence under the law. The Minister of Justice stated that ''organizations of all kinds will, therefore, have to take care not to admit to membership people performing such acts, since all members will be brought to trial as constituting an illegal organization, an offence which exists by the mere fact of having formed such an organization, and will be required to prove whether or not they are innocent''. This directly contravenes Article 11 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which states that a person shall be assumed innocent until proved guilty. The United Nations Special Rapporteur on Chile, in his report on the protection of human rights in Chile published on 21 November 1979, concluded his examination of the law as follows:

''Decree Law 2621, which was apparently promulgated in order to combat terrorism, contains elements which may transform it into an instrument for violating human rights. In particular, it affects the right of persons to be presumed innocent until they are proved guilty, the right of association, and the right of a person not to be subjected to arbitrary interference with his privacy, or to unlawful attacks on his honour and reputation. The possible social implications of this legislation for community life in Chile are particularly serious in view of the intimidating nature of its provisions as they were explained to the population by the Minister of Justice.''

On 6 February 1980 Decree Law 3168 was promulgated which gave the Minister of the Interior power to order the detention of people for up to five days and to assign them to residence in remote areas for disturbing public order or for attempting to disturb public order, without any rights to defence, trial or appeal. This decree gives the government powers under the present state of emergency that it formerly had only under the state of siege. To avoid the possibility that the Supreme Court might deem this decree law unconstitutional, the junta invoked legislative powers which it had assumed after the coup of 1973. Furthermore, arrests under Decree Law 3168 are not under the control of the Contraloria General de la Republica, the public body that oversees state administrative procedures.

Decree Law 3168 was applied to people who demonstrated peacefully on 8 March 1980, International Women's Day. Hundreds of demonstrators took to the streets for a rally organized by the women's section of the Coordinadora Nacional Sindical (CNS), the National trade Union Coordinating Body. The CNS had requested permission for the march from the government but had been refused because of the ''political intention'' of the rally. Peaceful demonstrations took place in Chile's main cities, Santiago, Concepcion and Valparaiso. The police detained more than a hundred people in Santiago and 26 in Valparaiso. Detainees were reportedly subjected to interrogation by the Central Nacional de Informaciones (CNI), the National Centre of Information, as the secret police are now called, and kept incommunicado for five days.

On 13 March the Minister of the Interior announced that 12 of the detainees were to be banished by order of President Pinochet, each for a period of three months, to remote villages in the far north or south of Chile. The other detainees were released ''under observation''. They, too, may be banished if they are detained again as a result of participating in any sort of protest; the people who were banished were referred to as ''repeated offenders''.

Towards the end of March 1980 the Minister of the Interior stated that a further five people who had been arrested on 8 March were to be banished. The five people concerned had been freed ''under observation'' but ''new evidence'' made it necessary to banish them.
Amnesty International believed that those restricted under Decree Law 3168 were prisoners of conscience and appealed to the government for their immediate and unconditional release.

In June 1979 the magazine Hoy was banned for two months after having published a statement made by the Special Investigating Judge appointed to look into the case of bodies found at Lonquen. The government stated that the reason for the banning was the planned publication of interviews with exiled leaders of the Socialist Party. The measure was taken by the military commander of the Santiago area under the state of emergency.

During 1979 the Comite Pro Retorno was formed by relatives of those exiled with the purpose of campaigning for their return in accordance with various international agreements to which Chile is a signatory, for example, the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the United Nations International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. Individuals applying to return to Chile have been refused re-entry, often without any apparent motive, since many of them left voluntarily and were not involved in any political activity abroad.

Between 1,500 and 2,000 people were arrested for political reasons during 1979 and at the beginning of 1980, mostly for participating in public and peaceful demonstrations, still systematically forbidden by the government. Several hundreds were arrested in their homes, at their places of work or in public places by members of the security forces who commonly took them to secret detention centres where they were interrogated and tortured or suffered other forms of ill-treatment, and then released a few days later.

An Amnesty International survey of some 1,500 detentions during 1979 reveals that most of those arrested by the CNI or by armed civilians (who probably belong to the CNI) were taken to secret places of detention and tortured by, among other methods, electric shock, suspension and severe beatings.

The government attempted to prevent a large turnout on Labour Day 1979, by means of short-term arrests in the preceding weeks and many arrests on the day. However, more than 10,000 people took to the streets. Many of those arrested were severely ill-treated and some tortured, by methods including electric shock. Most were released after a few days, although 57 were detained for several weeks. Twelve who had been arrested in or near the San Francisco church in Santiago were accused of agresion contra carabineros, aggression against police officers, and after torture and interrogation were sent to the Carcel Publica, Public Prison. After internal and international pressure, including a hunger-strike by relatives in Santiago, they were released on bail and finally acquitted.

On 28 May 1979 Jose Nazario Reyes Valenzuela was arrested, put into the boot of a taxi and taken to a secret place where he was held in a windowless room only 1.6 metres square. There he was stripped, suspended and constantly given electric shocks. He was interrogated about his alleged connection with the Vicaria de la Solidaridad, a human rights organization of the Chilean Roman Catholic Church. He was released without charge on 4 June.
Another victim (whose name is withheld by Amnesty International) was arrested in April 1979. He testifies:

''During my interrogation they applied electricity to me through the parrilla, metal bed frame. They applied electricity to my tongue, ears, genitals, hands, head and feet . . . later . . . they took me to another room where once again they stripped me completely and sat me down in a chair the arms of which were made of metal. This time they applied electricity to my hands and pounded me on the face.''
He stated that a doctor was present to observe his reactions and to assess his level of physical resistance.

Amnesty International has received dozens of detailed testimonies of torture during the past year. In January 1980 a submission was made on this subject to the Rapporteur on the state of human rights in Chile of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights. Despite the fact that many recursos de amparo, a procedure similar to habeas corpus, containing allegations of torture are filed with the Court of Appeal in Santiago and other Chilean cities, no action has yet been taken by the government to remedy this serious violation of the right of Chilean people to be protected against cruel, degrading or inhuman treatment by law enforcement agencies.

This inaction on the part of the government and the courts resulted in the death of a teacher, Federico Alvarez Santibanez, who was detained and tortured by the CNI. Federico Alvarez died while the granting of a recurso de amparo was delayed in the courts. He was detained on 15 August 1979 by a police officer while distributing pamphlets. After being treated for lesions of a minor nature he was taken by members of the CNI to one of their units and held until 20 August. He was then placed at the disposition of the Primera Fiscalia Militar de Santiago, Santiago First Military Court. After interrogation the court ordered him to be detained incommunicado in the Santiago Penitentiary's infirmary because of his condition. When that deteriorated, the duty doctor ordered him to be taken to the central emergency hospital, where he died at 6.50 am on 21 August. The post-mortem examination found the cause of death to be a complex fracture of the skull and that complications included aspiration of blood, final incipient bilateral bronchopneumonia and final aspiration of vomit. The fracture of the skull was produced by a direct blow and there was no evidence of self-wounding. Ministro en Visita, Special Investigating Judge, Alberto Chaigneau, submitted a report which concluded that ''at this stage of the process, it can be presumed that the investigated facts constitute a crime of homicide in which it is necessary to accuse as co-authors the functionary of the carabineros, uniformed police, who carried out the arrest and the functionaries of the CNI who submitted him to interrogations, and, as an accessory after the fact, the doctor who provided a certificate stating that Alvarez Santibanez was in a good state of health when he left the said CNI institution''.

Although it is not the policy of Amnesty International to request specific forms of punishment, it believes that individual responsibility for serious violations of human rights should be established under the law of the country. The medical groups of Amnesty International were also particularly concerned that a physician failed to follow the code of professional ethics in making a false statement on the health of Alvarez Santibanez and asked its medical groups to express their concern.

The unlawful activities of the CNI are also responsible for several unexplained deaths of political opponents of the government. Police allege that Alberto Salazar Briceno and Iris Yolanda Vega were killed when a bomb they were carrying exploded accidentally. Reports suggest, however, that the couple had been arrested two days before and were in police custody at the time when they were killed.

Further confirmation of the methods used by the CNI to eliminate potential opponents was provided by the death of Daniel Acuna who, according to the police, committed suicide by exploding a bomb while they were attempting to arrest him. The official explanation of the death of this venerable socialist leader was sufficiently incredible, and the material evidence so overwhelmingly against it, that a Special Investigating Judge was appointed. Because there was the evidence of unlawful killing by the military the judge soon declared herself incompetent. A military judge is now dealing with the case.

Short-term detentions and harassment of political leaders and trade unionists were common during the year. At the end of November 1979, 46 members of the banned Christian Democrat Party were detained, a seminar on the rights of youth was forbidden and invited foreign delegates were expelled or prevented from entering the country. In November 1979 alone Amnesty International estimates that more than 600 people were detained, mostly from shanty towns in Santiago, while police were allegedly looking for members of the Movimiento de Izquierda Revolucionaria (MIR), the Movement of the Revolutionary Left, banned since 1973.

In April 1980, 12 peasant leaders were detained on the grounds that they were planning agitation for 1 May. Juan Jara, the leader of the taxi-drivers' union, was also detained and held for several days for criticizing the government's economic policy.

On 16 April 1980 it was announced that the Supreme Court had upheld the acquittal of eight carabineros who murdered 14 peasants shortly after the 1973 coup-bodies had been discovered at the end of 1978 in a mine in Lonquen. The court ratified the ruling of a military tribunal which in 1979 declared that the eight carabineros were protected by the Amnesty Law of April 1978-a law benefiting those who committed crimes between September 1973 and March 1978.

Since 1973 the government has disregarded the interests and feelings of the relatives of disappeared prisoners. In September 1979 the Military Court announced that the bodies found in Lonquen would be returned to their families. The relatives then received the news that their dead had been buried secretly. The Cardinal of Santiago immediately issued a condemnation stating ''human dignity has been violated in the most extreme manner''.

In October 1979, 18 bodies were found in a secret grave in the cemetery at Yumbel near Concepci'on. It has now been established that they were workers from a paper factory, teachers and railway workers from Laja and San Rosendo, who had been detained by the police in September 1973 or had gone voluntarily to the police station accompanied by priests. The explanation of the government that ''disappearances'' were the result of civil war was again offered, but all the evidence shows that the victims were ''unarmed, handcuffed and adequately guarded''. They were taken from the police station to be transferred, it was stated, to the Los Angeles Regiment's political prisoners' camp. They never arrived there, but were killed and secretly buried, remaining ''disappeared'' until the discovery and identification of their bodies at the end of 1979.

Other secret graves have been discovered in Mulch'en in the Eighth Region of Chile and other places; unmarked graves in site 29 of Santiago Cemetery are believed to contain more than 300 bodies, many of which may be those of ''disappeared'' prisoners.

During the year threats were made on several occasions against members of the Agrupacion de Familiares de Presos Desaparecidos, Association of Relatives of Disappeared Prisoners, by a group calling itself the Comando Carevic, named after a police officer who died while allegedly dismantling a bomb left in Santiago by ''terrorists''. This appears to be a right-wing group, and has so far done no more than make threats. Other reports of harassment of relatives of ''disappeared'' prisoners are common. In August 1979 Amnesty International appealed for the protection of the safety of the wife of a ''disappeared'' prisoner, Pedro Silva Bustos, after she had received a death threat signed by Comando Carevic. Amnesty International requested the Chilean Government to take steps to end the illegal activities of the Comando Carevic.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. People who take the trouble to read that Amnesty International report will see how serious a matter it is that the Deputy Prime Minister said what he did on Tuesday in praise of Chile.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance today is one that I have long held and often expressed. It relates to the appalling road conditions that apply generally in Queensland in comparison with those in other States and, more particularly, it relates to the roads of north Queensland. There are many expressions that adequately indicate the position. For instance, some say that the further north one travels the better the fishing but the worse the roads. When one travels from Perth to Townsville one puts one's watch forward by two hours, but when one arrives on Queensland roads one sets one's clock back 10 years. I think that is a fair reflection of the problem that I am trying to explain. I am convinced that southern politicians, and Ministers in particular, have no real concern for the situation whatsoever. They have no regard for equality between the States, their road systems or the people as the Constitution was intended to guarantee.

SPEECH.PARA: As the national highway system is a Federal responsibility, I target my remarks particularly on that subject. I do so in the knowledge that national highways became a Federal responsibility in 1974. At that time Queensland's road construction was substandard, having taken a back seat in that State's priorities to other services such as free hospitalisation. Road funding has never held a high priority in the expenditure of that State or this Commonwealth's Government. For instance, the Commonwealth's rate of expenditure on welfare, defence, payment to local governments and many other services has been increasing in real terms over recent years. Roads expenditure is one of the few expenditures by the Commonwealth that has actually decreased in real terms, particularly if the yearly increase in the road construction costs index is applied.

At the same time the Commonwealth, by way of indirect taxes through the oil levy, has considerably increased its revenue to the extent that in 1980-81 the combined income from levies and excise from fuel based products amounted to $3,944m or 11.22 per cent of revenue. While I know the argument that this is an allocation to Consolidated Revenue, in view of the diminishing real terms expenditure on roads, there must be a reassessment of priorities so that a larger portion of this road tax can go back to road construction, to the people who pay those taxes. There must be a realisation by Commonwealth Government Ministers that expenditure on roads is just as vital-for expanding and developing our industries, for decentralisation, defence, trade and tourism-as is expenditure on welfare and other Government commitments. In fact only by encouraging trade, industries, tourism and decentralisation will sufficient funds be generated in the future to feed the ever-increasing welfare burden that this Commonwealth has experienced. I wish that I also had time to raise a grievance on the problem of increasing age pensions and a national pension scheme.

I have requested figures from the Department of Transport to emphasise Queensland's particular problem. I know that other States may have similar problems, but today I intend to emphasise my own State's case. On the basis of the lesser standards adopted and agreed to in 1980 between the Commonwealth and Queensland, it would require, on 1980 prices, $1,094m to upgrade Queensland's national highway system to its proper standard. On the basis of the 1980 Commonwealth national highway grant to Queensland, this would take 30 years to complete; that is, it would be completed by the year 2010. On that rate of expenditure the position is impossible because a new road has a normal life expectancy of only 15 to 20 years. So we are quickly going out the back door into the billy goat cart tracks situation. Honourable members should bear in mind that this expenditure is of a level inferior to that of Victoria and New South Wales where Rolls Royce conditions are enjoyed, compared with Model T Ford conditions in Queensland.

There is an injustice in the split up of the national roads funds allocation. For instance the length of national highways in 1977 in three States was as follows: Victoria had 690 kilometres, New South Wales 1,335 kilometres and Queensland 3,922 kilometres. In 1981-82 the national road allocation was divided as follows: Victoria $53m, New South Wales $104m and Queensland $60m. Aggregating the road lengths and the funds for the three States that I have mentioned, Victoria, with 12 per cent of the highway system, gets 24 per cent of the cake; New South Wales, with 22 per cent of the national system, gets 48 per cent; and Queensland, with 66 per cent of the national highway system, gets a meagre 28 per cent of the funds. There is no justice in the allocation or the formula from which it had its base.

I understand that the original formula in 1974 was based on population, registrations and other factors. It was dropped at a later date. The yearly allocations to each State since then have been distributed simply by escalating from the defunct base. So the system is still inequitable. Any population factor in this defunct formula does not take into account the tremendous transfer in population to Queensland over more recent years and the consequent loss of that population to southern States. But a formula should be on the basis of needs, not only population. Under the present appropriations Victoria getting double the funds in comparison with its road length, can afford four-lane highways, while Queensland, which gets only 42 per cent of its entitlement, has to suffer a national highway system that has gravel surfaces in some places, very narrow bitumen, broken edges to that bitumen and one-lane bridges. The southern States would never tolerate this situation, nor would their politicians.

I understand that last weekend 10 people died on Queensland's roads. One can only speculate on the extent to which this Government may have contributed towards those deaths through an inadequate apportionment of available funds. If the cake cannot be equitably divided it is imperative that the Commonwealth make an extra injection of funds to increase substantially the present allocation of $303m for 1981-82. There are particular difficulties in a State that is well endowed with many days of summer heat and a very high rainfall. Also, Queensland is decentralised to a greater extent than any other State in the Commonwealth. The climate and the spread of population mean extra costs in road construction. Those who hold the purse strings should go out and see for themselves the actual condition of the highways. As I mentioned earlier, the road deaths and the often forgotten statistics of accidents, the cost of hospitalisation and the resulting permanent disability and drain on the pension system, must be evidence enough of the need for urgent and immediate action.

It is also necessary for the State Ministers responsible for roads, who meet as the Australian Transport Advisory Council, to look carefully at the formula and come to a useful decision. I recommend to the Queensland Minister for Local Government, Main Roads and Police that that Council should prepare a case for consideration. He should use his considerable debating skills, as the most senior Minister on that Council, to persuade his State colleagues that Queensland is not getting a fair share. His energies would be better directed to this cause than to continual criticism of the Federal Government, through the Press, without any really substantial argument. I do not overlook certain initiatives taken by this Government in recent times, such as adopting the tender procedure for works to enable private contractors to compete. I feel this will allow more and better constructions to be built at the same price.

If I were asked to nominate the matter which generates the most argument and which is the most politically sensitive at this time to most northerners, it would be roads in all their forms. There are other matters that are of concern to the State for which I can offer advice. However, the responsibility for such problems does not rest wholly in the Federal area. One is licensing and regulating the weight of transport vehicles that use the roads. Too often they are the last on the roads in floods and the first back on them when the floods recede. No roads are constructed to withstand this abuse. In a State where the railway offers active competition, I wonder whether these heavy transport vehicles pay their fair share towards road maintenance for the damage they cause. These trucks take over the roads such as they are, in Queensland, a developing State. I believe that a greater contribution should be made by the user of the roads, thus lessening the expense met by the taxpayer.

Speed limits should be set at levels determined by the condition of the roads. A 90 kilometres an hour speed limit, as recently suggested, might be the level that the roads will bear. Fringe benefits would be better road manners, less fuel consumption and fewer accidents and deaths. That this occurs was shown recently in an American survey which followed a similar reduction in speed limit. Overall action needs to be taken on both State and Federal fronts to eliminate the appalling position of our northern roads, which are substandard and really a national eyesore. I issue an invitation to any Federal Minister, as I have to our Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt), to come north and to see and experience the situation for themselves. I am sure that if they see the potential of north Queensland and experience the crippling handicap of its transport system it will assist them in their deliberations on road funding and result in a fairer allocation of road funds to Queensland. The Federal Government is responsible for national highways. If we do the job properly we will do all of Australia a service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Opposition it is my duty to criticise the Government. Normally I enjoy that task but today I do it with considerable reluctance because the issue I propose to raise is one that I had hoped would be free of party politics. I refer to the present crisis that has occurred because of the failure of the Federal Government to make vital decisions that need to be made immediately if the bicentennial celebrations in 1988 are not to be a total fiasco. For the better part of this year I have hesitated to say anything because it has been my wish that there be no friction that will harm the very smooth and harmonious relations and operations of the Australian Bicentennial Authority, its board and its staff.

SPEECH.PARA: The House will recall that the Authority was announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in April 1979. It had the total support of all the leaders of government in this Parliament, the State parliaments and the Northern Territory. I am sure I speak for everyone on the Board when I say that when we first met in April 1980 there was an air of expectancy and excitement that we were embarking on a great adventure and that we were all honoured and privileged to participate in the planning of the Bicentenary for 1988. We saw 1988 not only as a magnificent opportunity to celebrate 200 years of European civilisation in Australia, but also as an opportunity to assess those 200 years, acclaim our successes, note the failures, and set ourselves and future generations new goals, objectives and perspectives for the next 100 years.

The Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) acknowledged the need to plan well ahead by initiating the Authority in April 1979. Although the Bicentenary was nearly nine years away, there was an enormous amount to be done and an early start was essential if it was to be a success. Initially the Authority concentrated on setting up the structure and staff to handle adequately the challenging program ahead and working out the general directions they felt the celebrations should take. State committees were appointed, offices acquired, the theme 'Living Together' was adopted, and a bicentenary symbol was designed. At the same time, a great deal of thought was given by the staff and the Board to the format of the Bicentenary so that it could achieve its objectives. It was felt that the celebrations should take place at a number of levels so that there was total involvement of all Australians.

At the national level it was felt that there should be a major activity or activities that would attract the attention of the whole nation and bring visitors to our shores from many other countries. Two projects were suggested early on that seemed appropriate for such a celebration. These were a world expo in either Sydney or Melbourne, and, of course, the 1988 Olympics. The former Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, had approached the Bureau of International Expositions which has the control of world expositions, for 1988 to be set aside for an Australian expo. It is history now that after a detailed feasibility study costing some hundreds of thousands of dollars, Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra decided not to proceed. Largely because of some irresponsible Press reporting that used 1988 costs to give an inflated price and ignored the benefit of the residuals that would still be there after the Bicentenary, the Federal and State governments got cold feet and decided not to proceed with either of the projects. That, however, is history. A similar fate befell Melbourne's attempt to gain support from the Commonwealth for its application for the 1988 Olympics.

The Authority then decided that if a major world exposition could not be undertaken, Australia should consider a modified expo. With this in mind an approach was made to the Queensland Government, who immediately accepted the offer on the understanding that funds would be provided for a feasibility study, as it was for Sydney and Melbourne, and that the Commonwealth would agree to share the costs, estimated at approximately $200m in today's prices. Incidentally, the $200m is a total price, but as in the case of Sydney and Melbourne one must take into account the residuals that are there after the expo is over. For months now both the Authority and the Queensland Government have been attempting to get a decision from the Australian Government, without success. The situation has reached a critical stage where, unless a decision is made to proceed in the next few weeks, there will be no hope of the modified expo being granted to Brisbane for 1988. The BIE has the final say in who holds world expositions. The many countries who would normally participate in a world expo will not do so unless the expo is officially endorsed by the BIE.

The year 1988 is reserved for Australia, and members of the Authority have been overseas twice to present their case. We have been told we have it, provided we make our final presentation on 9 December this year. That is a few weeks away, and so far absolutely no indication has been given by the Australian Government of its attitude towards the Brisbane proposal. If Australia does not present its case on 9 December, President Mitterrand of France is ready to step into the spot vacated by Australia to celebrate, I image, both the end of his seven-year term but, more importantly, the 200th anniversary of the French Revolution. France will almost certainly get the World Expo for 1988 or 1989, and Australia and Brisbane will miss out. They do not have an expo every year. This will probably be the last opportunity Australia has to have an event of world-wide significance, and the responsibility will be directly with the Australian Government.

That is one particular event. But more critical even than that is the failure of the Australian Government to give any indication of its commitment to the Bicentenary at all levels. The Authority has sketched out a program that can basically be divided into three categories. The first category, which I have just described, would be called the 'Centrepiece'. The second category, which consists mainly of activities such as festivals, reunions, parties, re-enactments, contests, sporting events, cultural performances, exhibitions and general entertainment, has been titled 'Celebrate Australia'. This is a type of activity that in the main does not require a great deal of forward planning. One, two or three years are probably more than enough for 99 per cent of these functions, with the vast majority requiring little government funding. The few suggestions that will be of a national or international character, such as the tall ships proposal, an international air race, a South Pacific festival of arts and an international military tattoo, will need some funding.

The third category, however, is to be called the 'Bicentennial Legacies Program'. The object of this category is that a range of capital projects be undertaken at national, State and local level which will leave a legacy on the ground for future generations of Australians. For example, at the local level it is expected that local government will undertake such projects as bicentennial libraries, historic restorations, cultural centres, sporting complexes, swimming pools and a range of other amenities. It is hoped that the State and Federal governments will similarly undertake fewer but more significant projects to leave something memorable for future generations at that level. Some ideas for the States include bicentennial parks and, for the Federal Government, national tree planting projects, science and technology exhibitions, historical publications, film and television productions, and maritime and aircraft museums.

Ideas like these are spilling into the Bicentennial Authority by the hundred from communities all over Australia. Committees have been set up over the past 18 months to work on such projects. But the interest of people is waning considerably because they are not being given any idea of the commitment of the Federal Government. It is envisaged that these local works of a capital nature will be funded approximately one-third local, one-third State and one-third Commonwealth. In a budget presented to the Commonwealth it was envisaged that the Commonwealth would contribute $5 per head for a total of $80m for this category over a six-year to seven-year period. Scaled-down budgets have also been suggested and presented to the Government which, in my view, would make the Bicentenary a joke. The total amount requested from the Government for all categories on the program was $420m over seven years.

The Government has had these proposals before it for months and it will not give the Authority the slightest indication of what seeding it proposes. The frustration of the Board and the staff is reaching a point where people are asking themselves whether they are really being taken seriously. They are asking themselves what is the point of meeting regularly, planning various projects and putting them to the Government to be rejected or ignored. If the Government does not wish to spend any money on the Bicentenary then it should say so. It should not waste the time of very busy, dedicated citizens who have more to do with their time than travel around Australia at taxpayers' expense directing an excellent staff at a very considerable cost to plan activities and projects that will never eventuate.

I think the Board has reached the point where it does not wish to waste its time on the Government's money. I assure honourable members that it has not put me up to this. I am reflecting its views and what has been said at its meetings. Board members are just so boiling mad. If all the Government wants is fireworks and marching girls displays then it would be better to disband the Authority for the next five years, put it into mothballs and re-form it in 1985 or 1986 when it could plan a froth and bubble Bicentenary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Mr R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance today is for two categories of people who have specific kinds of disabilities or handicaps-people who with some very specific and practical help from government could enjoy a greatly enhanced lifestyle. Firstly, I refer to the deaf. Technology has provided deaf people with an opportunity to communicate with each other and with essential services via what is known as a portaprinter-a printout telephone for the deaf which can be run on batteries, is portable and can be carried by deaf people as they move about and linked into a nearby telephone booth to allow them to commuicate with their home, with other people or with essential services. This machine provides a massive breakthrough in the communications barrier for the deaf. Not only can the deaf then talk to each other through written words when they are physically apart, as we do on the telephone, but also it enables them to link up with essential services such as doctors, hospitals, fire brigade boards, government departments, ambulances and so forth, so long as these services have this portaprinter equipment attached to their telephones.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a problem; that is, that these machines, together with necessary attachments, cost about $900 each. For that reason, and given that the profoundly deaf, because of their handicap, do not generally receive a high wage or salary, very few of these people are able to afford to purchase this equipment. Very few Government departments or agencies providing essential community services have installed these machines. The number of profoundly deaf people in Australia is not large; therefore assistance in making this equipment available would not be very costly. It is therefore most unfortunate that this great benefit, involving small cost, is not being conferred on this needy section of the community.

A number of options are open to the Government. It could subsidise the purchase of this equipment through the Department of Social Security. If this is not possible, Telecom Australia could purchase these portaprinters and then lease them to the deaf at a very small rental. Whatever the method of making this equipment more readily available, something should be done. The Government already makes concessions in other ways for those who live in the country in recognition of their isolation. I simply make the point that deaf people are absolutely isolated also. Furthermore, to some extent country people choose their isolation, whereas deaf people do not. I therefore urge the Government to assist the deaf in purchasing this equipment which will do so much to reduce their isolation.

The other point to which I wish to refer today is the need to provide some help for autistic children in Western Australia. It seems to me that autism is a handicap which is not well understood or acknowledged within the general community and which is not supported by government to the extent that it should be. Autism is a very rare behavioural condition which is extremely difficult to diagnose. It is a condition which is not clearly definable. No convincing explanation of its cause has yet been given and there is no definite, tangible medical treatment for its cure. No cure for the disorder can be sought because its origin is not known. It is not genetic. According to the Association for Autistic Children in Western Australia (Inc.) there are as many autistic children in this country as there are children born blind. The Association says that although 45 children between the ages of four and 19 years of age in Western Australia are known to have severe autistic symptoms, there could be many more than that-possibly 100.

Autism is a tragic problem for the child and his family. The autistic child is not blind but he cannot comprehend what he sees. He is not deaf but he cannot take in what he hears. He is isolated from his environment because he cannot make any sense of it. But he is not physically handicapped. He may be highly intelligent and yet he can divorce himself from bewildered family and live in a world of his own and, as in cases that I know of, he may not respond to his parents in any way at all for many years. This is a neglected area of welfare policy-I suspect not deliberately so, but more because of the lack of knowledge and awareness of the problem. Obviously, much needs to be done.

In Western Australia the Association for Autistic Children comprises a small paid staff of two full time officers and two part time clerical assistants. The Association's overall management is largely conducted by a dedicated band of volunteers and concerned parents. Regrettably, this very active group of people and their Association seem to be penalised at an official level for the degree of self-help they have exhibited in the past. They run an annual budget of approximately $250,000, almost all of which is financed by their own fund raising activities. There has been no direct Government assistance to this Association in the past, although in other States equivalent associations which do not exercise the same degree of self-help as the Western Australian Association have received official Commonwealth Government assistance. Admittedly, the Association has received some assistance from the Lotteries Commission in Western Australia, and the Mental Health Division of the State Government runs the Mildred Creek Centre which caters for the intensive care of a small number of very young autistic children. But in what is primarily a Commonwealth Government area of responsibility there has been no Commonwealth Government assistance at all.

The Association's community integration program, which will cost some $111,000 this year and between $150,000 and $160,000 next year, is proceeding without any kind of salary subsidy for its professional and administrative staff, while its counterparts in other States are receiving some kind of assistance. This initiative provides a most important educational program for autistic children in a totally integrated setting and will help these children to move into established Education Department pre-primary and primary schools. Again, no funds have been made available for the Association's community integration program from the Government's childrens services program. The Association has provided family relief and support services without government assistance of either a capital or a salary subsidy nature. It has had plans to develop a resource centre to help co-ordinate and act as a base for many of its activities. A submission for assistance was lodged with the Department of Social Security. As yet no approval for funding has been received.

The Association has plans to construct a residential pre-training centre in the metropolitan area of Perth for autistic adolescents to prepare them adequately for their futures. This will involve an expenditure of some $300,000 in 1982. There is also a proposal to develop an existing country property into a semi-residential complex for adult autistics at a cost of $250,000 in 1983 and $350,000 in 1984. Submissions for official government assistance with respect to these latter programs will be forthcoming in the near future. The Association continues to be confronted with rising costs in its existing programs. These new developments, involving very substantial amounts of capital, will certainly require some form of Commonwealth Government assistance.

I simply say to the Government that under the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act this Government and previous governments have provided a great deal of much needed assistance to many of the more widely recognised categories of handicapped people. I say to this Parliament and to this Government-I ask the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman), who is at the table, to bring this matter to the attention of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) -that it really is time that we gave more attention and more assistance to this very tragic area of need-autistic children and adolescents. I will certainly be using my best endeavours in the future to ensure that this happens.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to grieve today for the many thousands of Australians who once again find themselves confronted with the horrible thought that they may become the victims of a natural disaster. Before I continue with my grievance, I wish to congratulate my daughter and her fiance, Mr Ken Edwards, who announced their engagement today.
—I hope that the honourable member is not grieving about that announcement.

—No, Mr Deputy Speaker, I am not grieving at all. I wish to continue my grievance for those many thousands of Australians who may find themselves confronted with a natural disaster. It is once again that period of the year when natural disasters such as cyclones, floods, storms, tornadoes, et cetera will inevitably hit some part of northern, north-eastern and north-western Australia-probably all over Australia. If we talk to people in those high risk areas, if we talk to insurers, insurance brokers and loss assessors who are experienced people who have seen and been through natural disasters in the past-be it Cyclone Tracy, the 1974 Brisbane flood, the Brighton hailstorm disaster or the Dalby flood, just to mention a few recent catastrophes-the message comes across loud and clear; that is we have learned nothing from these unfortunate experiences when it comes to budgeting for disaster relief. The Federal Government's expectation for voluntary participation by the public in disaster insurance has proved ill-founded. It has been unable to convince the public that they must have adequate insurance to protect themselves against natural disaster, and yet nature is a fickle mistress. The 1981-82 cyclone season could conceivably bring about a recurrence of the distress and disillusionment which in the past affected the vulnerable and unfortunate people who were victims of cyclones Tracy and Althea. It is even possible that we could look back on these events as minor tragedies.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter of natural disaster insurance has been raised many times in this House. The attention of the Government has been drawn repeatedly to ways and means in which it could, if it were interested, give singular security and peace of mind to the Australian community. Sure, the Government has stepped in with money and support in the past on an ad hoc basis, but it has not guaranteed a secure future either for those Australians who, because of their location, cannot buy insurance or for those who cannot afford to pay for such protection. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is on record as stating that in 1980-81 the Federal Government would provide more than $71m to help the States and the Northern Territory meet the large and unpredictable cost of natural disaster relief. This, I would point out, was a year of relatively minor disasters. In fact the actual expenditure via payments to the States was not $71m but closer to $81m, while an additional $5m was expended via the defence budget on natural disasters and civil defence. Given that the States also contribute, the all-up payout must have been well in excess of $100m. Again I stress that it was a year relatively free of natural disasters. These amounts, of course, are over and above what the insurance industry would have paid to those people with insurance.

What I am concerned about is the welfare of the people and how they are severely affected, both financially and mentally, by major disasters. There is only one way to provide the community at large with disaster relief at a price the Federal Budget and the taxpayer can afford. This way is through a national disaster insurance scheme. What I am also concerned about in a land which is highly vulnerable to the effects of natural disaster-after all, it is not improbable that four, five or more could occur in any one year-is the Government's failure to establish any semblance of budgetary control over natural disaster relief. Is there a bottomless pit to dip into, as the Prime Minister seemed to imply in his answer to question on notice No. 666? I ask this because he seemed to imply that the definition of a 'major' disaster was when the States exceeded their budgets for such a purpose. What he said in the answer was:

The Commonwealth contributes on a $3 for $1 basis to the cost of State expenditure on approved relief and restoration measures in excess of the States' base amount where such expenditures are in respect of a major disaster.

When we consider the Prime Minister's statement in conjunction with the fact that it is up to the States to declare a disaster area, it is clear that we are faced with a completely open-ended budgetary situation. Given the recent rantings and ravings of the razor gang regarding imagined budgetary excesses, one would have expected the Government to make some serious economic assessment of disaster relief expenditure which, after all, is clearly a blank cheque situation.

Back in 1976 the late Eric Robinson made suggestions about a national disaster insurance scheme. This apparently has been shelved, as so many other important matters are shelved by this Government. Honourable members may recall that the Government at that time appointed two specialist committees-a technical committee and a mitigation committee. The proposal was that a pool of general insurers should offer natural disaster insurance against selected natural hazards, with the Commonwealth offering reinsurance facilities. The Government and the insurance industry would actively encourage maximum participation on a voluntary basis. The scheme had its flaws, but at least it was the beginning of a dialogue between the insurance industry and the Government. Unfortunately the dialogue ended abruptly when in January 1979 the Treasurer (Mr Howard) announced that the Government would not proceed with the scheme.

During a visit to Australia this year a world authority on insurance and reinsurance matters was at a complete loss to understand why Australia had not looked seriously at setting up a national disaster insurance fund, one backed by the world insurance and reinsurance markets, especially when countries such as Britain, Switzerland and New Zealand all have such schemes. The visiting British insurance broker explained that overseas schemes are cheaply and effectively administered and relieve government treasuries of huge outlays; to be more precise, they save taxpayers' money.

Let us examine the reasons why in 1979 the Treasurer announced the abandonment of the national disaster insurance scheme which was so close to being operative. It is instructive to do so now, particularly in the wake of the budgetary vandalism wrought by the razor gang in the name of smaller government. When all is said and done, the abandonment of the national disaster insurance scheme in 1979 adds up to the same opting-out of government responsibility which has characterised every new initiative since then. In 1979 the Treasurer spoke of a reluctance to intervene in the insurance industry and in existing natural disaster insurance arrangements when in fact the proposed scheme made clear that existing underwriting responsibilities could be continued by the insurance industry. The Treasurer also spoke of a reluctance to enforce compulsory participation in the scheme when the insurance industry's feasibility study showed that it was merely necessary to extend existing fire risk policies or to impose a levy on property rates.

In New Zealand the Earthquake and War Damages Commission imposes a levy on all property insured against fire to cover earthquake and war damage. Premiums are at the rate of 7c per $100 of insurance cover. The so-called problem relating to compulsion on either insured or insurers is in fact a non-problem. The cost spread over the community would be minimal and a pool of money would be available to relieve suffering and distress in individual circumstances. For just a few cents per household we would have the basis of the pool to permit insurers directly to underwrite risks up to a certain level or to pick up the excess over and above the Government's inflexible budgetary commitment. The matter needs to be looked at quickly and certainly some economic assessment needs to be carried out. With the expertise that already exists in Australia this should not be too time-consuming. Certainly it should not be too difficult to define what disasters are to be protected against, what limits of liability the Government will accept and what limits insurers will bear. With national disaster insurance and reinsurance on the world-wide market all would know they were protected and, the way I see it, the Government would have established budgetary control over disaster relief expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falconer Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take the opportunity in this Grievance Day debate of raising a matter which is of concern to a number of people in my electorate; that is, the future of the Ringwood project under the Community Youth Support Scheme. That project is known as SLEOS, which stands for School Leavers Employment Opportunity Service. The Ringwood CYSS project is actually a long-standing project. In fact it dates from the earliest days of the Community Youth Support Scheme. Indeed, before the program was instituted a group of people in the Ringwood area had evolved a concept for a support and advisory service to the young unemployed and was seeking avenues of funding for that project. When the Community Youth Support Scheme was announced by the Government I called representatives of that group into my office to explain to them the nature of CYSS and the way in which they could qualify for funding under that program provided certain changes were made to the structure of the project that they had in mind so that it would meet CYSS guidelines. I indicate that just to point out that this is a long-standing project which has been successful in gaining approval for funding each year since its inception.

SPEECH.PARA: The immediate problem which arises is that in July this year the premises that the group was occupying burned down. Those premises were an old house in an area that is designated to become a shopping centre car park. The group was able to obtain those premises at a very nominal rental. The grant it received under the CYSS program reflected the very nominal rental it had to pay. Even before the fire occurred the project was looking for alternative premises because it had come to the conclusion that it needed a different type of operation to get to the people in the Ringwood area who needed its services. In particular, it needed a shop-front type of operation which would, of course, involve the project in paying a higher rental to match the commercial rentals which were required in the Ringwood area. Even before the fire occurred the project officers were thinking along those lines, but the fire made its plans even more urgent.

The month after the fire came the Budget, with the announcement that the CYSS program was to be terminated. A month after that came the announcement that the Government had changed its mind and would enable existing CYSS projects to continue at their current levels of funding until next February, when new guidelines would be implemented for a new and improved Community Youth Support Scheme. The problem the project faces at present is that it is operating out of temporary premises which have been made available to it by the Ringwood Uniting Church. The premises are used by a great many other organisations because the church is particularly active. The facilities of the church hall and meeting rooms are used by a wide range of community groups. That use restricts the sorts of activities in which the Ringwood CYSS project can indulge and certainly restricts it in advertising its activities to unemployed youth in the area and in seeking to bring them into its programs in a vigorous way. At present the project is operating only in a part time sense. It is certainly not operating at full steam in the way that it would be able to operate if it had its own premises.

Before the Budget the group had reached an agreement with representatives of the State CYSS Committee that it would be able to obtain in a revised grant an extra amount for the rental it would have to pay in new premises. The agreement indicated an upper level of about $150 per week compared with the $30 a week-I think that was the amount-for its previous premises. It has now located suitable premises, not in the immediate area of the main Ringwood shopping centre but in a subsidiary shopping centre nearby in which the rentals are a little lower. In the main Ringwood area, rentals are about $200 to $300 per week for an ordinary shop front site. In the area chosen by the project the rentals are up to $150 a week. The problem is that the decision announced by the Government limits CYSS groups to their current levels of funding until February, and the present grant does not include an amount which can cope with the extra rental.

I want simply to appeal to the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown), whom I have advised about this subject, that he consider the Ringwood project as a special case to receive a revised grant even at this stage, before the new guidelines come into operation in February, because of its special circumstances. It is not a circumstance which applies to every CYSS project. I emphasise once again that this matter was the subject of discussions between office bearers of the project and representatives of the State CYSS Committee before the Budget and before any decisions were made which affected the whole CYSS program. Certain undertakings were given and certain understandings were reached. On the basis of the understandings which were reached before the Budget, I believe there is a good case for this project to receive some special consideration.

The fear the group has-I must say that to some extent I share its fear-is that if by February, when the new guidelines are implemented, its program is not operating full steam ahead, it will be regarded as being of less importance than other CYSS projects which are operating at 100 per cent capacity. Therefore, under the new guidelines there is a possibility that it will miss out. I do not put that forward as a serious probability, but there is a fear that, in the event of scarce funds being allocated according to priorities, the Ringwood project would slip down the priority list a little and would not receive the consideration it should receive, or would receive if it was operating in its new premises, as has been planned for some time, and was able to carry on the program it has been carrying on successfully for some years.

I realise that the Minister has problems in granting any exceptions because he may face difficulties with a number of the CYSS projects, whose officers can argue that they need extra funds and can use them productively. I believe that in this case there is a circumstance which does not apply to other CYSS projects. This circumstance arises out of discussions which were well in hand before the Budget and before the Government's announcements about the way in which it was going to revise the CYSS project. I ask for the consideration of the Minister and the Government in dealing with this problem and assisting a very good group which is doing very good work in my area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Innes Mr U.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to talk about a matter which affects very seriously some of my constituents and which would apply generally in regard to the difficulties in the housing area at the moment. During previous sessions of the Parliament I raised a number of questions about the operation of certain permanent building societies and expressed concern at the number of homes being repossessed by these societies. The monetary policies of the Government have ensured that even more Australian families will find themselves on the street. The interest rate increases encouraged by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) have placed an unbearable burden on many families, who will find their monthly house repayments simply beyond their means. Penalty rates are applied once an account falls behind, and many societies charge 60 per cent a year-an astronomical amount. Often they do not even inform the borrowers that the penalty applies but simply request payment of the normal monthly commitment. If the penalty is not paid it continues to accumulate penalty rates at the rate of 60 per cent per annum without the borrower's knowledge. The borrower will receive an account for a substantial amount. If he or she cannot meet the commitment, the repossession procedures commence.

SPEECH.PARA: In a recent case a borrower sued the Statewide Building Society over the legality of penalty rates. He based his case on an English precedent, the matter of Parker and Butcher v. the Sheffield and South Yorkshire Benefit and Building Investment Society. In that matter the judge, His Honour Lord Romilly, ruled that any contract not making its conditions fully clear to both parties was not legally binding. In the recent Statewide case in Victoria, the borrower argued, on the basis of the Lord Romilly judgment, that because the penalty rate was silent in the contract it could not be imposed. The case was to go before the Master of the Supreme Court, but at the door of the court the Society withdrew and agreed to waive the penalty as an act of good faith. If it really believes that penalty rates are legal, the waiving of a sum of more than $3,000 seems to be an expensive act of good faith. I think it can be argued that the Society withdrew because it recognised that it would lose and the question of penalty rates would be thrown into the melting pot. Indeed, if penalty rates were proven illegal, every borrower who has been charged penalty rates over the years under a contract which does not spell out the penalty rate would be liable to have that money returned. In a later statement of the client's commitment to Statewide, which was demanded by the client's legal adviser, the solicitor found a legal expenses claim for more than $700 which had been charged by Statewide for the fees of its solicitor, Allan Moore, for the very case to which I have referred. The Society claimed later that this was a mistake. Some sort of mistake! Dealings with building societies seem to be riddled with mistakes. I argue that there has to be a point where mistakes become the policy of that society. In one case involving Statewide, Allan Moore and Co., the same firm of solicitors, wrote to the borrower's solicitor-mind this-pointing out that the solicitor had a Statewide agency in his office. The company suggested that, therefore, he should not be involved in action against the Society. The solicitor retained the case. Three weeks later his agency-a lucrative asset to his business-was withdrawn by the Society. Embarrassed at users asking why he had lost it, the solicitor asked Statewide to put in writing a reason for the withdrawal. The Society refused. To this point, as I understand it, he has had no explanation. Perhaps the most damning comment made by an Allan Moore and Co. representative in front of a solicitor and his client was that if the borrower won that particular litigation then Statewide had friends in higher places who would have retrospective legislation introduced to cover the problem.

Another serious problem occurs with building societies after repossession and eviction. As I have pointed out previously, a number of houses in these circumstances are sold below their value. The figures are 91 per cent in Victoria, 92 per cent in Western Australia, 87 per cent in South Australia, 71 per cent in Queensland and an incredible 100 per cent in Tasmania. The only State where there appears to be some reason is New South Wales, where the rate is 32 per cent. Nearly all these houses are sold privately. One can suspect two reasons for this. The first-the kindest-is that there are so many houses being repossessed and families thrown on to the streets because of rising interest rates, unemployment and the anti-worker thrust of the Government's policies that societies are too embarrassed to sell these homes by auction. The second reason is a little more sinister. I do not have time to refer to it but I will do so in some future debate.

After a house is sold the mortgage insurer still wants his pound of flesh. The government-owned Housing Loans Insurance Corporation is involved in this. The Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh) cannot absolve himself from the responsibilities involved with the organisation which, in fact, repossesses houses. I instance a man in Frankston who bought a house for $42,900. Owing to circumstances beyond his control he fell behind in his payments at the end of a year. He owed $1,200 but the society was claiming $2,000 with ubiquitous penalty rates which, I would argue, were illegal. The man could not raise the $2,000 and his house was repossessed. The house later went up for private sale for $36,000. After the sale the society claimed its shortfall from HLIC, and now HLIC is claiming $9,000 from the borrower, who is in desperate financial difficulties and whose family is out on the street. He cannot pay. His future is very bleak. The irony is, of course, that the borrower pays an insurance premium of about one per cent of the loan to guarantee the society against default. The borrower then finds himself or herself in grave financial difficulties after the eviction. I do not have time to deal with the rest of this case in specific detail.

In general, if the solicitors who are involved in these sorts of dealings are honest then they should ensure that the dealings with HLIC or the building society concerned are straightened out and that people are advised of their obligations so that they can take steps to rectify the situation. The borrower must have some guarantee. The regulations must ensure also a code of ethics. Societies must ensure that borrowers are informed that the chattels in the house belong to them and guarantee that if and when the house is sold a reasonable amount of these chattels is returned to the borrower. At the moment these societies are stealing the possessions of these people by selling them as goods included in the price the house is sold for. The goods are not returned to the people who, in fact, own the property. Borrowers must be guaranteed also that when their house is repossessed resale is by public auction. Every attempt should be made to ensure that the proper price is charged to the borrower and that he has at least some reasonable time to find a way of getting out of his dilemma.

Since my initial revelations in this session the Minister has written to me as an apologist for the building societies. He has argued that they come under State law and are therefore outside his control. However, I argue that the HLIC is under his control. Through it he could force building societies to sell homes on the open market so that the borrower has every opportunity to have the debt excused. The present practice not only disbenefits borrowers at a time when they are in desperate financial difficulties but is open to widespread corruption. I believe that the latter is taking place. Further, I argue that the Minister, if he is genuinely concerned about families, ought to call all State Ministers together with a view to drafting a national code of ethics and regulations to govern building societies.

The Minister in his letter had the audacity to suggest that homes were sold below cost because of the condition they were left in by dispossessed borrowers. This is a perfect example of the 'kick'em when they're down' attitude of this Government to the underprivileged and those who fall by the wayside in the dog-eat-dog ethics of the present society. However, I urge the Minister to show compassion for these people and to take steps to close legislative gaps that allow building societies to exploit families and other borrowers so openly. Until he does, thousands of Australians will suffer the consequences. He has the responsibility to do this. HLIC is the body by which these terrible imposts are applied to Australian home buyers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time left in this grievance debate I wish to refer to the proposed future development of Perth Airport. In doing so my concern is that such future development should benefit both airport users and should be in the interests of the nearby residents. As far back as 1972 a joint Commonwealth-State committee was established to investigate the future options for Perth Airport. In 1979 this committee produced its report, which was subsequently approved by both the Federal and State governments. The committee basically recommended that Perth Airport be retained as the sole primary airport on the present site until at least the year 2005 and that this development should be in accordance with a master plan based on a detailed analysis of development options and their effect on the environment and nearby land use.

SPEECH.PARA: Following this joint committee's report the Department of Transport is now reputed to have a nine-year plan which includes, among other things, the upgrading of the existing domestic terminal, a new air traffic services centre and control tower and a new international terminal. The upgrading of the existing domestic passenger terminal is in progress. The proposal for the traffic services centre and control tower is presently under inquiry by the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Public Works, which held a hearing in Perth at the start of this month. Next February the Public Works Committee will be inquiring also into the proposed international terminal. With the two new facilities in the rundown to the construction phase I am extremely disturbed that the master plan, which I mentioned earlier, is incomplete and unavailable to the public. I argue that no building should take place until the master plan is complete and agreed upon by all the major parties concerned.

Perth Airport is becoming extremely busy. It is estimated that by 2004 total annual aircraft movements will amount to nearly 200,000. In the light of such a forecast it is obvious that the long term development of Perth Airport must involve the construction of additional runway length. For its part, the Department of Transport has described in a public information leaflet that it has distributed taxiways in the north-west corner of the airport, where it proposes to site the new international terminal, and a 300-metre extension on the southern end of the main runway. These runway extensions at both ends would bring aircraft movements and, of course, associated noise closer to the neighbouring residential areas.

In contrast to what the Department of Transport proposes the two local councils most affected by Perth Airport and future developments, the cities of Belmont and Canning, have both argued in submissions to the Public Works Committee that the construction of a parallel widespaced runway, two kilometres east of the present main runway, should proceed as soon as possible and that the new international terminal should be sited appropriate to that new runway. Air traffic movements to and from such a new runway would then be moved away from the residential areas and, moreover, industrial land. I am presently not in a personal position to conclude that the immediate construction of a parallel widespaced runway is economically justified. But I am certain of one thing and that is that no development, be it the air traffic services centre and control tower or the new and international terminal, should jeopardise the possible future development of a parallel widespaced runway either now, in the medium term or in the longer term.

At this point I return to the need for an airport master plan. In the absence of such a master plan the dangers of the sort of prejudicial development that I have just outlined are very real. In my mind the solution is clear. Any proposed construction should be delayed until the master plan is completed. Such a master plan, incorporating all possible developments, could then be available to the public and open for discussion before the Public Works Committee hearings into the international terminal, scheduled, as I said earlier, for next February. If we proceed in this way we will ensure an integral and planned development of Perth Airport covering all possibilities: The traffic services centre and control tower; the international terminal; a possible parallel widespaced runway; and all the roads and services that local councils will have to supply to service those buildings. If we do proceed in this way we will ensure that there is no building in the short term which will prohibit what may be necessary and, indeed, desirable in the longer term.

In raising this issue this afternoon I follow on the detailed work which has been done by my Opposition colleague the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley). I do not believe the development of Perth Airport is a matter of Liberal Party or Australian Labor Party politics. I say publicly that I want to join with the honourable member for Swan in a bipartisan way in arguing for the need for a master plan. Both the cities of Canning and Belmont have argued most strenuously also for the need for a master plan to precede any development. They have proper concern for the residents living in their own cities. They are concerned also that the airport service the needs of Perth and Western Australia, and quite clearly the conclusion that I have reached and have argued this afternoon is the only one that should be advanced. If we are going to plan something as important and complex as an international airport in such a way that it will last and service the community in the interests of the people who live nearby right through to 2005, surely we have to know what we are going to do. We have to have our plan set out logically so that we can continue over time.
