It is ludricrous to proceed with constructing a building in the absence of a master plan, especially if we proceed with a building that may jeopardise the construction of a parallel widespaced runway that could well be needed in the medium, if not the longer, term. I repeat that the master plan should be completed and be available to the public for open discussion and debate so that all major parties can agree on what is to happen at Perth Airport. Only then should construction take place.

I want to let his family and friends know that Pat Farrell had a lot of mates in the national Parliament.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's betrayal of the national interest in preventing Telecom from developing and marketing Australia's own information utility, relying on foreign data bases and handing over local outlets to commercial exploitation.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's decision to prevent Telecom Australia from developing and marketing Australia's own information utility is a savage and all too predictable attack on this country's intellectual capacity. The announcement by the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) that the vital area of providing 'on line' information services via telephone and television sets will be left to private enterprise has very serious implications. It condemns Australia to an entirely passive and derivative role in the information revolution which is now sweeping the technologically advanced world. The Myer company will operate Canada's Telidon system while the Packer interests will use the British Prestel system. Australia's role in this information revolution will be merely that of a consumer. We will only take. We will have nothing to give and there will be absolutely no incentive to innovate in this area, not only for ourselves, but also for other nations. This is just one more tragic example of how Australia is missing the bus with new technologies. The latest decision by the Government is no accident but one more in a long series of actions by which the Fraser Government is winding down Australia's intellectual capacity. It will turn us into a sterile and derivative society-the world's quarry and not much else-unless the present disastrous tendency is reversed.

SPEECH.PARA: The decision to let market forces run our information systems will widen the gap between the 'information rich' and the 'information poor'. Instead of democratising information access as is technologically possible, the Government's decision will simply shore up existing power structures. The Government fails to grasp that control over information is central to the survival of democracy. Already more people are employed in information, broadly defined, in Australia than work in agriculture, mining and manufacturing combined. In the 1990s we may ask: 'However did it happen that we lacked the will to establish an information utility of our own? Why did we sell out to foreign interests without even thinking about it?'

The implications and capacity of an 'on line' information utility are enormous, and comparatively easy and cheap to set up. It involves the combination of three things-computers, telecommunications and television. We need to adopt some new language to describe it adequately, apart from brand names such as Viewdata, Prestel and Telidon. Some Americans use the term 'compunications' which is an ugly word. I prefer and propose the French term 'telematique', or 'telematics' in English. All that the consumer needs is a telephone line, a colour television set, and an adaptor and key pad as a single unit, to link the telephone line to the television and allow the user to key himself in to an appropriate segment of the data base that he wants to use. This means that the user so equipped is then plugged in, from home, to an international data base. By 'keying in' his requirements he can be plugged into an information network which can give him up-to-the-second data, both general and specific to his own needs, on employment, housing, education, entertainment, tourism, publications, government decisions, sporting results, currency fluctuations and weather reports anywhere in the world. A person from Sydney or Melbourne looking for a new job or new house can, simply by keying in his qualifications, experience, income needs, choice of the types of community he wants to live in, the educational facilities available to his children, seek to fulfil his needs in other countries, such as Europe, North America or elsewhere-not just in other Australian States. This immediately makes the concept of a global society, with all its challenges and risks, a reality.

This capacity confirms that in the decades that lie ahead information will continue to be the greatest single factor in our economy, not just in employment but in value, more than mining, manufacturing and agriculture combined. The sooner we recognise that fact the better because when we do recognise it we will have to assert that the control of information resources is too important to be confined to private ownership. Like education, public health, water supply and defence, an information resource needs a close collaborative effort between all users and all suppliers and in all segments of society. Private enterprise should certainly have some role to play-we can argue about the extent of that-but the pursuit of profit must not be allowed to squeeze out the national interest. In effect what the Minister is saying is: 'So far as the telephone lines are concerned, you can use Telecom's lines-to that extent they constitute the common carrier-but the control of what goes into the system and what comes out will be determined by private, profit seeking interest and that is all'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—Shame indeed! We have passed legislation to ensure that the ownership of Australian newspapers cannot be in foreign hands, except in the case of Rupert Murdoch. The Minister is always willing to make an accommodation for Rupert Murdoch. But in this case the Minister said to private enterprise: 'Use whatever data base you like; use any information utility you like. Australia will continue once more to be simply passive users'. That is appalling and it suggests a great cutting back in Australia's intellectual capacity. The future of Telecom was canvassed in the report by McKinsey and Company, Inc. 'Capital and Policy Requirements for the 1980s: Telecom Australia' which was completed in June 1980. It stated that the efficiency of Telecom was affected because of the deliberate policy of holding back Telecom's level of capital investment. Understandably the Government failed to release this report until its hand was forced by the initiative of Senator John Button, the shadow Minister for Communications. This led to a debate in this House on 14 October. The Minister then took two quite absurd lines-each mutually contradictory. The first line was to attack the Opposition for 'bucketing' Telecom, which is the exact reverse of the actual situation in which the Minister is nailing Telecom to the cross and we are trying to prevent that crucifixion. In the second line, and maddest of all, he said that subject to priorities being worked out he was all for extending Telecom's capacity.

SPEECH.PARA: Then there was the decision last week to squeeze Telecom out of telematics and to hand it over to private enterprise. The Minister is taking more positions than the Karma Sutra. I will quote the Minister's words in case listeners and honourable members find it hard to believe what he said. On page 1978 of Hansard, in response to the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins), he said:

. . . this Opposition wishes to bucket Telecom at almost every opportunity. The consultants did conclude . . . that there was scope for the development of new policies within Telecom to cope with the expected high growth in demand for new services.
What is the rational conclusion that we must draw from that? Obviously that he is going to give the green light to Telecom to move into the telematics field. He went on:
Telecom has already moved to the establishment of management practices which will enable it to react more effectively to the demands of major customers for new services.

Again there is no hint that Telecom is going to have this right cut away from it and that it is going to be handed over to private enterprise. He then goes on to say, in that avuncular manner in the House that we are all so familiar with:

For the life of me, I cannot see why those cannot be provided by subcontracting facilities by extending the services and facilities available within Telecom itself. An integral part of the McKinsey recommendation provides for capital grants from the Government for those services provided by Telecom where the returns do not meet the costs of capital. This latter proposal will require very careful consideration at a time when it is essential for the Government to contain the growth of Budget expenditure. It is clearly a matter of determining appropriate priorities.

There is every evidence to believe that the transformation from telecommunications to telematics is the greatest growth area in the economy, both in money terms and also in community value. If we follow what the Minister said, we could only assume that the green light would be given to Telecom. But two days later, on 16 October, the red light was given and Telecom was told: 'Nothing doing! You are not going into that area. It is being handed over to my mates'.

The Minister's foolish and reckless action will cause great hardship to the very interests that he has been elected to this Parliament to represent. Rural telephone users are heavily subsidised by profits from telephone use in the big cities and the major trunk lines. By performing major surgery on Telecom, cutting off potentially the greatest growth area in telecommunications for the rest of this century, handing it to his fat cat friends in private industry as part of a corrupt bargain, the Minister is depriving rural Australia of the opportunity to share the financial rewards of the communications revolution. The Minister is so used to charges of corruption that he does not even respond when I mention it in my speech. The point was made by the Acting Chairman of Telecom, Mr T. E. May, in a letter of 9 January to the Minister, that Telecom was well placed to go into the information revolution. The letter makes the points that videotex systems other than Prestel-the system chosen by Telecom in distinction to the Telidon system which is being proposed by Myer-are relatively untested. Prestel terminals will always be less expensive than terminals associated with Telidon, the system to be introduced by Myer. For the next few years, Prestel terminals are likely to be between one-half and one-third the price. Private enterprise stood to earn $5m as information providers to Telecom in the first full year. Set suppliers would earn about $3m. Telecom proposed to leave private enterprise a number of functions. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter to the Minister from Mr Tom May, the Acting Chairman of Telecom.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
9 January 1981
Rt Hon. I. McC. Sinclair M.P.
Minister for Communications
Parliament House
Canberra, ACT
My dear Minister

Your letter of 15th December, 1980, sought further advice on certain aspects of the proposal to introduce a public videotex system in Australia. Each of the matters you raise has been given very close attention during the development of our proposal. The following paragraphs point up the main issues and a detailed analysis of the relative merits of Prestel, Teletel and Telidon is included in Attachment 1.
CHOICE OF SYSTEM
Background Knowledge

On four occasions over the past three years senior experts from Telecom have visited overseas countries to investigate the major world Videotex developments. The French, Teletel, the Japanese, Captains, the Canadian, Telidon, and the British, Prestel, have all been examined at first hand. In addition Telecom Research Department has experimented with Videotex techniques for a number of years.
The Maturity of Prestel

It is clear from our investigations that systems other than Prestel have been developed only to the stage where retrieval of text can be adequately demonstrated. They are all at a similar stage of development to that of the UK Prestel system in 1975. The conversion of the UK demonstration Prestel system from a one machine trial system without billing to a public service system with billing, response frames, security, closed user group facilities, charges incurred to date, etc., with adequate software support and documentation took the BPO nearly 3 years and around thirty man years of effort using the top programming talent in the BPO. Similar development work still needs to be undertaken with the other systems.

The telecommunications operating authorities in West Germany, the Netherlands, Austria, Hong Kong and Switzerland have selected and are introducing Prestel systems. In addition the Prestel International service linking eight countries including Australia has recently been confirmed following a trial. There are a number of other administrations in Europe and South East Asia including New Zealand and Malaysia currently investigating the introduction of a Prestel service.
Terminal Costs, Availability and Australian Content

By choosing Prestel the probability of terminal availability for the three broad classes of terminal i.e., the domestic and business user markets and the Information Provider (IP) market are maximised, the costs of each minimised and the circumstances for maximum participation of Australian manufacturers are most congenial. Prestel terminals will always be less expensive than Telidon terminals and for the next few years are likely to be between half and one-third the price.
Timescales Possible

It is our opinion that at this point in time and probably for the next few years that only the Prestel service could be purchased for a public service in Australia. The market undoubtedly wants to move quickly into Videotex. This is understandable when private enterprise will stand to earn around $5m per annum from Information Provider (IP) services even in the first full year of public service and set suppliers can expect to generate income of around $3m per annum in the same period. IP earnings will be independent of the system chosen and so delay would mean delayed profit and service opportunities.
Public Service Requirements

A public service rather than a trial is required in Australia in view of the substantial investment private enterprise will be required to make to ensure the success of the service. (At least one IP and one Terminal supplier are known to be contemplating budgets of $1m).

In our view it is essential if private investment is to be attracted for all parties to have confidence in the long term prospects for the service and a policy that would indicate the possible transient use of private investment would not be conducive to a successful service. In particular, Australian TV manufacturers have found provision of sets for the trial broadcast teletext services to be a loss making venture and are unlikely to invest substantially again in a trial service with a possiblity of a limited life.
Enhanced Graphics

Although Telidon has an enhanced graphics capability compared with Teletel or Prestel at this point in time the commercial value of this enhancement is unproven. Experience in the market place has shown that the prime requirement of Videotex is for textual display and that the use of graphics is declining. The enhanced graphics of Telidon will not materially assist in travel illustration, real estate sales, teleshopping and signature verification, all of which are recognised important market opportunities for Videotex. These applications require a picture and in this development the BPO have already demonstrated 'Picture Prestel' a high definition colour TV standard picture capability.

In this regard a typical example of the interest being shown in the 'Picture' capability is a request from Mr A. V. Curtis of the Real Estate Institute of Canberra in relation to the requirement by members for compulsory listing of all properties within 48 hours and the interest of agents in Sydney and Melbourne in Canberra properties.
Inappropriateness of Tender Procedures in this Case

It was the view of senior management in Telecom that if tenders were called to supply a public service Videotex system for Australia at this time so many critical areas of systems development would be undeveloped or unproven in systems other than Prestel that not only would the preparation of the schedule have been very difficult and added a significant delay to the project but a tender evaluation would be bound to select Prestel. It was on this basis that the certificate of inexpediency was granted and negotiations opened with the BPO. It is my view that this remains the correct course.
ROLE OF TELECOM AND PRIVATE ENTERPRISE IN VIDEOTEX
Telecom is aware of the Government desire for maximum participation of private enterprise and has formulated its policy accordingly. Telecom has decided:

1. Not to offer Umbrella Information Provider but to leave this to private enterprise. Telecom would limit itself to providing service type information of the type presently provided on the telephone recorded information service.
2. To only demonstrate and take orders for sets on an agency basis in agreement with private enterprise leaving the responsibility for set supply to private industry.
3. Not to enter the terminal maintenance market.
4. To encourage private in house Viewdata systems such as that developed by ICL compatible with the Prestel system.

5. To purchase the Prestel software enhancement developed by the Bundespost which allows access through Prestel to private third party computer databases to encourage as wide as possible access to information.
Adoption of these policies means that over 80 per cent of employment and earnings from the Videotex industry will be outside Telecom.

With regard to Telecom's proposed participation there are a number of compelling reasons for this which worldwide have led, with a couple of minor exceptions in the USA, to Videotex services with public access being virtually all organised and operated by the telephone operating authority with that body owning the equipment.
The more important of these reasons are:

1. To separate ownership of the publishing media from individual information publishers. It would not be acceptable to other publishers if one of their rivals owned and organised the service. With a projected forecast of 100-200 major publishing organisations on Videotex in the first year, it is difficult to see how an acceptable consortium could be organised. Telecom as a non-publishing organisation, does not suffer from criticisms of preference.

2. Telecom would provide a national service as soon as possible at a uniform price. To undertake provision on this basis to country areas would require cross-subsidisation from metropolitan areas. It is doubtful if private organisations would be willing to undertake this task with the result that country areas would not be connected to Videotex at unit fee or community rate. Other cross-subsidisation that may be necessary would be in the provision of services for disadvantaged groups including deaf, disabled and migrant groups.

3. Development of a national market by Telecom would maximise the benefits of the service and its penetration in the whole community including providing maximum readership audiences for publishers and the maximum potential sales for terminal suppliers, i.e., Telecom would 'make the market' and give private enterprise 80 per cent of a large unified service.

4. On a practical basis with Telecom organising and developing the service it can place the equipment in its premises at locations which minimise network cost and can readily organise multiplex links and short code access for progressive national coverage in a more efficient and timely manner than would be possible if a third party or parties were involved. In addition, as an operating body experienced in system evaluation, Telecom would not be committed to one particular equipment supplier and would select future systems to maximise customer benefits.

5. Telecom, as an operator of world standard telecommunication services has the proven skills, resources and experience and organisation required to run a high quality public service on a 24 hour, 7 days a week basis.

6. Telecom, as the public telecommunication authority has an established relationship with other telecommunication authorities and would participate in the international co-operation in Prestel enhancements and the marketing of Videotex services in other countries to Australian customers.

It is my view that private enterprise, in its role of user, publisher and terminal supplier as well as private individuals as a whole, whether living in the country or the cities would be best served by Telecom supplying the network and data storage capability and arranging the service.
The ongoing development and marking of the Videotex service would be a joint activity bringing together in a consultative committee the information providers, the terminal suppliers and Telecom.
VIDEOTEX AND BROADCAST TELETEXT

Broadcast teletext with its limited page capacity (around 500 pages) and its one way, in delay, mode of operation does not match the utility of the Videotex service with its interactive capability, its virtually unlimited page capacity and high speed page retrieval. Experience shows that whilst the market for teletext may be domestic, the applications for Videotex are for business, commercial and government services, with a widespread use of specialised terminals at least in the initial phase.

Already Channel 9 have opted out of teletext and its prospects of commercial success are uncertain. Those stations that have so far implemented a trial broadcast teletext service ATN-7, NBM-3 and BTQ-7 have done so with a Prestel compatible system. It is extremely doubtful whether a Telidon receiver or adaptor compatible with Australian Broadcast TV will be available in quantity in the foreseeable future.

With the two services being largely complementary the prospects for broadcast teletext would be best served by a rapidly expanding Videotex service. This is what potential users and publishers require and would be best achieved by implementing the system as proposed as quickly as possible.
I trust that the further information included above has clarified to your satisfaction the reasons for the course of action we are proposing.
Yours sincerely
T. E. MAY Acting Chairman

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. Recently the matter was referred to Mr Malcolm King of the Bank of New Zealand in Sydney to get his opinion on whether Telecom should be allowed to go into this system following the statements that Telecom wanted to go into prestel. The head of the Department received a telex from Mr Malcolm King dated 10 September 1981, which stated in part:

SPEECH.PARA: D. Private sector will have major and substantial role with Telecom as management co-ordinator, thus providing useful, beneficial interface between Telecom and private sector.
E. No capital investment appears needed from Telecom. Their contribution is use of existing network, billing system and staff as co-ordinator.
Mr King recommends there should be direct involvement by Telecom. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the telex to the head of the Minister's Department.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
To: Lansdown Department Communications Canberra
From: Bank of New Zealand Sydney
10 September 1981
The case for Telecom proposed participation in videotex prestel system is supported for following reasons.
A. Without Telecom as convenor it is difficult to see how there can be an effective national network system.
B. A national system which does not preclude independent private systems linked to it seems to optimise public interest.

C. Telecom appears to have absolute minimum role, contributing services which it already controls, manages and runs well. Increased use of existing telecommunication network and billing system helps optimise use of public asset.
D. Private sector will have major and substantial role with Telecom as management co-ordinator, thus providing useful, beneficial interface between Telecom and private sector.
E. No capital investment appears needed from Telecom. Their contribution is use of existing network, billing system and staff as co-ordinator.

F. If the concept of a uniform charge for access by users is adopted (and I support this concept) then a valuable information service becomes available at reasonable price on an equitable basis to the whole Australian community. This appears of special benefit to dispersed rural centres helping to achieve government objective of minimising disability of rural living.
G. The technology for the system is available, proven, can be adapted to accept new and further technology as it becomes available and can provide international access from national system.
H. There are favourable prospects for participation by Australian manufacturing industry and for increased employment by information providers.
Regards, Malcolm King

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. This is one of the most appalling decisions that this Government has made. It is essential that the House recognise the full significance of what is happening. It is very significant particularly that, so far as the rural area is concerned, we are starting to dismantle the potential profit areas, that $7,000m asset that is Telcom. It is a national outrage that Telecom should be destroyed in this way. If we find in future years that Telecom is essentially confined to the provision of rural telephone systems, that more and more people are moving away from the traditional use of the telephone and more towards the use of data bases, that we are hearing information relayed through our television system with the only thing in between being the telephone line, this could be very good for society-providing that Australia exercises and maintains the right to keep control of its own system.

SPEECH.PARA: The estimated cost of conversion by Telecom, which was confirmed this morning-the cost of the key pad and adaptor that I have referred to before-is $200, in 12 months' time. Currently the cost is between $A200 and $A300, but if the Prestel system is adopted it could operate in Australia within seven months. The Canadian Telidon system, which is comparatively untried compared with Prestel, would take two or three years before it could be adopted in Australia. So it means that for the price of $200-less than a Space Invaders game-one could turn his home into a data base and have access to information all over the world. Yet this foolish, reckless and short-sighted Government is not prepared to trust the Australian people, to trust that great Australian instrumentality, Telecom, to run the system effectively. Instead it says: 'If you have got a worthwhile growth area, something that could be a major asset, let us hand it over completely to foreign ownership and let the fat cats of private enterprise take the profit'. I think the decision is appalling. I think we will all live to regret it. I hope that the Minister-even this Minister-will reverse the decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —In spite of the rhetoric of the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones), nobody in his right mind could be convinced that the honourable gentleman has anything to support his argument other than an emotional commitment to a philosophy which certainly most honourable members do not espouse. It is a philosophy which states that only the Government and a Government enterprise can run anything in this country. That is demonstrably not so. I will go into the background to the introduction of this Prestel system and the reasons for the Government's decision, but first I will go through a few of the things that the honourable member said. He claimed that on successive occasions I refused to respond in this place to allegations of corruption. I say to him that at no stage have I refused to acknowledge the allegations. However, those who make such allegations would do well to look at themselves first. I completely reject every one of the allegations. I say to the honourable member that it does him little credit that in that respect he follows in the paths of some of his colleagues on that side of the House.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to the Prestel system, there is no doubt that there are tremendous advantages for social contact and for the business community in the introduction of telematics into Australia. The argument is not about whether it should be introduced or whether it is technically practical; the argument is about whether the Australian Telecommunications Commission, a statutory monopoly not created for this purpose but designed to function to provide telecommunications services throughout the length and breadth of this country, should be given a prior opportunity to move into this highly sophisticated new field. It is quite true that a series of arguments has been advanced by Telecom and by others in support of Telecom's participation. It is also true that in the early stages of the approach from Telecom it envisaged a much greater capital investment than that which was involved in the last proposal.

The honourable member's argument seemed to revolve around two areas and I would like to identify them. I believe it is essential that the people of Australia realise that, while the geographic extent and the population paucity of this country require a monopoly in the cable system that stretches throughout this country and in the network that provides our telecommunications links, that monopoly is not necessary when we are moving into a new area of technology which demonstrably can involve private enterprise. That it can do so is indicated by the fact that private sector people are involved. The honourable gentleman referred to correspondence from one of the companies interested in the Telidon system to demonstrate that that private enterprise company was very interested in introducing the system. There is no question that there is interest. There is a question of the extent to which such a company can provide a dispassionate, valid and broad-based telematics-type system, but I will go into that in a moment. The second part, and to me the important part, of the Government's decision is the funding requirements that lie behind the Government's believing that at this stage it is not appropriate for Telecom to be involved. The capital cost for computer hardware is estimated at about $3m spread over five years with payments of about $600,000 a year.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is chicken feed.

—It is true that it is not a large sum of money but it is $3m. I am glad to hear the honourable gentleman say it is just chicken feed. To most members of this House it is a significant sum of public money and public money is not money that can be just thrown away. It is necessary that we spend something like a quarter of a million dollars on maintenance. Again, the honourable gentleman would say it is not a large sum of money, but it is an additional quarter of a million dollars a year. Internal staffing costs and overheads would be of the order of $4m a year. The first year's loss is assessed at about $1.61m and the second year's loss at about $1.39m. It was hoped that in the third year the results might be more positive.

SPEECH.PARA: First, there is the philosophic difference-we claim that there is no need for a public monopoly to be involved in the field because demonstrably the private sector is interested and has a capacity to be involved-and, secondly, there is a cost consideration; perhaps it is not a great cost but it is nevertheless a cost that has been identified at a level which would reduce the financial ability of Telecom to be involved in those other areas that are its prime responsibility. The Government's concern is that the telecommunications services-the telephones and the line networks of this country-should have prior claim on the funds available to Telecom. The honourable gentlemen of the Opposition are not worried about how much money is spent. They are quite prepared to see taxes increase and funds borrowed by Telecom to any extent without worrying about the overall impact on the economy at large. We on this side of the House believe that it is critical that Telecom, which is the major borrower in this area, should be contained to the same degree that others are contained and that interest rates and the borrowing capacity of individuals should not be prejudiced by our expanding Telecom's intrusion into the market place by giving it the limitless right to borrow. Even on Telecom's assessment of the first couple of years, there will be a cost and there certainly will be a negative cash flow.

Thirdly, a series of suggestions has come out of some of Telecom's claims as to why it should run the system. In the House this afternoon the honourable gentleman suggested that he believed that only with an independent government statutory authority would we be able to have a dispassionate presentation of information on these telematic machines. Let us see how and why that would apply. The concept involves computer access to a series of information pages. Those information pages are to be provided through the black box, which the honourable gentleman quite correctly has identified, which will be attached to a television screen and linked with a telephone. The range of information provided on those pages is dependent upon the preparedness of the person seeking to provide those pages for inclusion in that data bank to pay whoever purveys the system. There is no suggestion that anybody operating the system will have anything to gain by saying to even my friend the honourable member that any information he provides should not be there. The only basis by which a cash flow can be obtained by whoever provides the system is by ensuring that the maximum number of pages with the maximum amount of information should be included in the system. The basis of payment is to be that the providers of those pages of information will charge at a certain rate those who seek access to them. The commission for providing that information is the payment to the provider of the telematic system.

The whole of the commercial operation, the commercial interest, is to maximise the number of pages involved. In other words, the actions of a commercial provider of the information would have directly the reverse consequence to that which the honourable member suggests, for it is very much in the interests of the commercial provider to ensure that the maximum amount of information is available through his telematics operation. There will be more than one operator in this field. Each operator will be intensely in competition, I suspect, with the others. Without doubt the one which provides the widest base of information will be the one in most demand. It is true that there is a feeling in Telecom that in some way there will be intrusion on the sort of information that will be provided; in other words, it is suggested that if one is operating a particular brand of product, and has a financial connection with the company providing the telematic system, one will not allow a competitive brand to be shown on the screen. I do not believe that to be so. Indeed, I believe the reverse will be in the interests of the person who is to provide the telematics system. It is true that a few other arguments are advanced in the telex from Mr King that the honourable gentleman tabled a few minutes ago. It is worthwhile my running through those. Mr King suggests that, without Telecom as a convenor, it is difficult to see how there can be an effective national network system. Of course Telecom has to be involved but I do not believe it need be involved as a convenor. The telecommunications system is the telephone link, the cable network around Australia. It is in that area that Telecom has to be a party. Indeed, it is obvious that it will be involved not only in the Prestel system but also, equally, in Telidon, Antiope and any other system that might be introduced, for it provides the only cable network throughout this country.

Therefore, Telecom certainly has to be involved and I believe that those who involve themselves in the area should also take account of the fact that the only way in which they will be successful is for them to provide local call access to the data banks wherever they may be, in the country or in the cities. It is only on that basis that a reasonable demand will be generated for the information provided. Mr King then says that a national system which does not preclude independent private systems linked to it seems to optimise public interest. Certainly there is no preclusion of independent private systems, but why have a national system? Can we not have, through the telecommunications link, a series of national systems? That is our objective-to have not just one but a series of competitive systems, and we hope we will ensure that they are all compatible.

Thirdly, he said that Telecom appeared to have an absolutely minimum role. It is true that as the project developed Telecom was not as involved as it was at an earlier stage. Telecom was prepared to the maximum to ensure private enterprise participation, but the point is that this is a statutory monopoly. Why should a government monopoly in this order be permitted to run something in which demonstrably private sector persons are interested? While the private sector would have a role in the Telecom proposal, why should the Government instrumentality have a role at all?

The next point made by Mr King is that the private sector will have a major and substantial role with Telecom as management co-ordinator. As I have suggested, Telecom will be involved, whatever the system, through the cable link-up. Further, he said that no capital investment appears to be needed from Telecom. I have pointed out that if we take the staff, the overhead, the computer hardware, and the software maintenance there is a significant sum of money required in order to operate the system, and those sums and personnel will be removed from what is Telecom's predominant responsibility. We all accept the technologies available. I have addressed myself to the concept of the uniform charge. I believe that whoever provides this system needs to ensure that a uniform charge is available and uniform access throughout Australia.

A number of allegations have been made about my handing this over to my friends. I can well understand nobody in the commercial sector being friends of the Australian Labor Party, but at this stage there is no identification of anybody being interested. Indeed, the Government is setting up a study to determine to what degree there should be licensing; to what degree there should be a determination of technical standards; to what degree there should be an integration and overlap between the different systems; if there are three or four telematic systems, to what degree that black box that is purchased by the individual can be used in each one of the households and for each one of the systems. The individual, of course, would then pay the charge on the system to which access could be gained. The study will determine what access should be given to the Telecom network in terms of systems comparability for private systems.

We need to make sure to the maximum that in the technical capability of the different systems we do not lock ourselves out of advancing technology. For example, it is said that the Telidon system has some greater capacity in graphics at this stage than Prestel. There is no doubt that Prestel certainly is more advanced in terms of its availability. The other advantage is that Prestel also provides access to an international network that is not, at the moment at least, available in other systems. There is no identification by the Government of any individual as taking over the Prestel system from Telecom. As I indicated a moment ago, we are studying the degree to which licensing, determination of technical standards, and access to the Telecom network should be prescribed. It is certainly not the decision of the Government to hand over to any one individual the access to this system simply because we do not believe Telecom itself should be involved in the provision of Prestel. It is necessary that there be access to the Telecom system. It is necessary that Telecom be a participant in whatever system introduced, and we believe that it is also necessary that there be some licensing procedure to ensure that the public interest is protected.

The basis of this proposal today is simply the philosophic approach of the Labor Party, its commitment to Public Service employment, and its concern that nobody in the private sector has a capacity to provide the service, which demonstrably it now does. The Government does not accept that the private sector cannot provide this service. We believe, indeed, that it is an area where the private sector has a tremendous challenge. Under the licensing procedures I have identified as being now under study, I believe the public interest will be more than adequately protected.

TALK.START.PARA: —The discussion is concluded.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 October, on motion by Mr Fife:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Upon which Mr Dawkins had moved by way of amendment:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: 'whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that-

(1) the University/College of Advanced Education amalgamations proposed in Newcastle, Armidale, Wollongong and Townsville should not proceed until arrangements satisfactory to both parties to the amalgamation have emerged;

(2) those Colleges of Advanced Education in New South Wales and Victoria for which no satisfactory amalgamation proposal exists should be funded until proposals satisfactory to the staff and students of the colleges involved are determined, and
(3) the Government should provide guarantees backed by special financial support to ensure that where amalgamations occur the-
(a) existing range of educational opportunities are maintained;
(b) employment security of staff is safeguarded, and
(c) academic integrity of the institutions is protected'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate is resumed on this Bill, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill, the Australian National University Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Canberra College of Advanced Education Amendment Bill, and the Tertiary Education Commission Report and summary of recommendations for triennium 1982-84.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to speak on the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill, one of the Bills to which you referred. I want to raise a matter of importance to South Australia and to agriculture generally, and I refer in particular to the Waite Agricultural Research Institute. I refer, firstly, to Volume 2, Part 2, of the report of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, starting at page 73, which deals with the University of Adelaide. At paragraph A4.143 the report refers to the Waite Agricultural Research Institute. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Universities Council, and previously the Universities Commission, have, in their funding of the University of Adelaide, recognised the special role of the Waite Agricultural Research Institute.
The report continues:

The University itself in 1980 examined the position of the Institute within the University structure and, following the recommendations of an internal review committee chaired by Justice Roma Mitchell, agreed to a new administrative and funding arrangement for the Institute. Nevertheless, the Council has continued to receive representations seeking to have the Institute recognised as a national research school, arguing, at the same time, for funds designated in some way as supplementary to the University's existing commitment to the Institute.
The Tertiary Education Commission, after explaining why it did not accede to the request of the University of Adelaide, continues at page 75 of its report:

The Council is aware of the contribution that the Waite Institute has made-and is making-to agricultural research; it is also conscious of the work of high quality being undertaken in this field in other institutions. It is of the view that the quality of the research carried out by any institution will be the essential basis on which the scientific community will accord it appropriate recognition.
The report goes on:
The Council is confident that within the resources available to it, the University of Adelaide will be able to maintain the effectiveness of the research programs of the Waite Institute.
Finally, the report states:
The Council-
That is, the Universities Council-
has also noted the University's-
That is the University of Adelaide-

representations for special consideration to be given to the capital requirements of the Institute. However, in view of the limited funds available to the Council for building and minor works programs in 1982, the Council is unable to make any special provisions for the Waite Institute. The University should continue to assess the capital requirements of the Institute in the context of priorities for the University as a whole.

I do not have time to develop my arguments in this debate, but I want to bring to the Government's attention in this forum the need for continued research in agriculture and the reason why I have taken up the claims of the Waite Institute with the Government. The Minister for Education (Mr Fife) is well aware of my action in pursuing this matter, and I take this opportunity of thanking him for his assistance. He has arranged meetings between myself and many of my colleagues from South Australia who are interested in this matter and members of the Tertiary Education Commission, as well as following the matter up with subsequent meetings and correspondence. The Minister has certainly gone out of his way to ensure that our case-that is the case of the South Australian representatives in support of the Waite Institute-has been properly considered.

By way of background perhaps I ought to explain two things. Firstly, it is acknowledged to be of great importance for us to implement technological changes in manufacturing industries in order to maintain our efficiency and our position amongst our trading partners. So it is just as important that we adopt technological changes and undertake research in agriculture to ensure that we maintain our lead as, if not the best, one of the best farming nations in the world. Secondly, I have been in a fortunate position of seeing the astounding advances being made in agriculture. No doubt they are occurring elsewhere in Australia, but I have a diverse farming electorate where enormous changes have been made in farming techniques leading to the introduction of many new crops and a more intensive use of the land. These developments have brought home to me the need for ongoing research programs to assist in ensuring that the land reaches and maintains its full potential.

Let me give some examples of the sorts of things that I mean in my electorate. Land in my area which was known as the 90-mile desert has now been developed into grazing and cropping land. Grazing land to the south of that area around Keith in South Australia is now the centre of a thriving seed production industry, boasting a turnover of millions of dollars and exporting lucerne seed in particular. Farther south a potato industry has been introduced and still farther south new areas of vines have been introduced and each year a substantial area is now devoted to oilseed production. The lower rainfall areas of the Malee north of Pinnaroo, which were once considered harsh and, by some, even marginal grazing and cropping country, are now being tried for irrigated vegetable production.

Accomplishing these giant strides forward in increasing the productivity of the country has not all been plain sailing. Shortly after I entered this Parliament a new insect pest-the lucerne aphid-found its way to Australia and caused severe damage to the grazing and lucerne industries. A large proportion of the grazing industry in the lower rainfall areas of my electorate, including the 90-mile desert, as it was called-to which I have previously referred-was seriously affected by the lucerne aphid. On that occasion the Government acceded to my request to provide just under half a million dollars to assist the South Australian Government in breeding a sufficient number of wasps to control the aphid population. Subsequently, a number of lucerne breeding programs have been undertaken in an effort to find a suitable aphid resistant variety of lucerne. At the same time, some farmers from my area went to the United States of America to see whether any of its lucerne varieties could be used here or could be used as breeding stock. That was a case when we undertook the research after the attack.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. This is all highly illuminating and fascinating. But perhaps the honourable member would indicate the relevance that these agricultural breakthroughs have to the Bill before us.
-I think it has been a very wide-ranging debate. There is no substance to the point of order.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The matter is relevant to clause 4. As I was saying, in relation to the aphid problem we reacted after the attack and we are still really seeking a suitable alternative lucerne variety to the old Hunter River variety. I am concerned that we should maintain, if not increase, our research to ensure that the new and more intensive farming techniques can be sustained and, indeed, improved. We should be looking more to the future and not merely relying on our ability to solve problems as they arise.

SPEECH.PARA: Farmers are probably the most significant group of conservationists in Australia; not the ratbag type of conservationists, but the real conservationists. Farmers know that their future lies in the soil, the environment and nature. Therefore, I have been involved in seeking assistance for a number of research programs, including research into pest management programs and programs aimed at developing management techniques for bee colonies to improve crop pollination. More and more we are trying to use natural controls on pests. We are adopting measures to assist nature to help us farm. It is hoped that this will reduce our dependence on insecticides and the like which not only are expensive but also must be used with extreme care, as the farmer well knows.

This is an area which I believe warrants government attention. It is an area where we can further help the farmer. I appreciate that there is a limit to the amount that we can appropriate for research. I acknowledge that valuable research is being undertaken in a host of areas which I have not mentioned-by universities, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and others. There is no doubt that this is extremely beneficial to the rural sector. I make the point also that nearly all farmers levy themselves to contribute to that research. Nevertheless, I urge the Government to bear in mind the importance of the Waite Agricultural Institute to farming in southern Australia. The Waite receives funds from government through the University of Adelaide, from farmers through research grants from levies, and from generous endowments and trust funds which have been set up for research purposes. My plea is that this important research centre continue to receive a high priority in the distribution of available research funds.
Sitting suspended from 12.57 to 2 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has moved an amendment to the second reading of the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill. I indicate at the outset that the Government is opposed to the amendment. Before dealing in detail with the amendment moved by the Opposition, let me state that the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill 1981 appropriates funds for tertiary education and implements the Government's decisions to provide for a small increase overall in real terms in the funds for tertiary education in 1982, for a rationalisation and reallocation of available resources between the various sectors and programs, including the costs of the Government's election commitments, and for a limited reintroduction of tuition fees.

SPEECH.PARA: Funds for universities and colleges of advanced education in 1982 have been reduced very marginally by only 0.4 per cent in real terms while funds for technical and further education will increase by 6 per cent in real terms, resulting in a small overall real increase in tertiary funds for 1982. Within these overall funding limits the Bill implements the Government's decisions on the recommendations of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission to reallocate resources between institutions within the higher education sectors consistent with the Government's decisions arising out of the Review of Commonwealth Functions and the Government's guidelines for the 1982-84 triennium. These institutional reallocations, including the increased funding levels for equipment, reflect the Government's decisions to adjust resources from teacher education to the technologies and business studies. Of the 30 colleges of advanced education listed by the Government for consolidation only seven are now outstanding and I will be arranging for further consultations with the State authorities on these colleges. In the meantime, as I explained in my second reading speech, the Bill provides the means for adjusting appropriations for 1982 if satisfactory arrangements can be settled. Where funds have not been provided for 1983 and 1984 in respect of seven outstanding consolidations, these will have to be the subject of further legislation.

The Bill before the House includes provision for the limited reintroduction of tuition fees. This puts into effect the Government's view that students who are not undertaking study towards first awards or those who should not be exempt on other grounds should be required to make a contribution to the cost of their academic studies. The amendments to the Australian National University Act and the Canberra College of Advanced Education Act are consistent with these provisions in the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill. Based on 1980 enrolments, my Department estimates that 13,000 students will pay fees next year as a result of these provisions. The honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) during his address last night attributed other estimates to Senator Carrick. The House needs to be aware that when answering a question in the Senate yesterday Senator Carrick referred to estimates published by the Federation of Australian University Staff Associations, not to the estimates of my Department.

There is also provision in this Bill for several new initiatives, including funding arrangements for the support of special research centres of excellence and the development of community language courses, both of which were included in the Government's 1980 election undertakings. Increased provision for certain non-government teachers' colleges is to be provided in recognition of the special role of the non-government education sector of the community. The Government has taken note of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission's comments on the falling participation rates of young people in higher education and will be asking the Commission to undertake an examination of this situation. I note that in terms of overall student numbers the Commission has reported that the planning ranges which it originally proposed for the 1982-84 triennium should be achieved.

It is my belief that the legislation before the House is a clear indication of the Government's continuing commitment to tertiary education, tempered by its acceptance of its responsibility to meet priority education needs within the limits of available resources. As I indicated a moment ago the Government rejects the amendment moved by the Opposition which refers to certain of the proposed college amalgamations. Colleges of advanced education in New South Wales and Victoria, for which at present no satisfactory amalgamation proposals exist, can be funded in 1982 under the legislation before the House. The range of educational opportunities where amalgamations occur and questions relating to employment are matters for the institutions concerned. I conclude by saying that it is nonsense to suggest that academic integrity is at risk. This is protected by the Acts of the State parliaments which establish the institutions.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Dawkins's amendment) stand part of the question.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that this Bill be now read a second time.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order, on that vote that I just heard, does it mean that there are 52 members who are going to vote for this lousy legislation?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no point of order.

INTERJECT.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governnor-General recommending appropriation announced.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 5-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 6 (Determinations with respect to fees).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will vote against this clause. This is the clause which gives the Minister for Education the power to determine the level at which fees will be charged up to a maximum of $1,000 and the groups of students to whom those fees will apply. The Opposition objects to the reintroduction of tertiary tuition fees in any form. While the legislation makes it clear that the fees proposed to be reintroduced will relate only to second degree students and higher degree students, we will oppose that as a matter of principle. The point is that this move is a clear abrogation of an election promise. In October of last year the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) said that the Government had no intention or proposals for the reintroduction of tertiary tuition fees. The people of Australia were entitled to take that statement at its face value; that is, that the Government did not intend to and would not reintroduce tertiary tuition fees in any form. It was only a few months later, as a result of the Lynch Committee, the razor gang, that the Government decided to reintroduce tertiary tuition fees in this way.

SPEECH.PARA: The question arises as to how an Opposition should act in relation to a government's election undertakings. It seems to us that if the government has a mandate for a particular proposal, there is an obligation on the Parliament not to frustrate unduly the government's putting into effect of that undertaking. When there is a question for which the government has no mandate, the Parliament is entitled to consider it on its merits. However, when the government has made a quite clear undertaking that it will not do something and then turns around and attempts to do it, the Parliament has an obligation to prevent the government's proceeding in that direction. It has an obligation to ensure that the government keeps its compact with the Australian people that it made at the time of the last election. That is why we will vote in this place and in the Senate to remove clause 6, thereby removing the Minister's power to determine fees for these classes of students.

If, as a result of the removal of that clause by the Senate-it is my confident prediction that the Senate will remove clause 6-there are any delays in this legislation, they will be due entirely to the caprice of this Government and to its obstinacy. The Senate has a perfect right-indeed, I would say an obligation-to amend this legislation to remove this provision. Any delays there might be in respect of the funding of universities and colleges around Australia are entirely in the Government's hands. The problem is entirely of its making.

The Minister tries to get out of this by saying that he has said repeatedly, and given repeated assurances subsequently, that he does not intend to reintroduce fees for any other groups of students, but what the Minister has to accept is that all his subsequent assurances are debased by his proven unreliability. He could not be trusted before the last election and he cannot be trusted now. He might carry on about what he likes to call my mischievous activities in suggesting to students and staff in tertiary institutions around Australia that it is the Government's real intention to reintroduce fees for all students, but I will continue to do that because that is my firm belief.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are lying. You know you are.
—I am not lying about the fact that it is my clear belief that the Government intends to reintroduce fees for all students.
—Order! I draw the attention of the honourable member for Fadden to the fact that it is not within the Standing Orders to express himself as he just has.
—Mr Chairman, are you going to make him withdraw?
—You used phraseology like this in last night's debate and today.
—I was not asked to withdraw.
—You parade yourself calling everyone else dishonest, but when anyone questions you, you take exception.
—Order! The honourable member for Fadden, in the circumstances, will withdraw the words.
—I withdraw, but only because you are so pleasant about it, Mr Deputy Chairman.
—The honourable member will withdraw unconditionally.
—Mr Deputy Chairman, you know how I feel. I withdraw.

—The reason for my having that quite firm belief is that it is the stated intention of a noisy and influential group of back benchers on the Government side-a group of which the honourable member for Fadden may not be a member but certainly there are other identified members such as the honourable member for Moore (Mr Hyde) and the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) and apparently 20 to 30 others-who are quite clearly of the view that the Government should proceed to reintroduce fees for undergraduate students as well as for the classes in respect of which this legislation intends to charge fees. There are other reasons for believing that that is the Government's intention in any event. The amount of money which is intended to be raised by the universities and colleges as a result of this measure is, on the Government's estimate, $8m for the whole of the next calendar year and $4m for this financial year. That to me is a highly optimistic and, I suggest, completely unrealistic estimate of the amount of money which is likely to be brought in as a result of this measure. Even if it were true, it would still be a very tiny proportion of the $1,865m involved in the total expenditure on higher education throughout this country. My guess is that in the next calendar year the Government will be extraordinarily lucky to get $4m as a result of this measure.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Education just today said, if I heard him correctly, that he thought that 13,000 students would be liable to pay fees next calendar year. If that is the case, it is still difficult to reconcile the estimate of the number of students with the estimated revenue unless about three-quarters of them are part time students. That may be the case, but during our questioning at the Estimates Committee the Government did not reveal the actual basis of this estimate. I repeat that, certainly in our view and in the view of people who have studied this matter, it is a highly unrealistic and optimistic estimate of the intended revenue. But the Government is not interested in the revenue, quite clearly. It is interested in re-establishing the principle of fees and a collection mechanism which can be easily extended to include other groups of students.

There are other reasons why this proposition ought to be opposed. To the groups of students to whom it is intended to apply it represents a very selective and severe penalty. Those students are, in many cases, the least able to pay the fees. A small proportion of post-graduate students are receiving Commonwealth or university awards of one kind or another. Stingy and inadequate as those awards are, both in level and number, students receiving them will be exempt from fees. The people who have no means of support-public support or university support-will be the ones selected for this specific penalty. They will have to pay a penalty of $1,000 a year because they want to undertake post-graduate studies. That seems to me to be incredibly unfair and unjust. It takes no account of the needs of those students, their ability to pay, or anything else.

What has to be recognised by the Government is that this measure will have a very detrimental effect on the research effort in Australian universities and, to a lesser extent, colleges of advanced education. Post-graduate students are vital to the research effort of this country. To penalise them in this way, which will inevitably result in fewer of them being able to study post-graduate courses, is incredibly stupid. The Australian National University has made some estimates of the sorts of impacts which it thinks that fees will have on its intakes. Because I am running out of time I seek leave to have the letter of the Vice-Chancellor of the Australian National University incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
THE AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL UNIVERSITY
Vice-Chancellor
Professor D. A. Low
22 October, 1981 Mr J. S. Dawkins, M.P.,
Parliament House,
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear John,
The particular issues over tuition fees about which I have pressed my concern, but unsuccessfully, are:

(a) In view of the exemptions from tuition fees which have been agreed to, tuition fees for research students will fall upon those least able to pay for these, the relatively small minority who whilst accepted as suitable by the university are not the recipients of any exempted awards. This, I have to say, is a matter of considerable concern to us, particularly since there has been a reduction in the numbers of Commonwealth Postgraduate Awards since 1977 of 16 per cent.

(b) From the papers you already have from me you will see that, of those who first enrolled this year in our Faculty of Asian Studies-in which the learning of an Asian language over three years is compulsory-over 20 per cent had a previous tertiary qualification. Under the proposed arrangements their counterparts from next year will be required to pay fees. I cannot think that it is in any way in the national interest that there should be any new deterrent to the already all too small numbers in our society who are prepared to go to all the trouble entailed in the learning of a language of one or our Asian neighbours. I believe it is very important that such people should not have to pay tuition fees.

(c) From the papers I sent, you will also have seen that there are significant numbers of Public Servants who enrol for a second undergraduate degree here at the ANU. Under last year's decisions of the Public Service Board, lately reinforced by the Government's decisions following the Review of Commonwealth Functions, the Public Service has to make deliberate decisions that any enrolments for a degree by a Public Servant is in the interests of the Public Service. The suggestion has been made that employers will need to consider paying tuition fees for second degrees when their taking was in their interest. If this idea is to be pursued as regards the Public Service, provision would need to be made for Departments or the Public Service Board to pay tuition fees on such occasions. The simplest procedure, I venture to suggest, would be for exemption to be extended to such cases too. As you will see from the figures significant numbers of Public Servants with previous tertiary qualifications enrol for a second undergraduate degree at the ANU.
Yours sincerely,
D. A. Low

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free Mr R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) has indicated, we in the Australian Labor Party will vote against clause 6 of this Bill for a number of very good reasons. As he indicated, the principal reason is that the reintroduction of tertiary fees is a clear breaking of a pre-election undertaking given by the Minister for Education (Mr Fife). There are also other excellent reasons. I will explore the likely effect of the reintroduction of fees on the participation rates in universities. It has been estimated that this measure will cause a dropout rate of about 40 per cent. This figure has to be assessed against the background of Australia already having one of the lowest student participation rates in the industrialised world. Figures put out by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development in 1978 showed this quite clearly. Australia ranked fourteenth out of the 23 OECD countries with only 46.1 per cent of the 15 to 19-year-old age group being full time students. Honourable members should compare this participation rate with those in Japan and the United States, where over 70 per cent of that age group is engaged in full time study.

SPEECH.PARA: The figures from the 1976 census are also very revealing. Of our population aged 15 and over, only 1.97 per cent held bachelor's degrees. The breakdown in that figure between men and women is very interesting. Of males over 15 years of age 2.83 per cent hold bachelors degrees but only 1.14 per cent of women in that age group hold bachelors degrees. The census figures relating to those holding higher degrees indicates an even lower participation rate. Of the population aged over 15 years only 0.35 per cent hold higher degrees-0.57 per cent of males and 0.13 per cent of females. These figures hardly represent an excess of higher learning in Australia. Yet this fee proposal will cut those miserable figures to even lower levels. Apart from lowering the participation rate overall, the introduction of fees will certainly skew the pattern of participation even more away from those on low incomes, women, and the disadvantaged in our society. The report of the Tertiary Education Research Centre at the University of New South Wales issued in 1978 showed that students at that university were more likely to be from families of higher social status, more likely to be of Australian parentage, and more likely to have attended a private school. The reintroduction of fees will certainly accelerate that trend.

We should also be concerned about the effect of this reduced participation rate on the supply of skilled labour in Australia. It is obvious that the introduction of fees, thus lowering the participation rate, will have a severe effect on the supply of highly skilled and qualified people in this country. The fact that this is happening at a time when demand for those with advanced degrees is likely to grow is, quite frankly, appalling. An article in the Times Higher Education Supplement of 26 December 1980 described the trend in demand for people with higher educational qualifications in the United States. It stated:

Continuing the trend of the 1970s, demand is still growing fastest for technical graduates, particularly those with advanced degrees. Recruitment of engineers is expected to increase by 16 per cent over last year at the bachelor's level, 25 per cent for masters degrees and 53 per cent for doctorates. The last figure is bad news for university engineering departments, which are already finding it virtually impossible to keep new Ph.D.s in the academic profession because industry is luring them away with fatter salaries and better equipment.
In science and mathematics, projected job opportunities are up 5 per cent for bachelor's degrees, but 21 per cent and 29 per cent at the master's and doctoral levels respectively.

That is the pattern of demand that is occurring in the United States. If that trend flows through, even partly, to Australia then we are likely to witness an increasing employer demand for post-graduate degree holders. However, the imposition of fees for second and higher degrees is very likely to have a negative effect on the enrolment and thus the supply of these highly qualified people. Instead, that overseas expertise will have to be imported. We will have to compete as a nation on the world market for highly qualified people because of the measures that we are taking in the Parliament that will work against training our own people.

The greatest fear is that this measure represents the thin edge of the wedge. We are all aware that the Minister has said repeatedly that the Government does not intend to introduce fees for undergraduates. When it is remembered that only 12 months ago the Minister promised not to introduce fees at all then I think any reasonable person must be aware that the currency of this Minister's promises and the currency of this Government's promises have been somewhat debased in recent years. There is a real fear that, unless clause 6 is knocked out of the Bill, we will be back here at this time next year debating proposals to reintroduce fees for all students at tertiary level.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to speak in opposition to this clause. I emphasise that what I believe is at stake here is an extremely serious principle. I think that it illustrates the obnoxious educational philosophy of this Government. The principle that we have here is the view that somehow university and college education is intended to produce basically a production line of graduates who are skilled in a very narrow way and who are not people who will go on towards excellence, towards contributing to the notion of adding to the total sum of human knowledge, towards making the contribution that we need to make in the areas of research. To reduce the number of students who will go into post-graduate programs by the introduction of fees is effectively to cut out that higher aspect of education and that higher aspect of our contribution to the frontiers of human knowledge. Every country-especially Western countries-is concerned to make that kind of scholastic contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: What is Australia doing? It is cutting out that segment by this attempt to reduce dramatically the number of post-graduate students. Let me remind the House what post-graduate studies involve in most cases. They involve usually undertaking an original piece of work for a masters degree or a doctorate. That original piece of work is intended to be a contribution to the sum total of human knowledge. Most of the research being done in Australian universities is not done by the employed academics at the present time; it is done by the post-graduate students working for those degrees. It is a total disgrace for this Government to cut out those types of programs. This shows that this Government is not concerned with the accumulation of human knowledge. It shows that this Government has an absolutely absurd philosophy on education and an absolutely absurd philosophy on research.

The average post-graduate student who will have to pay these fees is a person who has decided that he or she needs to go on to do a higher degree even though he or she has not received a scholarship or an award. This person is usually making substantial sacrifices in order to go on to do this higher study. Usually this person has to work part time or to live on a pittance in order to make his or her contribution. These people usually are very dedicated people, people who have decided on a particular program that they want to investigate. It is on that basis that they have decided to go on in their studies.

Given that situation, I cannot understand the rationale of this Government in attempting to cut these programs by the introduction of fees. I have been told by more than 20 people whom I have come across who were planning to undertake post-graduate studies which I considered important-I have some liaison with universities on these matters-that they are now not able to go on in their studies because they will have to pay $2,000 for a masters degree and $3,000 for a doctorate at the very least. This situation, I maintain, reflects the kind of absurd priorities of this Government not only in the area of education but in other areas as well.

The saving that is supposed to be made is at most $8m. This is absolute peanuts in relation to the total Budget. Given the fact that we now have a Budget surplus of $1,500m, $8m will not add enormously to government funds. What is even more serious in relation to this is that the vice-chancellors of all the universities have condemned this scheme. Not only the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee but also the Federation of College Academics, the Australian Union of Students, not to mention the Federation of Australian University Staff Associations-that is, everybody involved in tertiary education-have condemned the Minister and these proposals. Yet, the Minister does not care about democracy. He does not care about the voice of the people. He does not care about the voice of those who are directly concerned with these schemes. He simply ignores all of that criticism and tries to tell us that there is some rational justification for these proposals. There is absolutely no justification.

We know what the Government is on about. We know that these proposals are introduced in the short term in order to introduce general undergraduate fees in the long term. We say that that will, in fact, be the final result. If undergraduate fees are introduced in the long term, or even perhaps next year-who knows with the promises of this Government; we cannot believe a word it says in relation to these matters-it is very possible that we will find undergraduate fees being introduced even in the term of this Parliament. If this is the ultimate aim of the Government then it will stand condemned by the Australian nation because this shows clearly that it is not interested in the real issues concerning education; that it is not interested in the real aims and purposes of education.
