I remind the Minister that the aims and purposes of education have to do with the development of the whole person, with the development of citizens in this community who are able to contribute to the sum total of the society. Education is not concerned merely to produce an automaton which performs in a factory, in an office or for some other bureaucratic institution. The situation is that the Government has no educational philosophy at all except the attempt to cut out the availability of education to the majority of the people and at the same time to reduce standards throughout the educational establishments, particularly in post-graduate studies. I am concerned, as a former academic, that the level of our universities, which has been an excellent level in the past, will be reduced by these proposals. The Government does not seem to care about the importance of scholastic contribution in this area. It ought to reconsider this matter immediately and to drop these proposals. I say to the members opposite that they ought to vote for the Opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous speaker, the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous), made reference to the excellence in the standard of education in past years. I think that, begrudgingly, he was acknowledging that it was governments of this present Government's political persuasion, going right back to the Menzies days, that put the first real shot in the arm of tertiary education and caused the growth that we witnessed in those years. This Government is not an uncaring government about education. The national education bill amounts to billions and billions of dollars. I concede that the previous speaker may have put his finger on a point when he said that a small percentage of those seeking higher education may be totally reliant on government support and that the $1,000 provided for in the Bill may, for a small number of them, present a problem. But, on the other hand, the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Free), said that many people doing graduate work and post-graduate work are people from higher income homes. He is nodding his head and acknowledging that that is so. These people will not be affected. He has said already that those sorts of people will comprise the majority in this field. His concern is that this legislation will result in the number of such people being increased as a percentage of the total.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Burke jumps up and says how lousy this Government is because it is not giving a cent towards education. The fact is that the average cost to the Government and the taxpayer of Australia for a post-graduate student is about $5,000 a year. That figure is averaged out over a number of different courses. For example, a course in medicine might cost more than an arts course, but the average is $5,000. Whilst the honourable member for Burke presents a picture of the Government not giving a cent the figure of $1,000 provided for in the Bill represents about 20 per cent of the average cost. What he did not say is that the Government is still meeting 80 per cent of the average cost but that it is requiring those people who are doing those courses to contribute 20 per cent.

I believe in and recognise the worth of higher education. I recognise the worth of the work that is done in the pursuit of a second degree. But another argument that the Australian taxpayer has the right to put is that a person is not going to spend his life in a university pursuing degree after degree supported by him. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Burke, who is a self-confessed academic, I think would subscribe to the theory that some people have the right to stay at universities for the rest of their lives never making any worthwhile contribution. The flaw in this view is that the Australian taxpayer has to contribute to this education from his pocket; he has to pay the money to keep people at universities. Even if this draconian measure, to use his words, is introduced, it will still mean that on average the Australian taxpayer is contributing 80 per cent of the total cost of higher education.

I was not listed to speak on this Bill and I did not intend to speak. But one thing that galled me was the continuing vilification, distortions and accusations being hurled at the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) who is sitting at the table. I am aware that the Minister will shortly be speaking on his own account. But I think it is fair to say that when Opposition members say that they are absolutely convinced that the Government will introduce fees for undergraduates, they are putting a convenient interpretation on the words that he used last year. The Minister did not say last year that fees would never be imposed in universities. He did not say that.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did so.

—He did not. The Minister will be speaking in about two minutes; he knows the words he used. Whilst I concede that it is possible to put a convenient interpretation on his words, I think honourable members opposite are twisting the truth to their own political advantage. They are trying to place upon those words an interpretation which enables them to stand up here with conviction and strength and say: 'We do not trust the Minister because he said this once and tomorrow he will do something else'. In the name of fairness I say to them that the best they could say perhaps is that, if they put a certain interpretation on the words that came from the Minister's mouth last year and saw what happened, there is a chance, unless he gives a categorical statement here today, the same thing will happen later. But for honourable members opposite to try to put fear in the hearts not only of students but also of parents whose children are nearing the end of their secondary school education is totally unjust and unfair.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I repeat what I said earlier: Even though I conceded some aspects of the comments made by previous speakers I completely reject the observations of those honourable members who portray a situation in which students pay for their higher education. The average fee charged will be about $1,000 a year and the average cost to keep a person in post-graduate studies is about $5,000. So the Government or, more importantly, the taxpayers of Australia will still contribute $4,000 on average or 80 per cent of the cost of post-graduate study.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to canvass ground that I went over yesterday in my speech during the second reading debate. I want to look at this proposal strictly from the point of view of its equity. I do not want to permit Government members to talk, as they have done so far, in terms of general principles associated with this Bill, the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill, and think that their general principles about user-pays or about lifting the burden from the taxpayers and being equitable to the poor and not to the rich actually apply to what they intend to do here with this piece of legislation. I concede to the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Donald Cameron) the point that he sought to make, namely, that substantial Commonwealth initiatives in the area of tertiary education were carried out by previous Liberal governments. I concede that. Commonwealth responsibility in the area of tertiary education started under the post-war reconstruction Minister of the Labor Government, John Dedman. That responsibility was subsequently picked up and expanded in the period of the Menzies Government. In the area of what are now colleges of advanced education significant initiatives were undertaken when the current Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) was Minister for Education and a former Prime Minister, Mr John Gorton, was Minister for Education.

SPEECH.PARA: It saddens me that this is probably the first time that we have had a reasonably long running period of Liberal government in this country, in which, in fact, processes which Liberal governments helped set in train and which were dramatically increased in our period in government have been significantly reversed. The process has been one of retreat in the area of tertiary education since this Government came to office. This is one aspect of it; how unnecessary it is. The honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) pointed out yesterday that Australian taxpayers spend $20m a day on education. This legislation will present a saving of $8m at the most in a year. So, absolutely no argument can be heard in this chamber that this imposition amounts to a serious cost saving to Australian taxpayers. The relevant clause in the Bill is not a legitimate source of support for the argument which has been made in the past by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) and which seems to have been picked up today by the honourable member for Fadden. That argument is irrelevant in a consideration of the proposition which is before us now.

I want to go a little further, because this proposal has been hawked about as a move of great equity, and look at what its actual impact will be on the individual person undertaking second degree work. This imposition will fall hardest on the poor post-graduate student, not the wealthy post-graduate student. It will do so because of the tax deduction legislation in place under this Government. A businessman on $25,000 to $30,000 a year may decide that he will advance his bachelor of economics by doing a master of business administration degree. There are many people doing that. They will at least be able to argue before the Taxation Commissioner that this is a tax deduction. So for such a person the $1,000 will be more in the order of $500 in real terms.

If on the other hand a woman on a supporting mother's benefit has completed a B.A. honours or B.Psych. honours and wishes to advance to Master of Psychology in order to be able to work in a clinic or whatever, in fact to be able to use the undergraduate degree for employment purposes-because a bachelor's degree is not worth a pitcher of warm spit, she will be obliged to meet the full $1,000 for this purpose. There is the possibility of a tax deduction being allowed but the simple fact of the matter is that her earnings for the year from which she must support herself are nowhere near the realm where a tax deduction would mean anything. So this legislation is an act of discrimination against the poor post-graduate student in favour of the rich post-graduate student, if honourable members look at it in that light. That is the only question of equity which is involved here.

The honourable member for Fadden also went on to talk about average costs of post-graduate degrees being $5,000. I think that the honourable member for Fadden will find that that is the average cost of an undergraduate degree and that the cost of post-graduate degrees is very different. Indeed it probably would be the case if charges were made across the board at the undergraduate degree level. On $1,000, on average 80 per cent would be provided from government sources and 20 per cent would be picked up from the student. But that is not the case with most post-graduate students. The honourable member for Fadden seemed to denigrate anyone with experience in tertiary education, so I had better declare my qualifications. Before I became a member of parliament I was a card-carrying academic. Anyone who has been in my situation will know that the amount of time that is devoted to looking after masters and Ph.D. students is negligible in comparison with the amount of time devoted to undergraduate students and undergraduate teaching. They are not given lectures; they are not given tutorials. All that is done is that they are seen once a month or so-for that matter we do not mark their essays-for an hour to ensure that their work is going in the right direction. So if we take an academic's time and divide it into his salary and divide the cost of his room or whatever into what a post-graduate student gains from it, we would be very lucky in very many areas of post-graduate degrees to come to a sum of more than $1,000. It may just come to that but the amount would not come to much more than $1,000. So here I suppose the Government can be proud; it has completely achieved in this area the user-pays principle to the very considerable detriment of the poor and to the negligible benefit of the Australian taxpayer.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is four-fifths user non-pay.

—The honourable member has not listened to a word I have said. He should read tomorrow what I have had to say to see the answer to the silly point that he is attempting to make. I turn now to the type of person who will be discriminated against by this legislation. The type of person who, one would think, the Australian Government and the Liberal Party philosophy would want, in an Horatio Alger spirit, to encourage are mature age students, students who come into the education process after years in the work force, after assuming family responsibilities and the responsibility for building the community. They say: 'I have reached a point when I wish to expand my knowledge, perhaps advance my qualifications in the job, perhaps be a more useful member of the community, and I want to go outside to make an effort to do a bit of study'. Those people will be the ones who will suffer under this legislation. This is a more, rather than less, common phenomenon.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, I will use examples that have come to me as a result of my having been a card-carrying academic before I came here. I found-most of my academic colleagues commented on this too-that over the last five years an increasing phenomenon in Australian universities has been the bright student first year dropout as opposed to the dull student first year dropout which was the experience of our colleagues as academics when we were younger doing our undergraduate degrees. These people include the student who has to drop out to support his parents; the student who knows that the job market is hard and that a bird in the hand is worth more than a couple in the bush. When they are offered, as they often will be when they have good leaving or matriculation qualifications, a decent job in the civil service, in business or somewhere else, they take it and say: 'Oh well, I have to do this out of necessity. I know that down the line somewhere I am going to be able to pick it up'. I have dealt here with the specifics of this proposal and I do not want to hear again from any honourable members opposite an argument on the generality of this matter, because the generalities of their arguments on the users pay principle are utterly specious when it comes to a consideration of this proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not intended to join in this debate this afternoon but I feel impelled to do so because I want to draw attention to the improper suggestions made yesterday during the second reading debate by a number of honourable members on the Government side of this chamber that the staff of universities are motivated by self-interest. The honourable member for Casey (Mr Falconer) referred yesterday in his speech to the education industry in support of his view that a great deal of self-interest and self-serving is involved in university education. I know that the staff of Australian universities cannot fail to consider this view to be offensive. As a person who, until a year ago, had been a member of the staff of the University of Melbourne for 18 years, I find this self-interest accusation to be both offensive and completely untrue. I point out that all universities have established comprehensive administrative procedures in the approval and development of new courses. In many cases it is far more difficult for teachers in a university to satisfy their own academic boards and councils regarding the viability and academic need for a new course than it would be to meet the criteria of the Tertiary Education Commission. Let us have no more of this nonsense about self-interest and self-serving directed towards people who are dedicated to improving academic excellence in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falconer Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton), I want to point out what I did say yesterday and give at least one of the sources which I used with respect to the assertion that there is a good deal of self-interest being put forward by a number of the groups involved in the education industry. It is certainly not something that originally fell from my lips. Indeed I quoted a member of the Opposition, the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman), in a previous debate when he said--
—That does not make it right.

—This feeling is not just on this side of the House, as the honourable member for La Trobe was trying to say. There is a good deal of feeling, I think, on the part of certain honourable members opposite about some of the views that are put to us. I will quote again the honourable member for Prospect, an Opposition member. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is a danger that the most vocal groups in the community, the groups in the community best able to express their point of view, are able to get away with what I call a rip-off in education.
Later he said:

In conclusion, I come back to my original point. Education, especially tertiary education, has become a holy cow in this country. People do not attack it or criticise it and, what is much worse, they do not question it.
I followed that quote with remarks along these lines, when I said:
There is a degree of self-interest in the propositions that are put forward.
That is, by various interest groups in education. I went on to say:

I do not say that that is necessarily reprehensible. It is to be expected to a large extent. But we should subject it to the same sceptical criticism which we use when we examine proposals by industry groups or any other interest groups that put propositions to a government favouring their industry or their interest in some way or another. That needs to be done a little more in the education debates that we have in this country.

We have propositions put to us by industry groups, by groups interested in defence, by the Services and so on. We do not necessarily accept any of the propositions at face value. We examine them and look for what is legitimate in the arguments. We subject them to sceptical criticism when necessary. I suggest that we should simply do the same when we examine the propositions put to us by various interest groups in the education sector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make it abundantly clear that the Government has no intention of reintroducing fees for students undertaking their first degrees. I repeat that: The Government has no intention of re-introducing fees for students undertaking their first degrees. In fact the legislation before the House specifically excludes undergraduates. That point needs to be made, not for the benefit of members on this side of the House-they are aware that this is the case-but, unfortunately, some of the comments that certain members of the Opposition have made here today and outside this chamber would lead people to believe that the Government is intent upon reintroducing fees for undergraduates. I repeat that that is not the intention of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: What the Government has decided to do and what this legislation provides for is a limited reintroduction of fees for students undertaking their second or subsequent degrees or undertaking higher degrees. The Government's view is that, as those students have received their first degree at the cost of the taxpayer, it is fair and reasonable that they should make a contribution towards the cost of their subsequent education. The fees proposed represent a very small percentage of the actual cost. The fees to be charged are $1,000 per annum and the average cost of providing tuition in an Australian university or college of advanced education is about five times that figure. That needs to be borne in mind.

A great deal of emphasis has been placed on the fact that for 1982 the Government is appropriating $1.8 billion for tertiary education in Australia. The point is made by the Opposition that the fees that will be collected as a result of the introduction of this legislation will represent a very small proportion of that total figure. That of course is true. By implication, the Opposition is stating that the figure being appropriated is a very large figure indeed. On other occasions the Opposition, with a forked tongue, tries to make out and to convince the public that the Commonwealth has cut the funding of tertiary education in Australia. I repeat that the total amount being appropriated for 1982 is slightly in excess of what was appropriated for 1981. However, I concede that there has been some movement in funding within the tertiary sector and between parts of it: Some areas have benefited greatly by increases and others have suffered minor decreases. However, overall, the amount of money being appropriated by this legislation is slightly more in real terms than has been made available to universities, colleges of advanced education and technical and further education institutions during the current year.

I wish also to make reference to remarks that have been made by honourable members opposite concerning statements that I made towards the end of last year. I want to make it clear that I received correspondence from a large number of people and questions were put to me on various occasions. I said on all occasions that the Government had no proposals before it at that time in relation to the introduction of tertiary education fees. That was the position at the time I answered the correspondence and the various questions put to me. It is a matter of history and a matter of fact that, more recently, in the context of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, this matter did come up for re-examination. The Government made two decisions: First, that there would be no fees for undergraduates and, secondly, that fees would be charged to people undertaking their second or higher degree.
Question put:
That clause 6 be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak about the implications of amalgamation for some tertiary institutions in the State of Victoria. The Australian Labor Party has not opposed amalgamations in every case, and certainly strong cases can be made for merging some institutions. Some of the institutions that have amalgamated seem to be happy with the outcome. The association of the Caulfield Institute of Technology and the State College of Victoria at Frankston seems to be working out well enough. I draw the attention of the spellbound Committee to three proposed amalgamations in Victoria which I oppose-the Institute of Early Childhood Development in Kew, the State College of Victoria, Hawthorn, and the State College of Victoria, Melbourne. I do not want to detain the Committee unduly. There is an excellent explanation of the case of the Institute of Early Childhood Development in the Australian for 9 October 1981 in an article by Brian Hill entitled 'Axe over Pre-School Training'. I seek leave to incorporate this in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
In Asia there is a proverb: when the tiger and the buffalo fight, its the grass that gets trampled.

This sadly, seems to be the fate of Victoria's Institute of Early Childhood Development-an independent college founded more than 60 years ago and now in danger of closing because of the competing interests of other larger colleges and the Commonwealth Government.
The Melbourne-based institute does more than just train kindergarten teachers for Australia and overseas.

Its graduates are employed in hospitals, day nurseries, toy libraries, family day care centres, local government . . . in fact, in any situation which requiries a specialised knowledge of the individual development of pre-school toddlers.

Recently, however, the Federal Education Minister, Mr Fife, advised the Victorian branch of the Australian Pre-School Association that unless he received 'acceptable proposals' in the near future for the amalgamation of the institute with some other tertiary institution Commonwealth funding for the institute would cease from the beginning of 1982.

The Commonwealth, naturally enough, wants to prune government expenditure as far as possible and get what it considers the best value for money. And in the 1980s there is no shortage of carnivorous, competing tertiary colleges just itching to extend their range of courses and so attract more students, staff and federal funds.

But according to Mrs Agnes Farrance, honorary secretary of the Victorian branch of the Australian Pre-school Association, it is the institute and the quality of pre-school teacher training which will be trampled underfoot if any such 'amalgamation' takes place.
The State Education Minister, Mr Hunt, agrees. He has taken up the case with Mr Fife, and discussions on the institute's future are continuing.
'The institute's present strength lies in the fact that it is a specialist organisation,' Mr Hunt said recently.
'Because of this, it is the only advanced college in Australia which is able to offer post-graduate studies and qualifications in that field.
'Its student per capita cost is comparable with that of other institutions, and no savings in this regard could be anticipated from merger with another institution.'

The association, meanwhile, has made a formal submission to Mr Fife, urging the Commonwealth to 'retain and maintain the institute as an autonomous, independent institution for the professional preparation of personnel for the early childhood field and the continuing developing of their work in the community'.

It has argued that where colleges in Australia, Britain and the United States have been forced to amalgamate with large institutions, 'experience shows how rapidly the early childhood field disintegrates'.

The association says there is overwhelming evidence from all three countries that, following amalgamations, early childhood courses become watered down until they can no longer provide adequate preparation for the work with young children and their families.
The deterioration of courses is apparently related to staff redundancy problems, which the larger institutions here and overseas have attempted to solve at the expense of the early childhood section.

Following amalgamations, the association claims, the early childhood departments become such a small part of the bigger institutions that they do not have a strong enough voice in administration to maintain the quality of their staffing and courses.

Mrs Farrance said: 'The pattern everywhere has been for specialist early childhood staff to be lost and to replaced by redundant tenured staff from other areas with no background of either a practical or an applied nature in the area of early childhood.
DIFFICULT
'There is now a move in Britain and the US to re-establish or strengthen centres for early childhood studies, and it is proving to be a difficult and costly exercise to rebuild what has been lost.
'Specialists with an early childhood orientation, once dispersed, are not easily brought together again.'

Mrs Freda Briggs, dean of the De Lissa Institute of Early Childhood Studies at the Hartley College of Advanced Education, South Australa, says there are more than 500 early childhood students at Hartley but only one tenured member of staff with a child development background.

She said: 'The present contract staff in child development will go at the end of the year, and the child development course will be staffed from other areas where there is staff redundancy-e.g. geography.'
Mr Hunt describes as 'spurious and appalling' the reason offered by Commonwealth authorities for their demand that the Institute of Early Childhood Development be merged.
The reason, Mr Hunt says, is that Victoria is the only State where early childhood education continues to be offered in a single-purpose institution.
'The Victorian Government is co-operating with the Commonwealth in bringing about the merger of tertiary institutions where valid education, administrative or financial reasons are shown.
'It does not, however, accept the concept of amalgamation for the sake of amalgamation, or the view that bigger is necessarily better.'

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The article states that the IECD:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . does more than just train kindergarten teachers for Australia and overseas.

Its graduates are employed in hospitals, day nurseries, toy libraries, family day care centres, local government . . . in fact, in any institution which requires a specialised knowledge of the individual development of pre-school toddlers.

No other institution in the Victorian education system provides quite that kind of service. It is foolish to say to IECD: 'Well, you must undergo a forced amalgamation, willy nilly, with some other institution, irrespective of whether it covers your area or not'. I very rarely agree with the Victorian Minister for Education, the Honourable Alan Hunt, but he is correct when he describes as 'spurious and appalling' the reason offered by Commonwealth authorities for their demand that the IECD be merged. As he says, Victoria is the only State where early childhood education continues to be offered in a single-purpose institution.

The second case I want to refer to is that of SCV Hawthorn, which also has unique features. These were referred to last night by the honourable member for Casey, and I agree with every word he said. SCV Hawthorn reflects the fact that in Victoria, unlike the other States, there is a separate stream of technical education within the secondary system. Rightly or wrongly, Victoria retains that separation. The other thing that is important about SCV Hawthorn is that, unlike many of the students in SCV who go straight from school into another form of school and then go on to a third form of school for their professional lives, there has been a very heavy emphasis at SCV Hawthorn on training people who have come in from industry. A typical student at SCV Hawthorn is the person who has been a tradesman, who acquires a trade skill, then wants to go into teaching, and has to acquire certain teaching skills in a professional disciplined way at that institution. No other institution in Victoria has that kind of intake. It is difficult to say: 'You will be forced in with another institution, whether you like it or not'. I think it is quite unfair.

The third example I want to mention is that of SCV Melbourne. It is really a very old institution, physically located next to Melbourne University. It has a long and excellent tradition. It has been particularly strong in the humanities and in the visual arts. A lot of very distinguished people have taught there, including the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous). SCV Melbourne has been told that it simply must amalgamate with some other entity. The entities suggested are either the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology or Melbourne University, which is next door to the Footscray Institute of Technology. Contrary to the adage about not looking a gift horse in the mouth, the prospective hosts have expressed a certain lack of enthusiasm unless the Victorian Institute of Post-Secondary Education-known to all who love it as VIPSEC-agrees to keep up the numbers. Unless VIPSEC keeps up the numbers in these institutions economically it will impose some hardship on the host institution to take over SCV Melbourne. I am particularly concerned about SCV Melbourne because it is one of only two institutions which provide tertiary education places for my electorate. My electorate, and the whole of the west of Melbourne, are extraordinarily badly served so far as access to--

TALK.START.PARA: —But well represented.

—It is superbly represented, but not very well represented in tertiary institutions. If we look at all the western suburbs of Melbourne, there is a total population of 520,000, which is 26 per cent more than the total population of Tasmania. We have an atypically high proportion of young people there because the demographic pattern in the western suburbs differs from the rest of the metropolitan area. The total number of people engaged in tertiary education is only 3 per cent of the total enrolment in the metropolitan area. Over 20 per cent of the total population of young people is in Melbourne's west but they comprise only 3 per cent of the total enrolments. The difficulty is that once we say: 'That is all right, you can always get on a bus, you can always get a car, you can always go out to Preston, you can go out to some other eastern suburbs institution, or you can drive down to Frankston', it becomes unrealistic. It becomes one more practical disincentive to people from the west undertaking tertiary education. It underlines the difficulty faced by my electorate. Frankly, I would like to see the Melbourne Institute merged, if it has to merge, with the Footscray Institute. The Footscray Institute already takes the great bulk of people from my electorate who undertake tertiary education. There are significant numbers from the west in SCV Melbourne. If SCV Melbourne is forced to move and if the intake from the west is significantly reduced, this will cause great hardship in my electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to take up something that was raised earlier by the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Donald Cameron). He has a totally unrealistic view of what post-graduate work is all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Understandably.

—Yes, perhaps understandably. But he really seems to take the view that people undertaking post-graduate work are engaged in some wild frolic of their own; that they are merely doing it for vanity; or that they simply go on to do a Ph.D for kicks. He does not recognise that a very significant proportion of Australia's total input in research and development, not only in the areas of science and technology but in the humanities as well, comes from post-graduate students. We are concerned that in many areas the imposition of fees simply constitutes a quite significant economic disincentive to people going on with their post-graduate work. I have referred before to the case of engineers. I mention it again, I hope for the last time. It is not so much the fee itself but the alternative offers which are made to students. For example, an engineering student with a first class honours primary degree may have the alternative of going on and doing a second research degree and relying on the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme or of simply taking up a job offer from a firm. The firm would say: 'Do not be foolish. Why do your second degree now? We will offer you a job straight-out at $15,000 or $16,000 a year. Then you can get married and do your research degree later on'. That deferred opportunity may never be taken up. That is the real problem. In a highly commercial world we tend to evaluate what we do purely by looking at the money incentives offered. A company offers a young fellow $15,000 or $16,000 and he says: 'How will I survive on TEAS?' Somebody else says: 'Do not forget you will have to pay your university fees as well'. He may well say: 'I will give it up. It is just not worth persisting with. I will take the offer that is made by private industry'. That is the real difficulty. That is why I think the contribution of the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Donald Cameron)-whose contributions are generally well thought out and provocative, but also profound-was unfortunate. In this case he completely missed the bus.
