TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House has a general debate covering this Bill, the Non-government Schools (Loans Guarantee) Amendment Bill and the Schools Commission Report for the Triennium 1982-84, as they are associated measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the orders of the day at the conclusion of the debate.
-Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these three matters? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill and the Non-government Schools (Loans Guarantee) Amendment Bill. I indicate from the outset that the Opposition will not be opposing the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill as it is that legislation which provides for the implementation of the program of Commonwealth support for government and non-government schools throughout Australia. However, we will be moving an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill drawing attention to what the Opposition considers to be the serious shortcomings of the Government's policies as implemented by this legislation. The Opposition will be opposing clause 3 of the Non-government Schools (Loans Guarantee) Bill for reasons which I will outline later in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The policy of the Government in relation to the funding of schools is clearly in tatters. The Government had had to retreat from a number of areas, most obviously in relation to the School to Work Transition Program. The Government indicated in the guideline statement made by the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) in June of this year that it intended a certain amount of the recurrent funds available to the States for the purpose of supporting schools to be earmarked for the School to Work Transition Program. The Government intended that if the State governments were unable to demonstrate that they had made an increased contribution to the Commonwealth inspired School to Work Transition Program, the Commonwealth would use some of the earmarked money to support that program during 1982.

The Government earmarked also the capital funds available for expenditure on schools and similarly indicated that unless the State governments came to the party and met the Commonwealth's wishes in terms of their contributions to the School to Work Transition Program, again the Government would insist that part of the capital available under the Schools Commission's program would be directed towards the expansion of the transition program. This met with an enormous amount of opposition from State Ministers. They unanimously opposed this new departure in terms of the funding of schools. They not only opposed the mechanism that was being used and the interference that they thought it implied for the proper undertaking of their education programs but also objected to the program which the Government was seeking to force upon them. Many of the States, if not all of them, have their own transition programs, and they welcomed the Commonwealth's extra involvement in and contribution to this educational activity. But they objected to being put in the position of having to take money away from the normal running costs and the normal capital program of their schools simply to satisfy the whims of the Commonwealth in this regard. In the event, the Commonwealth caved in in relation to the earmarking of capital a few weeks ago after a meeting between the Commonwealth Minister for Education and the State Ministers for Education. Only a few days ago when introducing this legislation the Government announced that it also had caved in in respect of recurrent funding.

It is interesting to go back to a debate which we had in this House, a matter which was initiated by the Opposition. I drew attention to the folly of the Government proceeding in this particular way. We note the remarks of the minister at that time. Then, within days in relation to the capital proposition and within weeks in relation to the recurrent proposition, we saw the minister being forced to do a complete back-flip in relation to the transition program. He was forced to withdraw the earmarking propositon. He was forced to withdraw his threats to the States that unless they contributed to this program, he would in fact be expropriating money normally designed-certainly in the view of the Schools Commission- to support the ongoing activities and the ongoing capital expansion of schools simply to the Commonwealth School to Work Transition Program.

The important thing about this whole development is that the School to Work Transition Program has become the centrepiece of this Government's educational policy as it relates to schools. This was part of the obsession of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in relation to the problems which he saw in schools throughout Australia. He was preoccupied with the notion that schools, and schools alone apparently in his view, have been responsible for the appalling levels of youth unemployment in this country. He reckoned that the reason why so many kids, when they left school, spent such a long time on the dole unable to get work was that the schools had inadequately prepared them for work. He quite selectively and, in many cases, dishonestly drew on the earlier report of the Schools Commission relating to the schooling of 15 and 16-year-olds. Similarly he drew on the Williams Committee of Inquiry into Education and Training and that Committee's reference to the low level of school leavers' skills in reading and number work. But the Prime Minister completely omitted to take account of the other things the Schools Commission was saying in relation to 15 and 16-year-olds, and certainly failed to take account of some very important facts. As a result, however unacceptable the position is in relation to the skills of school leavers, the Prime Minister's prescription, as usual, was and still is totally counter-productive.

What the Prime Minister overlooked is that the innumeracy and illiteracy of school leavers is not a new phenomenon. It has been with us for as long as we have had school leavers. Of course it is unacceptable and of course something has to be done about it, but he also overlooked that the position has been greatly improving. The levels of literacy and numeracy of school leavers and, indeed, of kids still at school have been gradually improving over a long period. The most recent evidence of this comes from the report of the Australian Council for Educational Research, which the Government has quoted so fulsomely recently. That report sought to measure the improvement in reading and number skills of students of a particular age group over a number of years. Although we have to accept some of the methodological problems involved in that study and the fact that the results of that study have not been universally accepted, certainly that study reveals that there has been a very significant improvement in relation to these problems of illiteracy and innumeracy amongst kids at Australian secondary schools.

The Prime Minister, because of his continual abuse of the school system and because of his continual preoccupation with pointing to what he believes to be the failings of the schools, has managed to encourage more and more kids to leave school earlier and earlier. We have seen in recent years a reversal of the long term trend of children staying at school for longer and longer periods. The dropout rate is on the increase, and that is due very largely to the fact that the Prime Minister and others have been waging a war against schools, downgrading schools and questioning their capacity to perform effectively and to deliver the sort of education which children require today. Not only are kids leaving school earlier and earlier, younger and younger, but as well as that fewer and fewer of those who go on to complete their secondary education are going into the tertiary sector. This is a matter of great alarm, and it is a matter which the Prime Minister has a great deal to answer for because there is really no evidence to support the sorts of accusations and the sort of assault he has been waging on the education system of this country.

The Prime Minister, having viewed what he considered to be the particular inadequacies of the school system, landed upon this terribly ill-defined and ill-considered School to Work Transition Program. Nobody really knew what was involved in it. To the extent that the scheme has been successful-I have been happy to acknowledge that in some areas the scheme has been successful-it has been because of the imagination and the initiative of teachers at the local level being able to make something out of it. One could not make anything out of the statements of the Ministers who announced this scheme because it was really so vague and so imprecise that it really required an enormous amount of work and initiative at the school level to make it work in any way decently. However, the Prime Minister and the Minister for Education tried to dragoon the States into joining that scheme, but in the event the Government had no supporters in this regard. The Minister used to point time and again to the lavish praise heaped on the transition program by the State Ministers, but none of the State Ministers was prepared to put his money where his praise was-at least his praise as reported by the Commonwealth Minister for Education.

As I said, we have opposed the way in which the Government has tried to impose this scheme on the States. The State Ministers of all political parties have opposed it as well. Indeed, the minority report of the Schools Commission signed by two of the Schools Commissioners specifically drew attention to the transition program and its inadequacies, not only in itself but also in the way in which the imposition of the program on the States meant that standards in schools would decline as State governments had to withdraw funds from the normal activities of schools in order to put them into this particular transition education program. I think it is a great credit to those two School Commissioners that they had the foresight to stand up and to report to the Government on what they considered to be the inadequacies and the problems involved in this program. I am delighted to see that they have been proved correct by the subsequent action of the Government. I might say that it brings no credit to the other members of the Schools Commission who heaped enormous abuse on those two Schools Commissioners when they said they were going to produce a minority report. It points up the unnecessary timidity of the Commission these days particularly in relation to its volume 2 report.

The Commission knows what the defects are and what the problems besetting education in this country are. But the volume 2 report of the Schools Commission was simply a lame and uncritical response to the Government's guidelines. It is a pity that the Schools Commission could not have been even as adventurous as the Tertiary Education Commission, although I have had enough to say about the Tertiary Education Commission to indicate that I think it has collaborated far too enthusiastically with some of the worst aspects of the Government's tertiary education policy. The Schools Commission, to give it credit, has been very much more forceful on earlier occasions in drawing attention to the shortcomings of this sort of approach to the problems of school leavers. I will quote briefly from the March report of the Schools Commission for this triennium. It states:

Again, it is often claimed, particularly by employers, that young school leavers lack the personal qualities and basic skills which confer employability and that if only the schools would do their part in correcting these deficiencies the problem of youth unemployment would diminish. The Commission rejects this argument and maintains that while it is true that a number of young school leavers do lack confidence, initiative and motivation and do need to improve basic skills, there are many adequately prepared young people who want jobs and are unable to get them.
Referring to the Williams Committee, the report stated:
Williams . . . found that the least schooled and skilled among early school leavers experienced most unemployment.

The Schools Commission in its earlier report quite clearly rejected the proposition of the Government in this regard. It is a pity that the Government took so long to take notice of what the Schools Commission said. It took notice only when it was forced to do so because of the rejection and confrontation with which the Commonwealth Minister for Education was faced when he met his State counterparts some time ago.

What has to be remembered is that this campaign of abuse by the Prime Minister against schools and the teachers in them has created and continues to create very great damage in our education system. It has to be remembered that teachers are involved in activity which requires their wholehearted commitment. Most teachers have a very great commitment to what they are doing. They are not interested in it simply as a job. They are deeply concerned about what they are doing and the sort of education they are providing for the children who are in their care. All that is likely as a result of the Prime Minister's continual attacks is that they will become less committed and more uninterested. Teaching for them will become just a job. It is high time everybody in this community recognised the very great contribution that teachers are making and the very great dedication of the overwhelming majority of them and supported them in their difficult task, which is not made any easier by the failure of this Government adequately to support their activities, particularly in government schools.

That brings me to a particular problem which has been confronted by the Schools Commission over a number of years in its duties in making recommendations to the Government in relation to the funding of schools. Section 13 of the Schools Commission Act, which sets out the functions of the Commission, includes two paragraphs which make the job of the Commission extremely difficult. The Schools Commission is told that it should have regard to:

(a) the primary obligation, in relation to education, for governments to provide and maintain government school systems that are of the highest standard and are open, without fees or religious tests, to all children.
To make the job more difficult, the section states that the Commission should also have regard to:
(b) the prior right of parents to choose whether their children are educated at a government school or at a non-government school.

The net effect of this section of the Act as it stands is to direct the Commission to consider the needs of government and non-government schools equally and to recognise that, whilst governments have a primary obligation to government schools, the Commission must do nothing to jeopardise the position of non-government schools. In short, the primary obligation to government schools has to be balanced against the Commission's duty towards non-government schools. As I have said, the section directs the Commission to have regard to the primary obligation of governments to government schools in the exercise of its functions. There is no doubt that the Commission has followed this direction since its establishment. In its first report this was expressed most obviously in its endorsement of the Karmel targets and in its concern that States maintain real expenditure on schools and not use Commonwealth grants as a substitute for State effort.

In 1977 the Commission objected to the transfer of grants from the government to the non-government sector and urged the Commonwealth Government to reconsider the policy guidelines which led to this situation. The Commission's principal concern was that the subsidy scheme for non-government schools, coupled with a ceiling on total Commonwealth grants, would lead to continuing transfers of funds from government to non-government schools. The Commission addressed this question again in its report for the 1979-81 triennium when it referred to the 'undesirability of a future involving continued transfer of Commonwealth funds from government to non-government schools.' The Commission's answer was to recommend that the Commonwealth general recurrent grants to government schools should not fall below a fixed percentage of the standard running costs of government schools. In relation to non-government schools, the Commission pointed to the need to relate subsidies to a stable cost base rather than link them directly to government school running costs. It also considered that there was a need to set an agreed level of Commonwealth, State and private contributions to non-government schools. These measures, combined with a non-reducible Commonwealth contribution to government schools, would stabilise funding for both sectors and reduce the possibility of the transfer of funds from non-government to government schools. The government did not accept the Commission's recommendation.

In its report for 1980 the Commission again dealt with this matter. It pointed to the significant way in which the Commonwealth's role in school funding is changing. It showed a decline of 14 per cent in total allocations to the government schools in 1980 compared with 1976, a rise of 24 per cent in payments to non-government schools, and a fall of 12 per cent in programs shared by government and non-government schools. The Commission believed that these trends were a cause for concern. They arose from the need to accommodate rising payments to non-government schools, which was a consequence of rising State inputs into government schools to whose costs non-government school subsidies were linked, within total Commonwealth payments which had not been rising fast enough to cover the extra costs or which, in 1980, were declining. In consequence, the improvement of non-government schools shaped the allocation of funds, bringing a decline in Commonwealth funding to government schools and to special purpose programs, leaving the Commission no flexibility to respond to newly arising needs. The Commission repeated its recommendation for a minimum Commonwealth contribution to government schools, expressed either as a percentage of standard costs or in a set amount of dollars indexed for price changes per government school student.

The Commission revived these arguments in its most recent triennial report, with some modifications. It urged that government and non-government recurrent grants be linked to a standard cost per student. The standard cost is determined by assembling a number of baskets of services. These baskets are configurations of services which might be chosen to meet the needs of particular schools. Each component of a basket is costed and a total per student amount derived. The Commission did not advocate that schools adopt any particular basket. Rather, it provided a number of examples of baskets which all have the same average cost per student. This cost is what the Commission considered to be both a desirable and realistic level of school resource standards. The Commission considered that if growth patterns in real levels of State expenditure continued and if the Commonwealth maintained its real contribution to government schools, government school systems should attain the weighted average standard cost per student in the 1982-84 triennium.

The Commission has recommended that the Commonwealth contribute a fixed percentage of the standard costs of government schools. It has applied the 1978-79 proportion of Commonwealth expenditure on government schools in the States, that is, 6.7 per cent, to its basket of services standard costs. In effect, this means an increase of $7m, or 3 per cent, in general recurrent grants for government schools in 1981. Under this proposal the total amount of recurrent grants for government schools will vary with enrolments as the standard cost is expressed in dollars per student but the real level of Commonwealth expenditure per student will be maintained. For capital grants for government schools the Commission has recommended that the Commonwealth increase its grants by 10 per cent per annum for the 1982-84 triennium. It considers this necessary to overcome the large backlog of capital works needed in government schools. It considers the shortfall in capital works that occurred during the 1979-81 triennium to be unacceptably high.

It is clear from the Commission's past and present recommendations that it has maintained its commitment to government schools. It has increasingly sought to attain and maintain higher resource standards in government schools. It has urged the Commonwealth Government to reconsider policies which have resulted in a transfer of funds from government to non-government schools. It has attempted to prevent this from occurring in the future by proposing a fixed basis for Commonealth general recurrent grants for government schools. However, it is clear that the Government has repudiated its commitment to government schools by reducing Commonwealth grants for these schools while increasing those for non-government schools. The Government has refused also to accept the Commission's recommendations which have sought to stabilise the funding of government schools. The Government has always responded to this by saying that it is no longer necessary for it to increase continually the funding for government schools because on average government schools have achieved the targets set by the Karmel Committee. The Government conveniently overlooks that the Karmel Committee considered that its targets were the 'minimum acceptable degree of improvement' necessary to overcome 'in a reasonably short period the worst schooling deficiencies'. Therefore, the achievement of the Karmel targets by government systems does not indicate that there is no room for further improvement or that such improvement is not necessary.

What the Commission is really concerned about is the transfer of funds from the government to the non-government sector under circumstances where there is not an increasing overall education budget for schools. The Commission's past opposition to transfers and its recommendations for a non-reducible Commonwealth recurrent contribution to government schools is evidence of its support for this view. Equally, the Government's non-acceptance of such recommendations in the past indicates that it is unwilling to rule out further transfers in the future. Since 1976 there has been a substantial shift in Commonwealth funds from the government to the non-government sector. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a table which sets out this change.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows-
Change Program
% Government general recurrent - 4.1 Non-government general recurrent +53.7 Government capital -32.4 Non-government capital +13.1

TALK.START.PARA: —I make it perfectly clear that the Opposition has absolutely no objection to the increase in recurrent grants for non-government schools. In most cases this can be justified on the basis of needs. What we are concerned about is the way in which the increase in non-government school funding has taken place at the expense of the government school sector. One might make the point also that in relation to the increasing support for non-government schools the greatest increase in the subsidies has been in respect of those schools which are already best off, those schools which already have the best resources. The point we are trying to make is that the Government has a bias towards non-government schools and this is working very much against the interests of government schools.

SPEECH.PARA: When we are talking of non-government schools and when we are talking about Karmel targets it has to be recognised that many of the non-government schools have resources far and away in excess of those of government schools. That must be taken into account whenever the Government claims that its policies are justified by the fact that the government schools have, in its view, reached the Karmel targets. Most of the non-government schools, of course, have not reached those targets. This is very largely a deliberate decision taken by the non-government school systems. They have decided that it is more important for them to increase the number of schools-this goes particularly for the Catholic system; I do not cavil at it-than it is to increase the quality of their existing schools. That is a decision that they are entitled to make. But the Government should not use that as a justification for the transfer of funds.

The Government boasts that it has maintained the recurrent funds for government schools. It says that this is particularly admirable at a time when there has been a slight fall in enrolments in respect of government schools. What one has to recognise is that a slight fall in enrolments does not lead to a reduction in the costs of those schools. Just because one or two classes lose one or two students does not mean that we can withdraw teachers from schools. After all, that is the main way in which money is expended in schools. The other point which must be emphasised is that the Government has deliberately decided to reduce by $6m the capital funding available for government schools at a time when, in the Commission's words, there is a huge backlog of capital work required in those schools.

I very quickly refer to the Non-government Schools (Loan Guarantee) Amendment Bill and indicate again that we will oppose clause 3 of this Bill. This Bill intends to extend the provisions of the loan guarantee not only to existing schools-we have no objection to that-but to new schools. This is the new departure which we object to. What the proposal involves is that where groups of parents or groups in the community are too small to go themselves to a lending authority for funds or where they have no assets to provide the collateral for those loans the Government now will have the power to give those schools access to these guarantees so that they can get the loans that they need to establish schools. We have no objection to the fact that the Bill intends to extend the guarantee to interest payments as well as principal payments but we object, as I said, to the way in which this change will provide a direct encouragement to small groups of people in the community to set up schools without any planning, and without any necessity to refer to any adequate registration system. This is the main point. The Commonwealth has no control over the standards of those schools. The State governments, as has been indicated quite clearly, particularly by the Victorian Minister of Education-I understand that this is being discussed, perhaps even today, at the meeting of the Australian Education Council-face the problem of determining what is an appropriate standard for new non-government schools. I will have a little more to say when we get to the Committee stage of that Bill. I now formally move the second reading amendment to the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill which has been circulated in my name. I move:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
'whilst not denying the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that-

(1) the Commonwealth Government is ignoring its primary obligation to the government school sector as stated in section 13 of the Schools Commission Act, especially in its neglect of Schools Commission advice that the continuing shortfall in capital funds for government schools is unacceptably high;

(2) the advancement of one sector of Australia's schools should not be at the disadvantage of the other sector, whether public or private, as this will revive tensions within the community which disappeared with the introduction of the 'needs' policy by the Labor Government in 1973; and

(3) the excessive and unplanned proliferation of new private schools beyond the demand for new places at a time of contraction of the school age population is wasteful of resources and will destabilise existing schools creating 'public resentment' as expressed by the Victorian Minister for Education'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek to confine my remarks on this package of education Bills to the States Grant (Schools Assistance) Bill. The overall value of the Schools Commission's recommendations for 1982 is $1,008.1m, which in real terms is a 4.6 per cent increase over expenditure in the previous year. These recommendations were included in the Schools Commission report tabled in this House on 27 August 1981 and are in accord with the Government's guidelines. Attention has been drawn to the two members of the Schools Commission who issued a minority report disagreeing with some recommendations. They did this for two reasons: Firstly, they were concerned at the divisive effects of the expansion of non-government schools-I note the same concern and will broaden this issue later-and secondly, they felt that there would be a reduction in services provided to students in government schools. I disagree with the latter view, believing that it does not accurately reflect or understand the Commonwealth's funding role.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the major aspects of this legislation. General recurrent grants to non-government schools have been increased in accordance with movements in the government schools' standard costs and also to accord with the Government's election commitment to compress the present six subsidy levels to three funding groups. Group 1, replacing levels 1 to 3, will receive per capita rates of 20 per cent of government school standard costs; group 2, replacing levels 4 to 5, will receive 30 per cent; and group 3, replacing level 6, will receive 38 per cent. Group 3 schools will receive 40 per cent of government school standard costs in 1983. The Government has announced also several changes to the procedures for assessing non-government school subsidies. These include changes in the ranges of expenditure from private sources and the consideration of schools' disposable income. It was announced also that the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) will allow schools disadvantaged by these changes in expenditure ranges to remain at a higher subsidy level for up to two years until they adapt their resources to the new arrangements. The Government will review any cases in which this is not achieved within two years.

New non-systemic schools, formerly assisted during their initial years of establishment by being categorised to levels 6, 5, 4 and 3 in the first, second, third and fourth years of their existence respectively, will, under the new arrangements, receive additional subsidies at the rate of 10 per cent, 7.5 per cent, 5 per cent and 2.5 per cent of average government schools standard costs respectively in each of their first four years of operation. General recurrent grants for government schools have been retained at their existing real levels, despite the fact that government school enrolments in 1982 are expected to continue the downward trend which became evident after 1977. In continuing to maintain this program at previous levels, the Government has in effect slightly increased the real per student allocation in government schools. Expenditure per student on recurrent resources in government schools has long since exceeded the expenditure targets set by the Karmel Committee in 1973.

There are six points, I believe, to be made in relation to the current debate on the education appropriations. Firstly, a false impression of education funding arrangements is deliberately being created by the Opposition by omitting reference to the major responsibility of the State governments. Secondly, apart from direct grants for education, the Commonwealth, through untied revenue sharing grants, provides the States with a capacity to make additional funds available from their own resources for education. Thirdly, the Commonwealth Government's policy is aimed at supporting both government and non-government education sectors. In the case of government schools the Commonwealth tops up the contribution of the States which have the primary financial and constitutional responsibility. In the case of non-government schools, the Commonealth is the major source of government financial assistance as a supplement to private effort. Fourthly, when State contributions are taken into account, government schools with 78 per cent of enrolments receive 89 per cent of government education funding while non-government schools with 22 per cent of enrolments receive 11 per cent of government education funds.

My fifth point is that resource levels in most non-government schools are approximately 30 per cent below those of the average government schools. The sixth point I wish to make-I believe the situation has been grossly misrepresented in this debate-is that in recent years the New South Wales Government has chosen to transfer some $30.5m of funds provided by the Commonwealth for schools building purposes to other education uses. It is of primary importance to realise the limited role of the Commonwealth Government in school education in topping up the allocation of the States which have the primary and, indeed, the constitutional responsibility for school funding. As I mentioned before, in this connection State governments currently provide some 89 per cent of total public funds available to the government school sector. The Commonwealth Government's contribution represents the remaining 11 per cent of government school funding. On the latest available figures, State governments, on a national basis, provide some $3,611m for government schools with the Commonwealth providing the remaining $445m. Most of us are aware that State governments contribute up to 50 per cent, and in one or two cases more than 50 per cent, of their annual budgets towards education.

It is clear, therefore, that parents are being misled by education funding statistics which deliberately omit the largest contribution to government schools, that of the State governments. The allocation of total government school education funding between the government and non-government sectors does not favour the non-government sector as has been implied. Overall, an average of $1,790 is spent on each government school student each year by the Commonwealth and State governments and an average of $770 on each non-government school student. It must also be remembered in comparing funding of government and non-government schools, that the Commonwealth Government is the main source of government funding for the non-government school sector. Indeed, most non-government schools have recurrent resource levels about 30 per cent below those of the average government school. It is this gap which has been a prime factor in the decisions of successive Commonwealth governments to increase recurrent grants to non-government schools, but not at the expense of government schools.

I am concerned at the expansion of new non-government schools, particularly in some of our smaller towns and communities where divisions do result and available education funds are not effectively deployed. However, the Commonwealth Government is committed to a policy of freedom of choice and equality of opportunity in education for all Australian children. It seeks to pursue this objective by providing resources for both government and non-government schools. Instead of criticising the Federal Government for these policies, the Opposition and some of our wider school communities would be better advised to isolate the reasons why there is, in some cases, a significant desire by parents to place their children in independent schools.

The effect of Commonwealth funding in supplementing the major role of the States in the government school sector has been a demonstrable improvement in the resource standards in government schools in recent years. At this point it should be emphasised that the current extent of Commonwealth assistance at the school level is a relatively recent development, having been initiated only within the past decade. Studies by the Schools Commission indicate that all government school systems have generally reached ahead of schedule, and in many cases exceeded, the resource targets which were set in 1973. Some 80 per cent of non-government schools, on the other hand, are well below those resource targets and the level of Commonwealth Government assistance in this sector is designed to improve their lagging resource standards. The Commonwealth makes no secret of the fact that it is providing a significant contribution to assisting the non-government school sector. However, the amount of assistance to this sector in running costs is estimated as a percentage of the average cost of educating students in a government school. Therefore, as the cost to governments of educating government school students rises, so too does the amount paid to non-government schools which is limited on a percentage basis.

I think the opportunity should be taken to make a further point in relation to the grossly misleading statements made over a period of months concerning the effect of Commonwealth funding on State education capital building programs. As with recurrent funding, the Commonwealth Government makes a contribution to State capital programs which again remain substantially a State funding responsibility. To date the Commonwealth has permitted State governments to transfer between the two categories of grants-capital and recurrent-they receive from the Commonwealth. This has enabled States to vary the allocation of Commonwealth funds they receive to suit their particular needs. For several years the New South Wales Government has chosen to transfer substantial amounts of Commonwealth funds from allocations for capital works to recurrent purposes which includes general running expenses. Indeed, since 1977, the New South Wales Government has transferred some $30.5m of Commonwealth funds in this way. Yet the New South Wales Government has sought to criticise the Commonwealth for providing insufficient funds. This criticism is even less defensible when noting New South Wales Government Budget figures which indicate a decline in capital expenditure on government schools by the State Government from $143.6m in 1978-79 to $113.5m in 1980-81. I think this indicates the hypocrisy of the New South Wales Government in its criticism of the Commonwealth.

The Commonwealth is therefore a partner with the States in education funding. Apart from direct Commonwealth funding, to which reference has been made already, it must be remembered that the capacity of the States to provide additional funds from their own resources has been increased by the Commonwealth through revenue sharing grants to the States. Through this additional form of untied grant, State governments have the capacity to determine their own priorities of expenditure and further increase expenditure on education. In November 1979, the Commonwealth introduced the School to Work Transition Program for young people aged from 15 to 19 years who were regarded as being at risk in the transition from school to work. The Commonwealth undertook to provide a total of $150m in real terms for the program over 5 years from 1980 and asked the States to match this expenditure dollar for dollar for government schools and technical and further education colleges from 1982 onwards. This was designed to provide a total effort costing $250m over a five-year period. The program commenced in 1980 and the Commonwealth agreed to continue it in 1981 without a State contribution for that year.

The Government did indicate that because the States had not at that time indicated their readiness to make additional contributions to match the Commonwealth's expenditure in 1982 it felt compelled to take special action to increase significantly the resources devoted to transition activities. We therefore proposed to earmark up to $27m within the Commonwealth general recurrent grants to the States for government schools for expenditure on transition education. From that sum grants at the rate of $10 per pupil were to be provided to each government secondary school.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a bit blind.

—Just wait for a moment. We also proposed to earmark about $19m of government schools capital funds for equipment facilities for transition education. The honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) has questioned the Commonwealth's right to request this of the States. I thought it was the Commonwealth's responsibility and its role in education to attempt to meet particular needs in schools in our communities and to ensure that those deficiences and inequalities in the State systems were removed. It is therefore important and significant I believe, and it justifies the Commonwealth Government's action, that following consultations with the States since 4 June they have, in general, agreed to increase their recurrent expenditure on transition programs in schools over the base year 1979-80 by amounts which approximate and in some cases exceed the amounts proposed to be earmarked. Therefore the Commonwealth no longer needs to proceed with the recurrent earmarking since its principal objective has been met. The Commonwealth Government will expect the States to continue their increased effort in transition programs and will seek the provision of information on a continuing basis to monitor progress in this effort. The Commonwealth hopes that in appropriate circumstances the States will arrange for school communities to participate in the development of transition programs.

SPEECH.PARA: There are other major changes in this Bill which involve joint programs for both government and non-government schools. These include the widening of provisions relating to multicultural education to include projects involving instruction in Aboriginal language and culture which are to be eligible for funding. They also include revised provisions for programs of education for severly handicapped students to enable them to participate in educational activities outside the institution or private home in which they normally require constant care.

Other initiatives that I will speak briefly about are the important increase in funds for the Country Areas Program, the relaxation of the criteria by which eligible areas may be selected for funding and the discontinuance of the school level innovations element of the special projects program. As Chairman of the Victorian Country Areas Association I acknowledge the interest of the Minister for Education and the involvement of the Schools Commission in the Country Education Program. The country education project was set up by the Australian Schools Commission in 1977 to look at new ways of delivering educational experiences to isolated rural schools and communities. The major aims of the project are to develop a clearer definition of the nature of rural disadvantage and rural education; to involve local schools and communities in assessing their educational needs, determining priorities and developing and implementing programs based on these needs and priorities. The project was also developed to encourage the process of co-operation and sharing between all schools and communities in designated rural areas while looking for new ways of bringing educational experiences to isolated rural schools and communities.

This project has been highly successful in the five rural areas in which it has operated in Victoria. I am pleased that now eight additional areas have been declared and that the Federal Government has increased funds to the program by $1.5m for 1982. Because of proposals to restructure the administration of the Victorian education system, we are presently seeking to ensure that this program retains its original characteristics. Many of the programs have been developed through the co-operation of the State Education Department, the Catholic schools system and local governments. The benefits of working together, sharing resources between schools and communities and the use of local resources, outside the traditional school community, have been most rewarding. For example, the country education project in Victoria has produced special Higher School Certificate English television programs that have been beamed to rural high schools through the regional television networks. I particularly acknowledge the major encouragement given to us by BTV6 Ballarat. Initiatives have been developed for a Melbourne-based work experience program which provides country students with city work experience through linkages with city based relatives and/or a sponsorship for accommodation and work experience by Rotary clubs.

We have seen also the joint funding program, I believe a first in Australia, between rural community service officers with the co-operation of CEP, community education and the Department of Youth, Sport and Recreation as well as local government. The education of children in all schools, whether government or non-government, is a shared responsibility of both the Commonwealth and State governments. The continuing substantial overall level of support will enable further real improvements in schools' resource levels. The provisions in this Bill demonstrate the Commonwealth's continuing commitment to high standards in all Australian schools. I reject the Opposition's amendments out of hand and commend this Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Child Mrs J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In seconding the amendment moved by my colleague the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) I will base my remarks today on the Schools Commission report for the triennium 1982-84. In doing so I point out how deeply disappointed I am with the path that the Schools Commission has now taken. Before dealing with the report I will answer a couple of remarks made by the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Fisher). He spoke of independent schools. There is no such animal left any more. All schools are now in receipt of government funding, which makes them government or non-government schools. He also spoke about the transfer of funds in New South Wales from capital to recurrent. I point out to him that this was done with the blessing and the approval of the Federal Minister for Education (Mr Fife), not in some underhand manner as he perhaps pointed out.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Schools Commission was first introduced by a Labor government some years ago, the emphasis put on its operation was that it should be almost totally dependent on government guidelines and that it should survey the needs of education for the future. What we have now is a supposedly independent Schools Commission which gives advice back to the Government, advice that the Government has already told it it wants. It was never envisaged that the Australian Schools Commission would be a de facto campaign committee for the government of the day. But what is happening at the moment is that this Liberal Government goes to the polls, makes promises all over the place-particularly in key marginal seats to win a few more votes-and then advises the Schools Commission what it wants it to do. How can the Schools Commission possibly be independent if the Government tells it what it wants done rather than what the Schools Commission should be looking at?

I do not blame the Schools Commission for this quite so much as I blame the Government. This Government seems intent on taking away from all independent and advisory bodies any independence at all. The end result, of course, is that the public education system of Australia is running down, parents are pulling their children out as the facilities get poorer while the Federal Government decides to give more of the public money to the non-government schools just to try to win a few more votes in key electorates. But I do not think it will work anyway. The Government should be reminded that 78 per cent of all children in Australia go to local state schools and that 78 per cent of all children in Australia receive only 52 per cent of the Schools Commission's allocation of funds. Some 52.2 per cent of funds go to government schools while 47.8 per cent go to non-government schools. So 22 per cent of children in Australia get 47.8 per cent of the funds, while 78 per cent get 52.2 per cent. I call that an inequitable distribution of funds.

In addition, the Commonwealth Government is giving for recurrent expenditure much more for each pupil in non-government schools than for each pupil in government schools. The argument that it is all right because State governments give more to government schools than to non-government schools for recurrent expenditure only goes to show that perhaps the States have a better idea of their responsibilities in education than has the Federal Government. If the Federal Government is perfectly happy to see the non-government school system expand at the expense of the government schools, so be it. But the Government should not try to tell us that it is an independent schools commission that is giving it such advice; it is a schools commission that is receiving direction from the Government.

It was interesting to see that, for the first time, two of the commissioners of the Commonwealth Schools Commission have issued a minority report, in which they claim that the Federal Government is slowly whittling away the independence of the Commission. According to the authors of the minority report, the Government has been introducing more and more prescriptive guidelines which replace the broad and general guidelines introduced in 1975. In 1975 it was largely up to the Commission to decide how funds were distributed. I quote from the minority report:
Some recommendations on non-government funding arrangements have resulted from Government policies and election promises rather than from the Commission's own deliberations.
The minority report also states:

Guidelines to the Commission have become increasingly detailed and specific, over-riding its proposals on program policy and structure, and reducing its ability to exercise its own judgment on their implementation. This is a matter of concern for us.
I suggest it should be a matter of concern to all parents, staff and students within the government system of education throughout Australia. The minority report also states:
The recent review of Commonwealth Functions-
That is, the razor gang-

and the cumulative effects of annual guidelines have removed some discretionary powers from the Commission, endangering its ability to act as a statutory body, and suggest a view of the Commission as a department of Government.

Quite decidedly, the system of government education is starting to run down. I will cite some figures from notes given to me, referring specifically to the position in Victoria. If we look at the Schools Commission figures for 1977-78 to 1979-80, we find that Commonwealth government school expenditure fell by 16.1 per cent in that period while non-government school expenditure rose by 12.2 per cent. In 1973-72 per cent of Commonwealth school funds were allocated to the government sector. In 1980 it was 54.2 per cent. The Schools Commission, in its report for the triennium 1982-84, proposed a 3 per cent rise in Commonwealth government school recurrent expenditure and a massive 16.2 per cent rise for non-government schools. I believe it is time we halted the drift away from funding and accepting responsibility for government schools. In Victoria both the Schools Commission and the State Government admit that almost $400m is needed to meet basic building needs. We would do well to consider that if this drift away from financing government schools continues it will divide the community.

Most of us have lived through the bitterness of the pre-1972 State aid fight in regard to the allocation of money to non-government and government schools. None of us who were involved in that fight want to go through that again. Under a Labor government, the Schools Commission looked at the entire education system in Australia in an independent way, with the needs of education and the needs of the students being paramount. It distributed the available funds on the basis of need only. I believe this is fair; it is an honest way to distribute it, and it is the only way that unites the community. All of us would be quite happy to see money go to schools, within both the government and non-government system, on the basis of need.

I was delighted to see that the Federal Minister for Education, had taken the advice of the shadow Minister for Education, the honourable member for Fremantle, and had withdrawn his insistence that Commonwealth money be used for school to work transition programs. Under new education spending guidelines for 1982, the Government had decided to earmark up to $27m of recurrent grants for expenditure on the transition programs in secondary schools in the States. Predictably, the States reacted angrily and informed the Minister of their refusal to participate. I suggest to the Federal Minister for Education that he has been forced to back down on that one and he might now care to reconsider and to back down on the amalgamation proposal for the Institute of Early Childhood Development. It is certainly not too late for him to do so.

The thing that should be remembered about the government education system-the Government would do well to remember this-is that it is the system of education for which State and Federal governments have a responsibility to people thoughout Australia. An education system should be available to all Australians, wherever they live, and its quality should be first class. We could not say that is so now. Its quality should not vary from State to State or from suburb to suburb and its cost to the parent should not vary. Whilst I go along with the idea that there should be a choice or an alternative system, such as that provided within the non-government system, I also suggest to the Government and to the Schools Commission that there is a possibility for choice and diversity within the government school system. It should be possible for us to have experimental schools, alternative style schools and multicultural schools, as well as the traditional types of primary and secondary schools to which we are accustomed. Australia is a changing society and our education system needs to keep up with the changes, stresses and tensions that today's living brings. Australia's education system should be thought through with care and planned for the future-for the needs of the children of the future, for the citizens of the future-not for the needs or the political expediency of the Government that happens to be in Canberra when the report comes through.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill appears, on the face of it, to be a reasonable attempt by the Government to provide financial support for government and non-government schools at existing levels, and even to increase the number of educational programs. However, when this Bill is considered in conjunction with the recommendations of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, commonly known as the razor gang, it can be readily seen that it is a base confidence trick by the Government. The intention of the Government is clear: It is to ensure that both the funding and the delivery aspects of education services will be undertaken by the States. On the user pays principle, non-government schools will flourish and prosper at the expense of the government school system. But how will the three million Australians who are disadvantaged and in genuine need fare with an education system under which the user pays? The Government is trying to create two classes of people in Australia-the privileged users who can pay for the best in health, education, welfare, housing and transport, and the underprivileged who rely on government facilities to provide them with welfare, health and education services because the inequalities of our society deny them the ability to pay.

SPEECH.PARA: The Schools Commission was established in 1973 in order to advise the Commonwealth Government on acceptable standards and the needs of government and non-government schools. The Commission, in its report, gives an assessment of the needs of schools and the way in which these needs may be met. Guidelines are issued by the Government which indicate the financial limits and the framework by which the recommendations of the Commission, with regard to the allocations to programs and to the States, can be carried out. For the Commission to carry out its work properly, it is essential that it can adequately gather information from the schools and education systems all over Australia. Yet this is one of the first areas of the Commission's activities which have been cut by the razor gang. I quote from the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) relating to that report:
There will be a reduction in the Schools Commission's direct involvement in program administration and information collection.

How will it be possible for the Commission to make recommendations on the needs of education if it is unable to collect information and monitor education programs? It should be clear to honourable members that the Government does not want the Commission to undertake its proper function. In fact it wants the Commission to wither on the vine. The Government would like to return to the days when standards of education varied from State to State, back to the time when the poorer States could not provide an adequate system of education. The whole aim in establishing the Schools Commission was to ensure that education facilities throughout Australia were of a high standard and quality.

My reference to equality makes this an appropriate time for me to refer to another of the razor gang cuts; that is, the abolition of the Curriculum Development Centre unless the States are prepared to provide financial support. Coupled with this threatened closure is the termination of support for education research in general and the Education Research and Development Committee in particular. What a short-sighted action this is for a government which claims that it aims to improve the quality of life for all Australians. In fact these cuts means that eventually it will not be possible to produce the excellent education booklets which have been published over the years. Bearing in mind what I have already said, it came as no surprise to me to find, when the Schools Commission report for the triennium 1982-84 was tabled, that two of the 11 members of the Commission had found it necessary to issue a minority report. I take this opportunity to commend Mrs Joan Brown and Mr Allan Marriage on their integrity in taking a courageous stand against the retrograde education philosophy on education of this Government.

The report of the Schools Commission makes it clear that the majority of the commissioners who signed that report have failed to exercise their powers and fulfil the responsibilities given to them under the Schools Commission Act. The minority statement points out that it is the responsibility of the Commission to advise the Government of any detrimental effect its policies are having on public education. This the commissioners have failed to do. It must also be pointed out that the practice of the Government in issuing guidelines to the Schools Commission which are incompatible with its functions and responsibilities as set out in the Act represents a criminal interference with the independence of the Commission. An abject failure of the majority report is the lack of any reference to the resurgence of the bitter State aid debates of past years, as a result of the bias of the current funding policy which favours non-government schools. Reference has been made to this fact in the minority report, which points to the indication in the 1982 guidelines of a further reduction in the Commonwealth's commitment to government schools following the 13.3 per cent reduction for the five-year period preceding 1979. These reductions are being made at a time when the recurrent grants to non-government schools are increasing, with an 11 per cent increase planned for 1982. The inequity of the Government's education funding policies is causing the resurgence of the bitter State aid debates. With 77.7 per cent of children attending government schools and only 22.3 per cent attending non-government schools, the allocation of the funds represents a deliberate transfer of funds from public to private education. The practical realities of the education policies of the Federal Government are indicated in the minority report. It states:

It is already evident that the quality of service provided to students in government schools in Australia is beginning to deteriorate. Pressures to increase class sizes are increasing, and support services for schools are being reduced. Disruptions to schools are occurring as teachers, usually with the support of their local communities, are resisting by whatever means are available to them, staff shortages, forced reorganisations, and the loss of specialist personnel.

I can vouch for the fact that the deterioration in the education facilities for government schools referred to in the statement is occurring in my electorate. As an example, many small primary schools are unable to offer adequate classes in art, physical education, music and library because specialised staff are not available. Cutbacks have been made in the numbers of emergency teachers, and this has meant that many school camps and excursions have been cancelled, with even a cancellation of classes in some cases. Many of the schools in my electorate are operating classes in portable and other sub-standard classrooms. It is conceded that many school buildings are comparatively new, but the lack of cyclical maintenance funds means that the essential repairs are not being carried out, to the general detriment of the life of the buildings.

During term one of this year an intensive survey was conducted into the educational, staffing and curriculum needs of more than 130 secondary, technical and primary schools in the Knox region of my electorate. Some of the schools surveyed expressed satisfaction with their staffing entitlements and the programs they were able to offer, but the vast majority expressed dissatisfaction at large class sizes, forced cutbacks in education programs, and staff shortages, particularly in the areas of mathematics, English and physical education.

A brief summary of the results shows that, in relation to class sizes, 22 per cent of primary schools have one or more grades containing more than 35 students and more than 40 per cent of all primary school classes in Knox exceed 30 students. With regard to special needs, the summary indicates that more than 500 students requiring additional tuition in mathematics and more than 900 students requiring additional tuition in English are not receiving the additional tuition they require.

Finally, the survey summary indicated that in relation to discontinued and cutback programs almost half of the 130 schools surveyed reported forced cutbacks in education programs, particularly in the areas of English, mathematics, library and physical education, which I have mentioned previously. It should be borne in mind when considering these results that 30 students is the maximum class size recommended by the Schools Commission and that English and mathematics are considered by the community to be priority areas of education.

In conclusion, I express my strong support for the views contained in the Commonwealth Schools Commission minority statement and call on the Government to withdraw this Bill and reconsider its decisions in relation to the level of funding for the capital and recurrent programs of government schools. I support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to conclude the debate by reiterating that the Government has accepted all of the recommendations of the Commonwealth Schools Commission for the detailed allocation of funds for schools in 1982, which have been set at $1,008.1m and represent an increase of 4.6 per cent in real terms over expenditure in 1981. As well as this quite substantial increase, the Government has taken some decisions on the reallocation of resources, which are implemented in the Bill. These will enable the Government's educational election commitments to be met and will give greater priority to such areas as migrant and multicultural education, country areas education, and educational programs for handicapped children.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the remarks made by the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) concerning the Government's decision to earmark certain funds for transition education, let me remind the House that in my guidelines statement I said that the Government proposed to earmark funds for this purpose within the general recurrent and capital programs. On 22 September 1981 I announced that we did not propose to proceed with the capital earmarking or insist on the allocation of a cash component to each government secondary school. In the light of advice now received from most State governments that they have increased, or propose to increase, their own recurrent spending on transition programs in schools and technical and further education colleges, over the base year 1979-80, by amounts which approximate, and in some cases exceed, the amounts proposed to be earmarked, the Government no longer needs to proceed with the proposed earmarking of general recurrent funds. The Government has not backed down, as suggested by the honourable member for Fremantle. Its principal policy objective has been met. The Commonwealth expects the States to maintain their increased transition effort and hopes that the States will arrange for school communities to participate in the development of transition projects. The Government rejects the amendment moved by the Opposition in the House this afternoon.

Commonwealth policy on schools funding has, as its central objective, the provision of educational services of the highest standard for all Australians, whether they be in government or non-government schools. In addressing this objective, it is necessary therefore to take into account the total resources available to schools from both Commonwealth and State sources. In this context, persistent and grossly misleading claims have been made by Opposition members since my guidelines statement in June of this year, the most recent occasion being this afternoon, in relation to the Commonwealth's role in school education funding. I take this opportunity to state the true position clearly and concisely. Non-government schools are not being financed at the expense of government schools. State governments have the constitutional and primary responsibility for government schools. The House should note that, in addition to direct Commonwealth expenditure on government schools, the Commonwealth provides untied revenue-sharing grants to the States, to spend according to their own priorities. These revenue-sharing grants, along with funds from other Commonwealth and State sources, represent about 89 per cent of total public funds for government schools. Direct Commonwealth funding of government schools merely supplements the States' efforts.

State Governments direct less than 5 per cent of their total schools' budgets to non-government schools. Commonwealth funding, in redressing this imbalance to some extent, must therefore provide relatively greater assistance to non-government schools. This simple fact of basic justice seems to have been overlooked, perhaps deliberately, by the Opposition. At present, non-government schools, with 22 per cent of all enrolments, receive only 11 per cent of total public funds for all schools. Despite the continuing decline in enrolments, the Government has continued to maintain in real terms the level of general recurrent grants for government schools in 1982, resulting in a small increase in their per student allocation to those schools.

The Commonwealth Schools Commission has reported that, on average, government school systems have exceeded the expenditure targets set by the Karmel Committee in 1973, reflecting the substantial and continuing contributions of Commonwealth and State governments to those schools. Evidence of these contributions can be seen in the substantial improvements in student-teacher ratios in recent years; although staffing standards in the great majority of non-government schools are also improving, they are still well below the levels that have been achieved by government schools. Indeed, the average resource levels of government schools have reached the stage where they would be classified under the Commonwealth's subsidy system for non-government schools as being in group 1; schools with the highest resource standards. Despite this, on the latest available figures, each student at a government school effectively receives from taxpayers, that is, from all government sources, more than twice the amount-about $1,790-received by a student at a non-government school, who receives about $770.

General recurrent grants to non-government schools in 1982 have been increased in accordance with movements in standard costs at government schools and with the Government's election commitment to compress the present six subsidy levels for non-government schools to three. The Commission has reported that the great majority of non-government schools have resources, on average, some 30 per cent below those of government schools. The Commonwealth's concern for these low-resource schools has led to continued improvements in their subsidies from about 30 per cent of average government school standard costs in 1977 to 38 per cent in 1982, with a further increase to 40 per cent in 1983. This represents an increase in real terms from about $364 and $580 per primary and secondary student in the most needy non-government schools in 1977 to $562 and $913 in 1982 in constant 1982 out-turn prices. It should also be noted that almost 90 per cent of Commonwealth funds for non-government schools is directed to those schools in groups 2 and 3 which are in receipt of supplementary support above the basic grant because of their greater needs.

Commonwealth assistance to non-government schools recognises the right of the parents of all Australian school schildren to a basic level of financial support from public sources for their children's education, as well as the right to additional support for children in those non-government schools which have a relatively greater need because of lower resources. The Commonwealth is concerned to ensure that freedom of choice and equality of opportunity continue to apply to all Australian school children. In addition, the Commonwealth provides assistance to groups with special needs in both government and non-government schools.

The honourable member for Fremantle expressed his support for the basket of services concept as recommended by the Commonwealth Schools Commission to replace the percentage link arrangements used to determine the level of financial support for non-government schools. The Government rejected this recommendation because it is the Government's policy to retain the percentage link mechanism and because non-government schools are opposed to the proposal because they believe it could lead to a reduction in Government funds for these schools.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to announce today to honourable members the Australian Government's decision on the question of Australia's participation in the proposed Sinai peacekeeping force. In doing so, I want to set that proposal against the background of the history of the Middle East over the last 30 years, for it is only against that background that the importance of the proposal can be judged and the decision relating to it understood.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the last three decades the Middle East has been the most unstable region in the world. This instability has had many causes, but what has given it special character has been the conflict between Israel and the Arab states. This has generated more bitterness, more hatred, more suspicion than any other conflict in the world during this period. Four times in one generation it led to war: In 1948 immediately after the creation of Israel; in 1956 during the Suez crisis; in 1967; and again in 1973. These wars not only disrupted the region itself, but threatened the peace of the world.

As well as war, the conflict caused a terrible refugee problem, fed fanaticism and terror, and distorted and warped the lives of the countries involved. By the mid-1970s, for example, Israel found it necessary to spend 36 per cent of its gross national product on defence, with crippling results for its economy. All efforts to end the conflict, and there were very many, failed in the face of accumulated suspicion and hostility. The differences appeared irreconcilable. Then, in November 1977, the nearest thing to a political miracle in our time occurred. In an extraordinary act of political courage and vision, President Anwar Sadat of Egypt flew to Jerusalem and addressed the Knesset, the Israeli Parliament. This single dramatic act created a new situation overnight. It set in train a process of negotiation between Egypt and Israel, with the United States of America closely involved. Within a year, this had culminated in the Camp David Accords of September 1978, and, in another few months, it resulted in the Egypt-Israeli peace treaty of March 1979.

These events were generally welcomed as an historic breakthrough. It was not a matter of believing that all problems were solved, for clearly there was a long hard road ahead and the principal actors would need not only great determination and skill, but all the support they could get from the international community, if they were to complete the journey. But the problems no longer appeared utterly intractable and a willingness to contemplate compromise replaced complete dependence on solution by the gun.

The Camp David Accords and the peace treaty contained two essential elements. One dealt with the procedures for implementing 'full autonomy' for the inhabitants of the West Bank and Gaza after the establishment of an elected self-governing authority. The other dealt with the bilateral aspects of the peace treaty and, specifically, with the return to Egypt of the territory occupied by Israel in the Sinai Peninsula during the earlier fighting.

Several things need to be noted about these two parts. First, they are not separate and discrete but interconnected, two parts of a total and very carefully negotiated package. In particular, progress on the future of the occupied territories of the West Bank and Gaza depends on maintaining confidence at the bilateral level between Israel and Egypt, and this in turn depends on the completion of the return of the occupied territories of the Sinai to Egypt. Secondly, the future attitude of the other Arab states to the Accords is likely to depend very substantially on the successful carrying out of the Accords as they relate to the Sinai. If the current reservations and suspicion of the Arab states are to diminish, it is essential that they be carried out. Thirdly, both elements of the peace process require substantial political and strategic concessions by Israel. These were agreed to by Israel in return for an agreement on a satisfactory set of arrangements to guarantee its security. It is here that the peacekeeping force assumes prominence.

On the basis of the confidence established at Camp David, Israel has already withdrawn from approximately two-thirds of the Sinai and, given the history of the relationship between the two countries, that it has done so has been remarkable. It is scheduled to have withdrawn completely from the Peninsula by the end of April 1982. But, as the text of the treaty makes clear, that complete withdrawal is conditional on the existence of a peacekeeping force which will supervise both the Israeli withdrawal from the Sinai and the implementation of the security arrangements agreed on in the treaty. The existence of an effective peacekeeping force in the Sinai, one which would by its presence secure Israel's southern flank, is therefore a necessary condition for total withdrawal. It would also help to create the kind of confidence required for progress to be made with respect to the West Bank and Gaza. The existence of such a force would not guarantee success-nothing can do that-but without it there can be little hope. The peace force that was envisaged in the treaty was a United Nations force. Unfortunately, it has not been possible to bring that into being. The Soviet Union, which has consistently opposed the Camp David Accords and which vetoed the extension of the mandate of the United Nations emergency force, stands as an insurmountable obstacle to its creation. The Soviet Union has consistently adopted an obstructionist approach to the search for a Middle East peace, has sought to encourage and take advantage of instability and to position itself to make strategic gains.

The question has been, therefore, whether faced with the Soviet veto there should be no force at all, with the disastrous consequences that would entail in the whole peace process, or whether there should be an international peacekeeping force outside the United Nations system. In considering that question it should be noted that the likelihood of a Soviet veto was anticipated at the time of the signing of the treaty. In letters to both President Sadat and Prime Minister Begin, President Carter undertook that:

If the Security Council fails to establish and maintain the arrangements called for in the treaty, the President will be prepared to take those steps necessary to ensure the establishment and maintenance of an acceptable alternative multinational force.

That letter and the assurance it gave were an integral component of the agreement reached by Egypt and Israel in 1979. The Australian Government believes that while it would have been preferable for the Sinai peacekeeping force to be established under a United Nations mandate-if that is ruled out by the position taken by the Soviet Union-then in terms of what is at stake, in terms of peace in this highly sensitive region, it is infinitely preferable that there should be an international peacekeeping force created outside United Nations auspices than that the whole peace process should be frustrated by the absence of any force at all.
