Let me add that we should be careful, in a situation where it is possible to take significant initiatives for peace, before we circumscribe them by establishing circumstances in which the Soviet Union would gain a permanent capacity to interpose a veto, for that might give to the Soviet Union a greater power than it could manage on its own account to thwart and frustrate progress towards peace.

Granted that the need for a peacekeeping force to support the continuation of the Israeli-Egyptian peace treaty is accepted, the question remains as to whether Australia itself should participate in such a force. No one would pretend that this is an easy question to answer and this Government has deliberated long and hard over it. I make no apology at all for the time we have taken in coming to a decision. There are considerations which weigh for and against participation, and these were set out in the statement to this House by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) on 26 May.

A number of major arguments point in the direction of participation. Participation by Australia would encourage the formation of a more broadly-based peacekeeping force which would enhance prospects for international acceptance of the peacekeeping force-a force which is needed to ensure that Israel's withdrawal from the Sinai can be carried out in accordance with international commitments. Australia has given strong support to the development of the peace process in the Middle East and has a responsibility to follow up with practical assistance. President Sadat took great political risks in initiating and perservering with the peace process and it is vital for his successors who have committed themselves to support that peace process that the remaining third of the Sinai still under Israeli control be regained by Egypt in April 1982. The failure of Australia and other Western countries to participate would require the United States to bear the burden itself and would be seen as a failure by the West to support United States policies in the Middle East. This would risk giving propaganda opportunities to the Soviet Union, whereas participation in peacekeeping would encourage constructive United States involvement in efforts to bring about a lasting settlement of Arab-Israeli differences. Our participation would be welcomed by Egypt and Israel, as well as the United States, and our participation would imply our continuing support for Israel's security. It would have positive impact on Israel's approach to negotiating similar arrangements for its other borders.

When I met President Sadat in London a month or two ago he sought to impress upon me in a very plain, very open and honest way the strength of Egypt's desire and wish to have Australian participation, but he did not try to suggest that there were no risks, that there were no problems. The nature and the honesty of his appeal impressed me very much as to the man, as to the person.

A number of arguments have also been used against Australian participation. It is sometimes said that our policy has been to participate only in United Nations sponsored peacekeeping operations, and that a force which was not broadly based would find little international acceptance. Some have said that the Middle East is remote from Australia and that the reactions of other states in the region might be adverse. Some have said that the extent of any Australian commitment would be uncertain and potentially too extensive, especially in view of our commitment to participate in peacekeeping in Namibia. Some have said that participation in a peacekeeping force in such a volatile area is too risky, and that it might even result in an adverse impact on support in Australia for our relationship with the United States. While there are weighty considerations on both sides a number of factors have led the Government to the view that Australia must be prepared to contribute to the multinational peacekeeping force. The starting point is that Australia has a clear and strong national interest in the progress of peace in the Middle East. It is first and foremost a matter of deciding what it is in our own national interest to do, and then acting accordingly.

Without question, the continued progress towards peace in the Middle East is of enormous significance to Australia. An outbreak of conflict would have repercussions not only for the region but also for the peace of the world which would affect us profoundly and in manifold ways. It would affect our allies and friends in ways which could not but impinge greatly on our international relationships and with risks for the strategic balance of great moment to our national security. Australia's interest is in seeing what is probably the single most serious threat to world peace removed. Further warfare in the Middle East could trigger off a much wider war. Australia has a legitimate interest in preventing this. This point is so evidently true that I believe it does not require elaboration here. There is also the economic fact that Egypt is Australia's largest single trading partner in the Middle East. As the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) said in the House yesterday, a stable Egypt is very important to the whole of our trade with the Middle East region. It is in the interests of Australia and the whole world that Egypt's stability be maintained, and this maintenance requires continued international support for the policies commenced by President Sadat, and which his successor President Mubarek is pledged to continue. That we have an interest in peace, rather than war, in the Middle East is, I believe, indisputable.

This leads to the second fact which has weighed in our decision-that the peace process which has been begun in the region under the Camp David Accords is the only framework for peace which has been put forward in the long history of that region which shows some prospect of achieving its immediate objectives. While other proposals have been made from time to time, none has yet achieved the degree of acceptance from Israel and Egypt the Camp David Accords have achieved. Senator Church made this point eloquently in Canberra yesterday when he said:

There has been much said for and against the Camp David Accords, but remember that those Accords, though they are still only partially implemented-and far from perfect-represent the only formula that has yet achieved a peace in this part of the world . . .

A central part of the Camp David process is the establishment of a peacekeeping force in the Sinai. The Government is aware that many Arab governments have stated public opposition to the Camp David Accords. The Government believes, however, that there is support for the concept of returning Arab land to Arab sovereignty; in this case returning Sinai to its rightful owner, the Government of Egypt.

The Government attaches great importance to its relations with Arab countries, and understands their wish to achieve a settlement which makes proper provision for the interests of the Palestinian people. Australia hopes that its relations with Arab countries will continue to develop. There is a growing realisation tha many countries including a major part of the Arab world are seeking the same objective-peace. Given that peace in the Middle East is in Australia's national interest, and given that the only existent basis for peace is Israeli-Egyptian accommodation, and the establishment of a multinational peacekeeping force, Australia cannot avoid the question: Do we have a capacity to make a contribution to the peace process by membership in that force? One fact is plain: There is a limit to what Australia as a middle power can do. We must avoid unrealistic views of what we can achieve. But to say that there are limits is in no way to say that we could not make a useful and a valuable contribution, in conjunction with other countries which share our interests and our concern for peace in the region.

Egypt, Israel and the United States-the nations which signed the agreement in August this year providing for the establishment of a multinational peacekeeping force-have made it clear that they would welcome Australian participation in the force. Indeed, they have indicated that they attach great importance to our participation and that the assassination of President Sadat has made that participation even more important to them. President Sadat's successor, President Mubarak, has indicated his determination to remain on the course set by his predecessor. President Sadat's assassination has in fact created a greater need for international recognition of the conditions for peace in the Middle East.

Egypt without President Sadat needs more support from other nations to continue the peace process than Egypt with President Sadat, and the Egyptian Government made clear to the Deputy Prime Minister on his recent visit that this was very much its own perspective. This consideration has weighed with the Government and has been significant in tipping the balance in favour of participation in the peacekeeping force. We have a capacity to contribute, and our contribution is sought by the countries most closely involved. These facts place the most weighty responsibility on us. This Government has never taken the view that Australia should refrain from doing what it can to create a better and more peaceful world. Within realistic limits we have consistently argued that Australia has responsiblities, and must recognise those responsiblities in its actions.

Australia has had recent involvement in peacekeeping in the Middle East; Australian forces were part of the United Nations peacekeeping forces in the Sinai from 1976 to 1979 and were withdrawn only when the Soviet Union indicated that it would veto an extension of the force's United Nations mandate. In this case it would obviously be more comfortable to do nothing-to say that peace in the Middle East does not concern us, or that we cannot contribute to peace. But neither of those propositions would be true. Those attitudes widely adopted amongst nations in past times and in other conflicts have led in the end to catastrophic wars. If all nations wanting peace were to leave the active pursuit of peace to others, peace would fail by default, as it has too often in the past, and we would all bear the tragic costs, as we have too often in the past. Australia is concerned. We can contribute. And accordingly, we have decided, provided certain reasonable conditions are met, to make a contribution to the multinational force.

On 12 October I wrote to President Reagan informing him that the Australian Government would agree to participate in the peacekeeping force if certain conditions were met. I informed President Reagan that the Government has decided that Australia will agree to participate in the Sinai peacekeeping force subject to Britain and Canada also agreeing to participate. In the interests of obtaining the broadest-based international acceptance of the force, significant European participation is a critical factor. We are glad to see from published reports that France is reconsidering her attitude. The Australian contribution would be limited to the contribution we are initially called upon to make, and that contribution will be of limited duration to be agreed.

Apart from the membership of the peacekeeping force there are other matters which the Government believes are important to provide full protection for Australia's independence and sovereignty, and which were set out in my letter to President Reagan. As is usual practice, we would need to instruct the commander of any Australian contingent that if he received orders from the commander of the force which he believed were contrary to, or went beyond, the agreed purposes of the force, he should not comply with them until he had consulted with Australian authorities. No part of the peacekeeping force-including the United States component-should have any association with the United States Rapid Deployment Force. A solution to the Palestinian issue is clearly central to the future stability and peace of the Middle East. In participating in the Sinai peacekeeping force we would be concerned that our contribution would have the maximum positive influence in continuing and broadening the peace process in the Middle East. Australia has consistently supported the continuing peace process but we have been disappointed by the lack of progress and prospects for further movement in the autonomy negotiations.

I stated in my letter to President Reagan that Australia will be looking to the United States to exert and sustain the strongest pressure to ensure effective progress in implementing the Camp David Accords as they relate not only to the Sinai but also to Palestinian autonomy. We recognise how much the United States has been doing in an endeavour to establish lasting peace in the Middle East. We recognise also what President Sadat and Prime Minister Begin were trying to do in their search for a peaceful solution. It is important for the Middle East and for the whole world that these efforts should be continued and should have the widest possible support.

Our participation in the peacekeeping force would be on the understanding that all the parties to the Accords abided by word and deed with their provisions, and press forward with a continuing peace process in the Middle East. The conditions necessary for Australia's participation have all been conveyed in the clearest terms to President Reagan. The Australian contribution under consideration at present comprises elements of an air transport unit, equipped with helicopters and fixed wing aircraft, and probably involving some 200-300 personnel. But the precise composition of our contribution will of course depend on the outcome of discussions with other participants and also on the decisions of those other governments. I want to set out step by step the timing of the decision and the discussions and consultations which led up to it, because it is important that there should be no misunderstandings about this. During the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting I would obviously have wanted to, and did, consult with leaders, and at the time President Reagan put the same suggestion to me and to certain other countries. I consulted with the Prime Ministers of Canada, New Zealand and the United Kingdom in Melbourne during the Conference. And then following the assassination of President Sadat, the Deputy Prime Minister consulted with Secretary of State Haig, Dr MacGuigan, Lord Carrington and Mr Colombo, who were in Cairo for President Sadat's funeral. These consultations in Cairo took place on 10 October, and I was informed of their content by cable and in telephone conversations with the Deputy Prime Minister.

The decision that Australia would participate under the conditions I have already outlined was taken on 12 October. I want to make it plain that that decision was taken after consultation with, and with the agreement of, the Deputy Prime Minister who, as honourable members know, was overseas at the time. The Government's decision about participation in the peacekeeping force and the conditions for that participation were conveyed by letter to the President of the United States and the Prime Ministers of Great Britain and Canada on 12 October, and the Prime Minister of New Zealand was subsequently advised of our position. It will be obvious to the House that whilst Australia's decision was taken on a completely independent basis, the practical commitment which will flow from it will depend upon the decision of other governments. This is why I said in the House on Tuesday that 'there is no procrastination on this issue by this Government' and also that 'I expect to be in a position to make some announcement about this decision in the relatively near future, but that is not necessarily waiting on decisions of this Government, but decisions of other governments'.

It was appropriate, in view of the conditional nature of Australia's decision, that the other governments should have some time to formulate their own positions in relation to that, but it is the view of the Government that events have now moved ahead and that Australia's position should be made known.

The Australian Government believes that this multinational peacekeeping force is a significant step for peace. It is not a decision which is pro-Arab or pro-Israeli. It is a decision which is pro-peace. It is a decision which could never have been made had President Sadat not taken his historic initiatives. The assassination of President Sadat has stengthened, not weakened, the need for international support for the peace process. A role of the utmost importance now falls on Prime Minister Begin. Many have questioned his approach to peace and the implications of his policies.

Australia has made abundantly clear on many occasions its support for the state of Israel behind secure and recognised borders as specified in United Nations Security Council Resolutions 242 and 338. Our credentials on that matter are not exceeded by any nation. So let me from that point of support and friendship say that much will now depend on Prime Minister Begin and on the Israeli Parliament. There are many who believe that it was President Sadat who was foremost in carrying the banner for peace in the Middle East. Notwithstanding that Prime Minister Begin has fully participated in the progress to that point, with President Sadat's death there now falls to the Prime Minister of Israel the opportunity to hold aloft the banner for peace that President Sadat carried with such courage. Prime Minister Begin now has the opportunity to make sure that the autonomy talks are meaningful, and to do all that he can to bring about positive results. Let him make sure that there is a true and fitting memorial to President Sadat in a peace settlement that can endure and that leads to a wider settlement in the Middle East. There is a challenge before Prime Minister Begin, Israel, Egypt and other countries such as the United States to act with vigour and initiative so that those who celebrated President Sadat's death by firing their guns for joy are confounded, and the terrorists and promoters of discord are defeated. Let those who have used terror as an instrument recognise, with the vision of a Sadat, that the true road to peace lies in a recognition of Israel's right to exist; then discussion and negotiation can replace the sound of gunfire.

In making this commitment I wish to emphasise that Australia will contribute to a peacekeeping force, not to a conflict. The Sinai peacekeeping force will not be taking sides with either Egypt or Israel. It is not going to be involved in either military attack or defence in any military sense. Its role is to monitor, to observe. I consider it most understandable that when two countries, with a long and sorry history of mutual conflict, decide to put this history behind them and engage in a new era of peace, they should wish to have mutual friends in whom they can have confidence to assist them in the sensitive business of overcoming past suspicions. The Sinai peacekeeping force is to play the role of mutual friend. If the time should come when either party should wish to attack the Sinai force, then the whole peace process would have come to an end. By definition, the force's role would already also have come to an end and it would leave the region. But this situation will not come about, and it will not come about because Australia and other countries are ready to play their part, which is after all a modest part, in ensuring that Israel and Egypt pursue their mutually declared objective of developing a new and friendly relationship.

I realise that the moment there are differences of view on this important issue. I hope that honourable members and the Australian public will give very careful consideration to all the considerations I have mentioned and will agree that in the end the right course for Australia is the one the Government has decided to take. Australia has played a significant role over many years by its willingness to contribute to peacekeeping forces in trouble spots around the world, and while this particular decision has been more finely balanced than others, I have no doubt that in the end the easier decision would be irresponsible and wrong. The easier decision would be one we might well live to regret, for surely none of us would want the situation in which a failure on our part to help two countries in their search for a lasting peace might contribute to increasing instability in a region where it is the interest of Australia as of the whole world that there should be increasing stability.

I appeal to members of the Opposition not to seek to divide Australia on this issue. I appeal to them not to be swayed by talk of war when the proposition and possible prospect is one of peace for one of the most war torn parts of the whole world. The conditions wrapped around this particular decision are such that all parties in this Parliament and all people in Australia can accept the decision as one that in no way derogates from Australia's sovereignty, as one that recognises our responsibilities to do what we can to help achieve the objective of peace that is so close to the hearts of Australians, as one that is in Australia's widest national interest. I present the following paper:
Sinai Peacekeeping Force-Ministerial Statement, 22 October 1981.
Motion (by Mr Sinclair) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Sinclair)-by leave-agreed to:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition speaking for a period not exceeding 32 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is an extraordinary one. It commits conditionally Australian military personnel and equipment to serve overseas in the most volatile region on the globe, a region which is frequently rift with sudden, unpredictable and horrendous conflict. The most extraordinary aspect of the statement is that the final decision about Australia's commitment of personnel and equipment rests in the hands of others-Britain and Canada-not Australia. It seems to me a rather unique and curious way for foreign policy decision making to proceed. All parts of the Parliament and the country are concerned to see peace achieved in the Middle East; but equally, concerned and informed people are worried that that objective will not be achieved by discredited processes or by approaches which are partial and which are capable of interpretation as serving sectional outlooks. I will come back to those matters. I declare, very early, the attitude of the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party on this matter. There should be no ambiguity about its declared position. On 27 May 1981, on a motion by the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi), seconded by the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke), and carried unanimously, the following resolution was endorsed:

SPEECH.PARA: That it opposes Australian participation in any multinational peace-keeping force in the Sinai not under U.N. auspices.

I will come back to some of these matters a little later. It was quite obvious that the Prime Minister approached this issue, in the concluding comments he delivered, with a great display of hide. He appealed to the Opposition not to divide the nation on the issue. If any single decision, if any lone declaration, will divide the nation on this issue it is the statement of the Prime Minister in the Parliament tonight. The opinion polls in this country are clear. There is no equivocation about the Australian community's attitude. Those opposed to such a commitment have increased from 61 per cent in August to 72 per cent in September. Those who support this sort of proposal constitute only 25 per cent of the Australian community. I make it clear-as I will quite abundantly when I quote from a document-that there are members even in this Parliament on the Government side who have declared pursuasively their opposition to such a proposal as the Prime Minister has just announced.

Having said that, I commend the firmness of the Prime Minister in the statements he has made in relation to the rights of the Palestinian people. I hope that he will persist with those declarations undeviatingly because there will be no resolution of the Middle Eastern situation until the Palestinian problem is resolved. That in turn requires a recognition of the sovereign rights of the nation of Israel according to United Nations declarations 242 and 338. We in no way underestimate the enormous difficulties of arriving at a solution to these problems. I repeat what the Prime Minister said at page 18 of the document circulated to us. He stated:

In participating in the Sinai peacekeeping force we would be concerned that our contribution would have the maximum positive influence in continuing and broadening the peace process in the Middle East.

The fact is that the United States Government, in spite of the enormous clout that presumably it would have with the Begin Government of Israel-I make a distinction between the Begin Government and the Israeli people-in spite of the presumption of enormous influence, has been singularly unsuccessful in achieving a more tract- able approach by the Begin Administration to all aspects of the Camp David processes. At page 19 the Prime Minister says:

. . . Australia will be looking to the United States to exert and sustain the strongest pressure to ensure effective progress in implementing the Camp David Accords as they relate not only to the Sinai but also to Palestinian autonomy.

I have to confess my confidence about what will be achieved in that latter respect sags badly. Already the United States has displayed successively on particular occasions and successively through various administrations that it lacks, in the final result, the power to force the Begin Administration to take a more realistic and creative approach to the need for a peaceful settlement of the multitude of problems in the Middle East which directly impinge upon Israel, Egypt and the Palestinian people.

When the Camp David Accords were first announced the Opposition supported them. On the occasion when they were presented to the Parliament the proposition was that there would be a United Nations sponsored peacekeeping force. Six months later a letter from President Carter was attached to those Accords in which there was a declaration that in the event of a United Nations peacekeeping force not being capable of being established then a US sponsored multinational military force would be set up. That was never presented to this Parliament. We supported the Camp David processes with some optimism on the basis of the declaration in relation to a United Nations sponsored peacekeeping force. If there is to be any respectability, credibility and influence on the part of any peacekeeping force then its perception in the eyes of the world must be that of a force which has international sponsorship, not one which is seen as an extension of United States foreign policy-no matter how well motivated it might be argued that that extension of US foreign policy is. This is particularly true in relation to this volatile, this potentially explosive part of the world-the Middle East.

Let me outline some of the very real difficulties which are not novel. There are difficulties which have plagued the whole process of the Camp David Accords since their inception-the attitude of the Begin Government towards the West Bank and Gaza. Since the Camp David Accords were signed and in spite of the clear intention of those Accords to arrive at a withdrawal of the military presence of Israel from those particular areas and processes aimed at establishing autonomy-however that may be defined in the upshot of debate-for the Palestinian people of the West Bank, the Begin Government has completely abused the implicit principles and commitments in that undertaking. The Begin Government has proceeded to establish further settlements on those areas. One would have expected, by implication, that there was a declared immunity for those particular regions against the establishment of further settlements once the Camp David processes had been signed. I quote the Washington Post of 28 September 1980, which states:

Since the accords were signed nearly two years ago, the physical landscape of the West Bank has changed with the addition of 39 new Jewish civilian communities, bringing the total number of settlements operating there, under construction or approved by the government, to 72. They now have a population of about 14,000.
It concludes by quoting the Agricultural Minister of the Begin Government, Ariel Sharon, who said:

You just can't do anything about it any more. That is why it is impossible any more to talk about the Jordanian option or territorial compromise. We are going to leave an entirely different map of the country that it will be impossible to ignore. I don't see any way any government will be able to dismantle the settlements of Judea and Samaria.

The Begin Government has undertaken a program which is clearly designed to acquire territorially the West Bank and Gaza. It is an extension of an ideological, theological view that Mr Begin and his colleagues have of the State of Israel. I do not want it misunderstood what I am saying. It is not a view which is shared by all Israeli people. It is not a view, for instance, which is endorsed by the Israeli Labor Party. One of the great virtues of Israel is that, like an island in a great sea, it alone is the functioning democracy in that part of the world. There is a more stimulated and a better informed debate taking place there on this matter than occurs within this country. It is the cause of deep sorrow in Israel that the Begin Government proceeds in the way in which it does. The Israeli people in conflict with the objectives of the Begin Government recognise how the behaviour of that government is contributing dangerously to the instability of the area and how much more difficult it will make acheivement of peace through whatever process for that particular region. I quote the Christian Science Monitor of 7 September this year, which states:
Israeli military officials state that only about 2 per cent of West Bank land has been taken for settlements. However, Messrs. Benvenisti--
A former Deputy Mayor of Jerusalum-
and Rubinstein--
a long-time Israeli West Bank correspondent for Davar-the Word-a pro-Labor Party daily newspaper-

say that Israel asserts rights to about 1.5 million dunams (one dunam equals one-quarter of an acre), 27 percent of the total West Bank area of 5.5 million dunams-for potential settlement, military, or other use. This does not include the area of the former Jordanian sector of Jerusalem and surrounding land, whch was formally annexed by Israel in 1967.

Let my go on to give further evidence of the extraordinarily difficult task which is before us and evidence of why the Camp David processes are in reverse, why they are discreditied internationally. In the Knesset on 5 August 1981 the Begin Government, among other things, carried this declaration:
At the end of the transition period, set down in the Camp David agreements, Israel will present its claim, and act to realize its right of sovereignty over Judea, Samaria and the Gaza district.

How can it be proposed that Australia, by participating in the United States sponsored multinational military force in the Middle East, will be influential in changing this firmly declared attitude of the Begin Government? The Begin Government is the greatest threat that the world has to international peace. The explanation is simple. Mr Begin, in desperation to win the last election, undertook a number of military escapades which cannot be excused. He has now formed a coalition which operates on a knife edge. In those circumstances there is in Israel a sense of great alarm at the potential for Mr Begin to undertake further destabilising military types of adventures. This is the nature of the problem we are talking about and over which the Prime Minister has so glibly skidded. The settlement on the West Bank in the Gaza was developed after the Camp David processes were signed by the Israeli Government.

There are some facts about the situation in the Middle East which have to be acknowledged. Israel, as much as Egypt, needs peace and, therefore, needs to withdraw from the Sinai. The economies of neither can survive if there is continued tension and military conflict. Let us look at the case of Israel. I think the situation of Egypt is much more apparent. Already the Israeli economy is confronted by a rate of inflation of 130 per cent; it is accelerating. It has to divert a very large proportion of its total resources to military expenditure. That is inflationary; that tends to undermine the strength of the productive side of the economy. In those circumstances, Israel is confronted by a situation which I saw when I visited there last year--

TALK.START.PARA: —When you saw Arafat.

—When I saw Arafat through the assistance of the Australian Government which maintains official contact with him at a very high level in Beirut. Let us have no humbug about that. Israel is unable to provide housing or the general standard of facilities that the public of that country expects. Therein lies the genesis of increasing tensions within that country.

SPEECH.PARA: Israel desperately requires on economic grounds peace with Egypt and, indeed, with other countries in the Middle East. It requires it on military grounds. If it is able to withdraw from the Sinai it is able to withdraw its military forces from deployment on its western flank. It is, therefore, with a secure peace arrangement, able to establish a more effective defensive-I hope not offensive-deployment of its military forces on its other borders. In that sense it makes good strategic sense and good tactical sense for Israel to withdraw from the Sinai. I put the proposition that in view of the fact that the arguments in favour of withdrawal from the Sinai on the part of both Egypt and Israel are such that it is curious that it should require any sort of outside military force to supervise this sort of thing. Neither side can afford the continuation of this situation. Economically and militarily it will destroy them.

I said before, in view of the fact the members of the Government reacted with some agitation to some of my comments, that I will quote from a Government member's document to show that within the Government ranks there is substantial agreement with the views I have been putting and the concluded attitude of the Labor Party as declared by me and as established at a Caucus meeting earlier this year on this matter. Let me tell the honourable members opposite what their colleague the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) had to say about the Middle East. The document is headed 'Sinai-In or Out'. On page 6 he asks the question:

With its southern flanks fully secured by the force (particularly by virtue of the US presence in the force), Israel would be more likely to engage in serious negotiations, and to make serious concessions for the purposes of solving the West Bank, Gaza, Old City of Jerusalem and the Golan Heights issues.
The answer to that from Mr Spender is this:

Nothing in recent history supports this view. If anything, it seems likely that the more secure Israel feels to the south, the more free it would feel to take military action against e.g. the PLO and Syria.
That is what the Liberal Party says. On page 7 the document states:
Even if Australia quit-
That is, from a commitment to this force--
on good and previously agreed grounds, if the US remained, it would be unlikely to look kindly on Australia's withdrawal.
In conclusion, and in the considered view of Mr Spender and his colleagues, the document states:

By becoming part of the Force, we place ourselves hostages to fortune, in that we can be affected by events that we can neither predict nor control and we subject ourselves to risks that cannot be calculated.

We agree with that. We agree that by commiting ourselves to this force in the circumstances outlined by the Prime Minister we do commit ourselves to become hostages of fortune, that the future destiny of this country can be determined by events over which we have neither control nor about which we can make any prediction. That is the view of a government member who has carefully considered this matter and it is a view that has been endorsed by a great number of his colleagues. At page 12 of the Prime Minister's statement there is a surprising, if not disturbing, declaration, or confession if honourable members prefer. He said:
Further warfare in the Middle East could trigger off a much wider war.

It is an extraordinarily unstable part of the world. If Egypt and Israel are genuine about their wish to have this withdrawal completed there is no need for a supervisory force. It is in their interest to do so. What is likely to happen-the Prime Minister's declaration which I have just quoted makes this clear-is that in the event of further hostilities, a fact that I want to come to in a minute in terms of the potential for grave instability in Egypt, Australia, as part of a very small peacekeeping force, could be overrun and we could be in serious trouble. What does any honourable member of this House or any seriously-minded member of this community believe to be the likely situation in the event of hostilities between two major conflicting forces and between which there are only 2,000 lightly armed members of an observer group? They would be overrun. The consequences would be cataclysmic. The Prime Minister, unaware of the contradiction of what he said, stated at page 25 of his statement:
If the time should come when either party should wish to attack the Sinai force, the whole process would have come to an end.
I doubt that anyone will argue with that, nor indeed be generous to suggest that it is a major insight. The Prime Minister continued:
By definition the force's role would also already have come to an end and it would leave the region.
Again, it is probably the height of his capacity for perspicacity. He then said:
But this situation will not come about . . .

If he says it will not come about why explore the prospect? His confidence is not a confidence shared by more than 70 per cent of the Australian community; it is not a confidence shared by any editorial writer who has written on this matter; it is not a confidence that is being shared outside by informed commentators on international affairs who are concerned about the part of the world we are discussing. I find it extraordinary that the Prime Minister has to declare that Australia's commitment is conditional upon the commitment of other countries in the world. He has declared principle in the course of the ouline of what he had to say. He has made a claim by implication of statesmanship. But we find in the final result that there is sort of a dallying and an uncertainty and an inconsistency. In 26 pages of dissertation from the Prime Minister on this matter we find two to three key paragraphs and they are that Australia's commitment is conditional upon Canada and Great Britain, two members of the old white Commonwealth, making a prior and unequivocal commitment to serving in this United States sponsored multination military force.

Let us look at what the Prime Minister says. He says that this process of commitment of Australian troops is the only way to peace. He says that there is no other alternative. He says that it is a matter of great principle. He says that our presence in the force will ensure that it becomes a more broadly representative force. He says that it will allow us to apply influence on Israel so that there will be other border settlements. I put to one side the fact that far larger, more powerful and demonstrably more influential countries have failed in all of this and ask: Why, if he believes all of these things, does he then declare conditionally that for all of the principle, for all of the influence and for all of the good we can contribute to peace, we will not go ahead with it unless Canada and Britain are behind to hold our hands? He said that Australia will make a positive impact on Israel's propensity to negotiate similar arrangements. I repeat it because it is a key proposition he puts forward to justify this undertaking. He ignores completely contemporary developments in that part of the world, the developments on the West Bank, in Gaza and the behaviour of the Begin Government in Israel in Jerusalem. He ignores the fact that in spite of the massive aid that the United States of America pours into Israel every year-some $2,000m, about $3500 per year for each inhabitant of Israel-the United States has not been able to achieve that leverage.

I put this proposition very simply: The two processes should in no way be separated. It is necessary to establish leverage with the Begin Government in relation to the Camp David processes connected with the West Bank and Gaza. It is nonsense for the Prime Minister to put forward these propositions to commit Australia to this multinational United States sponsored military force without first ensuring that maximum pressure is applied to the Begin Government and that there is a demonstrable, positive reaction to that pressure by the United States in relation to the Palestinian peoples in the West Bank and Gaza. He is seeking to give a gloss to a partial response to the Camp David processes and in the process he is ignoring the fundamental rights of the Palestinian people. Ignoring them in that manner will contribute greatly to further instability in that region. I note that at page 10 of his statement he uses terms such as some people having talked of our remoteness from the region and about our commitment in Namibia in some way weakening our capacity to participate in this force. He goes on to talk about some people saying that the area is volatile and too risky. I will tell honourable members the first person to go on record with that declaration-the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street), the honourable member for Corangamite. I have a copy of his cablegram stamped 'secret'. Government documents stamped 'secret' are much more easily obtainable than the ones that are just stamped 'confidential'. The cablegram, dated 27 April this year, is addressed to the United States Secretary of State Haig. The Minister stated:

We are also committed to the UNTAG for Namibia when the force is raised. We have an interest in seeing peace and stability in the Middle East, but it is beyond the area of direct strategic concern to Australia . . .
That is the unequivocal declaration of the Government, not the Opposition. He goes on to say:
In your message--
That is Haig's-

you made reference to Australia's important trading links with Middle East countries. The Government will of course need to give very careful consideration to the effect on our relations with regional Arab governments of possible participation in the force.

It is well known that nothing has altered since that cablegram was sent to diminish in any way the reservations of the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The only thing that has changed-not the circumstances, which are what I was talking about-is that the determination and dominance, the single-minded obsessiveness, of the Prime Minister, of which we heard so much earlier this year from the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), has won out. He has bluffed and bullied a concession from his colleagues. I repeat, the provisional commitment he talks about is an extraordinarily vulnerable one. It involves 200 to 300 personnel with fixed wing aircraft and helicopters, which are highly vulnerable to guerrilla incursions in an area which is highly unstable.

I mentioned earlier that I would come to the point of potential instability between Egypt and other Arab countries. It is clear that Egypt is becoming the venue for important military establishments of the United States for the accommodation and support of its Rapid Deployment Force. In that sense there is a major injection of instability within Egypt-that is, domestically-and from outside as a consequence of the developing attitudes of Arab countries. Egypt has enormous potential for instability. There is the problem of quite evident pan-Arabism there, which is quite contrary to the spirit of this proposal. There is resentment within important sections of the military to the way in which policy under Sadat developed, and is continuing. There is opposition among the intelligentsia and resentfulness amongst the middle class. There is very hostile opposition among the Islamic fundamentalist movement which is still influential and significant. Overlying, underlying and impregnating in every conceivable way these sorts of potential forces for destructiveness are very serious economic problems-a rapid rate of inflation which is overwhelming any economic growth; a very low level of income per capita; and a serious maldistribution of wealth of the country.

We are opposed to the commitment of Australian troops overseas in any multinational military force unless it has United Nations sponsorship. We are opposed to the commitment of Australian troops in that region of the world because we agree with the assessment of the Minister for Foreign Affairs; that is, it is well removed from our area of strategic interest. In that respect I draw the comparison between the obvious strategic interest of all the major countries of Europe, which should be placed well ahead of us. The tardy way in which those countries have responded to this proposal is an indication of how defective they view it as being. The fact that such enormous pressure had to be applied to so many countries with so little result for the United States is an indication of the serious reservations which world leaders harbour in relation to this proposal. Australia's best interest will not be served by being committed to this sort of force. It will be highly vulnerable in a very unstable part of the world. Developments could transpire there which could quickly suck us in to a rather horrendous development of military conflict with the gravest implications for international stability.

I repeat, there can be no settlement of the problems in the Middle East until there is a settlement of the so-called Palestinian problem. In that respect I note that the European Economic Community, specifically Great Britain among many countries of the world, has declared that it is necessary that any processes designed to bring about a peaceful settlement in that part of the world must have associated with the representatives of the PLO. When I went to the Middle East last year, at Beirut in Lebanon I was able to meet Mr Yasser Arafat. I was able to meet him because the Australian Government-the Fraser Government-arranged it.

TALK.START.PARA: —At your request.

—At my request. I was able to make that request sensibly only because I knew the Fraser Government had long-standing, high level, official relations with the PLO in Lebanon at Beirut. I was taken to meet Mr Yasser Arafat by the most senior representative of the Australian Embassy in Beirut.
—At your request.

—I certainly would not do anything at the honourable member's request. The representative had long-standing personal contact with these people. I conclude by making this declaration: We believe that peace is an imperative for the Middle East and to achieve that it must be recognised that both Israel and the Palestinians are entitled to independent states and national homes of their own. There can be no lasting peace until the Arab states and the Palestinian Liberation Organisation respect and recognise Israel's sovereignty and right to exist. Equally, there can be no long-lasting peace until Israeli forces have been withdrawn from occupied territories to secure and recognised boundaries and a just settlement of the claims of the Palestinian people is achieved. That will not be achieved by the processes the Prime Minister has announced tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia will participate in the Sinai peacekeeping force, subject to the conditions--
—You've changed your mind, have you?
—Order! The honourable member for Reid will resume his seat. This should not be an example of Brown's cows coming into the chamber. The honourable member will resume his seat and behave himself.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, the reason I took that stand was that, whilst we listened to the Prime Minister in silence, when the Leader of the Opposition spoke the Government forces in support of the Liberal-National Country parties were like a bunch of jackals and I had to protest to the Speaker at their behaviour. Frankly, if they continue that behaviour we on this side of the chamber will reciprocate.
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member for Reid will resume his seat.

—I said that Australia will participate in the Sinai peacekeeping force, subject to the conditions described by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), for a number of very substantial reasons. Clearly, the most important reason of all is that the whole world, including Australia, has a very great stake in the peace of the Middle East. As is well known, the Middle East is one of the most volatile parts of the world. It is probably the most strategic part of the world because it supplies most of the oil traded around the world. It has a long and sorry history of instability and conflict. The world has welcomed the Camp David Accords, which hold out the best hope for peace in the Middle East. If Australia believes peace in the Middle East is important, it cannot turn its back on its responsibility to do whatever it can to secure that peace. It is not good enough for Australia to pay lip service to the ideal of peace in the Middle East but be unwilling to contribute to that peace process.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, very substantial practical considerations are involved. A conflict that would disrupt the flow of oil to the world from the Middle East would have enormous consequences. Such a disruption would be a catalyst for great instability for all kinds of people around the world and could very well lead to a massive conflict amongst nations trying to get their energy supplies. From Australia's point of view, instability in the Middle East could seriously disrupt the very substantial trade wich Australia has with countries in that region. These are important matters and they cannot be put aside. But I emphasise again that the overwhelming consideration in the mind of the Government in making the decision announced today is its responsibility to do what it can to contribute to the peace of the Middle East. The key country is Egypt, a large country which has the largest population in the whole of the Middle East and a country which has enormous intellectual influence amongst all the countries of the Middle East. Egypt is the only major country of stability in a troubled Middle East today. If we had an unstable Egypt it could well turn the tables and bring about enormous conflict in that part of the world which I have described.

Some people say that the assassination of President Sadat added to the arguments against Australia's paticipation in the Sinai peacekeeping force. I believe that the reverse is true. The tragic death of President Sadat, who did so much to secure peace, should inspire many countries to make a firm commitment to peace in the Middle East and to do so by making a practical expression of commitment to the peacekeeping force. People must realise the tremendous courage that President Sadat displayed in 1977 by going direct to Israel to talk about a peace agreement. Until that point in time there has been only a disengagement arrangement between Israel, Syria and Egypt. His going straight to Israel caused tremendous resentment amongst strong-willed Arabs who so detested the Israelis that they were unforgiving about his being prepared to make such a move. It is sad that that created a strong feeling, a reservation, by many of the Arab countries, many of which are quite moderate and considerate and want peace and a solution that brings peace.

All honourable members will know that I attended the funeral of President Sadat in Cairo. As well as giving me the opportunity to pay Australia's tribute to a great man, my presence in Cairo allowed me to meet senior people in the Government of Egypt and senior representatives of a number of countries around the world. As I said in the House yesterday, I believe it is of utmost importance that the new Egyptian leadership continue firmly along the path laid down by the late President Sadat. In Cairo I was assured in the firmest terms that that would happen. Egypt is a key country in this matter, not only because of its commitment to peace but also because any serious instability in Egypt, or any Middle East instability or conflict in which Egypt became involved, could only cause serious problems for all the countries of the Middle East and all the countries that have associations with the Middle East. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) seems to have failed completely to understand these things. He fails completely to understand the change that President Sadat's death has brought.

It is now more vital than ever that we do all we can to strengthen the solidarity of Egypt in the course on which that country was set by President Sadat. It is now more important and urgent than ever that all nations consider how serious it would be to the peace of the area if Egypt were to become destablished. One of the points on which the Leader of the Opposition relies in condemning the Government's decision in his assertion that a substantial majority of the Australian people is opposed to participation in the peacekeeping force. It is not at all surprising that many Australians feel that way. It is quite a normal reaction. It is like asking people whether they want their taxes increased. No doubt none of us want to be involved in these affairs but, if the issue is important enough, if the Government sees its responsibility and understands the circumstances much better than the average Australian, it has a responsibility to its people to give leadership. The Government does not make its decisions on the basis of public opinion polls; it makes its decisions on the basis of what it believes is right for Australia and for the peace of mankind.

The Leader of the Opposition complained that the Government's decision was conditional upon participation by Britain and Canada. He said that if the Government believed so strongly that Australia should be involved, its decision should be unconditional. But, as the Prime Minister said, the point is that the peacekeeping force can be fully effective only if it is broadly based, with participation from a number of significant countries. The terms and conditions of the peace Accords is that there be a multination force. What Australia wants is to be part of a force with standing, a force with credibility, a force of like-minded nations. That is why we want to see Canada and the United Kingdom-

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't even believe it yourself.
—Order! The honourable member for Port Adelaide will get an opportunity to put forward his own views in a minute.

—I am quite capable of speaking my own mind. I have heard enough from this person to support communist attitudes. I know how much it is in the interests of some people to see a destabilised Middle East in the interests of--
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I do not need the fascist Deputy Prime Minister of this country to speak for me. He knows that what he is saying now is all lies.
—Order! The honourable member for Port Adelaide will resume his seat.

—There is no equivocation on where I stand as far as my friends and allies are concerned. There is great equivocation with some members of the Opposition on where their interests seem to lie. Since the death of President Sadat there has been a reassessment by many of the major European countries of the reservations they may have had before to meet the interests of some of the Arab countries who were personally resentful of President Sadat. They are reassessing the matter because they now realise how serious the situation is and how important it is to keep this peace process going. It would be quite unrealistic to have, as the Labor Party seems to want, a United Nations force. It is unrealistic because the Soviet Union has already declared its position and said that it will not support a United Nations force. The fact that there is no United Nations sponsorship does not mean that the rest of the world should bow and accept the failure of this peacekeeping force.

SPEECH.PARA: I deplore very much the sentiments expressed by the Leader of the Opposition this afternoon in his vitriolic attack on the Prime Minister of Israel, Mr Begin. His intemperate language contributes nothing to the cause we are all seeking to support. Everybody should be doing his utmost to bring about some sort of lasting peace within the Middle East. We should all be contributing to finding a solution to the Palestinian question. That problem must be resolved, but there is a chance, a hope, of achieving something in that direction only if the first stage of the peace accords can be achieved, that is, the withdrawal of the Israeli forces from the Sinai Peninsula. Already two-thirds of that force have been withdrawn, but the Israelis are demanding that there be a peacekeeping force of the last one-third. When that withdrawal takes place there is a chance of the autonomy talks proceeding to try to resolve the Palestinian question.

I believe Australia has a direct and vital interest in the peace of the Middle East. That interest arises from trade but, more importantly, we have an interest in maintaining stability and peace in that area. Australia has a long history of contributing to peacekeeping activities. Australian policemen have been in Cyprus. We contributed to the United Nations peacekeeping forces in Indonesia in 1947, Kashmir in 1950, Korea in 1950, and Palestine in 1956. In 1963 we have had observers on the United Nations Yemen observation mission, and in 1962-63 we were with the United Nations group in Papua New Guinea. In 1975 Mr Peacock asked the then Minister for Foreign Affairs in the Labor Government a question about possible Australian participation in a Middle East peacekeeping operation. Mr Whitlam conveyed the answer on behalf of the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The answer stated:

On 29 October 1973 the Australian Permanent Representative to the United Nations informed senior officers of the U.N. in New York that, if requested, Australia would be prepared then to offer a joint force of approximately 440 personnel to the UNEF being set up following the October 1973 war between Israel, and Egypt and Syria.
It went on:

On 30 September 1974 the Prime Minister, in his speech to the General Assembly of the United Nations, said: 'We wish Australia to be always among the first nations from which the United Nations would ask for peace-keeping forces: We shall be among the first to respond.'
As a result, an Australian force went into the Suez area in 1976 and remained there for three and a half years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The real issue in this matter is what is in the best interests of the Middle East from the point of view of peace. I was rather surprised to hear the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) say that the only way to bring about peace is to send this hotchpotch of a force, although we may not send it. That will depend on whether two other governments approve. I can think of nothing more ridiculous. The people of Australia who are listening to this debate will say: 'Are they going to send the force or not?' The answer depends on whether Canada and the United Kingdom agree. I have spoken to Mr MacGuigan, who is the Foreign Minister for Canada, and the Canadians have no intention of joining the force. Does that leave us in the position--
—That is very different from what he said to me.
—Maybe he has changed his mind, but does it leave us in the position--
—A lot of people have changed their minds.

—The Minister says that a lot of people have changed their minds. Could I have a chance to continue the debate? The point the Canadian Foreign Minister was making was that Canada has plenty of other commitments. If we get the message that the Canadians are not going to join the peacekeeping force, all this debate will be irrelevant. We will assume that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) believes we have to have this debate this evening, although for what reason I do not know. He has had no answer to his letter. However, he has gone on record as saying that it might leak out. Of course, the Government is well known for its leaks. Let me put on record what we know to be the situation. Earlier this year the Deputy Prime Minister visited the Middle East and was interviewed on his attitude to a peacekeeping force. He made the clear statement, and it has come out in this House by way of interjection, that he did not mind, provided it was under the auspices of the United Nations. He made that statement himself. Our policy is just that.
—But if the Russians say no, you won't be in it.

—It has nothing at all to do with the Russians. Let me make that very clear. I would like an opportunity to talk intelligently about the matter. On 8 August Prince Fahd of Saudi Arabia put forward eight proposals for peace. We fully support the Saudi Arabian Proposals. How can there be peace in the Middle East when we ignore all the Arabs who are there? Is it not a matter of record that Saudi Arabia is the best bridge between all the Arabs? It is certainly the country from which the oil comes. It is certainly the country where the United States is anxious to preserve some credibility.

SPEECH.PARA: I will come to the nub of the matter. Two-thirds of the Prime Minister's speech passed before he could identify the real issue. He spoke about everything else, but then it came to this: A solution to the Palestinian issue is clearly central to the future stability and peace of the Middle East. How is the Palestinian issue to be solved? Will it be solved by bombing Beirut and killing civilians? Will it be solved by destroying an Iraqui reactor? Will it be solved by Shamir, who is the Foreign minister for Israel, saying no, he will not abdicate from the West Bank? It is not on, from his point of view. Why is it that we are to commit our troops to this area? It is fundamentally clear that the Arab-Israeli conflict derives from the non-resolution of the Palestinian problem. The Palestinian problem has been the principal unifying factor with the Arabs. The failure to solve the Palestinian problem has resulted in a deepening of Arab political alienation from the West. The non-resolution of the Palestinian problem has been the most important factor frustrating Western attempts to co-opt the Arab countries into an overt Western aliance. Is that not important?

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you debate the issue?

—The honourable member makes a stupid interjection about debating the issue. Here we are discussing the Palestinian matter. Let us make it clear that the issue is an independent Palestinian state on the West Bank. Let us look at what is happening. We should be trying to give some prestige and stability to the Saudi Arabians but there is a good chance that we will destroy them. If we destroy them we will destabilise the whole of the Middle east. That being the position, should we not be discussing the concept of the Saudis being the moderating influence? What about Australia taking the initiative and suggesting that we should agree with what the Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia suggested as early as the first week in August. Why was what he said not accepted? The Israeli Prime Minister Begin said he did not like it. Is that sufficient reason to reject it? Unless we give some prestige to the people who can negotiate in this area nobody can be reconciled to the proposition that there will be peace in the Middle East with the Palestinian terrorists and the Lebanon. Have honourable members opposite discussed with their Lebanese constituents the possibility that the Lebanon is about to be destroyed because war has been exported into the Lebanon. Do honourable members opposite not understand the problems of that nation? They talk about not wanting it to be divided. Can they not think of a more divisive matter in their constituencies than the fact that there is no solution for these Lebanese people? Let me make it very clear that on 21 April Begin protested vigorously to the United States of America about the proposed sale of AWACs aircraft to Saudi Arabia, claiming that it would be a threat to the security of Israel. I wish to put on record what Saudi oil Minister Yamani had to say. On the next day in New York he said that Israel, not the Soviet Union posed the primary threat to Saudi Arabia. He said that Israel is the opening through which the Russians will creep into the Arab world. Have honourable members opposite got that? That is what Yamani said. He said also that if countries planned against a Russian threat when the real threat was to the internal or regional instability of the Arab people they would miss the whole point. Pressing countries such as Saudi Arabia to accept an American military commitment only contributes to the instability of that country and threatens the very security of the United States itself. The record speaks for itself.

SPEECH.PARA: Ostensibly what we are about is fulfilling the Camp David Accords. There are two elements to those Accords. The first is that the Sinai should be given back to Egypt. The second, running parallel with it, is that there should be full autonomy for the West Bank and Gaza. Nothing has happened with respect to the latter. What has happened on the West Bank bears a bit of description. The evidence is that Israel is continuing to establish settlements on the West Bank. There are 15,000 Israeli settlers in that area and they represent the most militant of all people. Arab lands on the West Bank have been expropriated. In June of this year the Begin Government established Israeli courts for the Jewish settlers there. As far as Shamir is concerned, the solution is for the Palestinians to settle in Jordan. That would be fine if it were possible to get every other Arab to agree with it. Let us put on record also what Cyrus Vance said about the Camp David Accords. He said:

It was agreed at Camp David that there should be full autonomy for the West Bank and Gaza. It was understood by the parties that full, and I underline full, autonomy meant exactly what the words indicated.
What did he say about Reagan? He said:
The Reagan Administrative has sought to push this issue far to the back of the stove and has not developed a policy with respect to this critical matter.

Is that not the real problem that we are debating here? How can we commit Australian forces without a guarantee of peace in that area and when we are not looking at the real crux of the problem as it was identified by the Prime Minister. The Palestinian issue is the one that has to be solved. We will not solve the problems of Egypt by putting a force of 2,500 in the Sinai. The problems of Egypt are basic. The problem that Mubarak now faces is a resurgence of Islamic fundamentalism whose supporters are opposed to Egypt's Western style of government. We are now asked to bolster up Mubarak in these crucial days by putting 2,500 troops in the Sinai. They would not last one day if war broke out. The Prime Minister said that in his statement. He used the delightful expression that if war broke out between Egypt and Israel, of course, we would not remain there. I do not know what he means by the use of that expression. The crux of his statement was that so much depends on Prime Minister Begin. I make it very clear that we are firmly of the view that the state of Israel must exist, but it has to be on the basis that the Palestinians also are entitled to co-existence. Mr Begin does not subscribe to that view. That is the difficulty in which we find ourselves. If Begin is of that particular view-he has expressed it-and if his Government is of that view why is the Government suggesting that in any shape or form we can get stability in the Middle East? One of the parties there says: 'I will not agree to any settlement on the West Bank in accordance with the Camp David Accords'.

One of the two fundamental elements of the treaty was that the Sinai should go back to Egypt. The other was directed to solving the Palestinian problem. It has not been solved. What then happens to the treaty? Are we to rely on a letter that President Carter wrote to Anwar Sadat saying that he would contribute a peacekeeping force? Are we to say that that letter constitutes another treaty? It is completely contradictory to what the Camp David Accords are about. The Camp David Accords provided that there should be a peacekeeping force under the auspices of the United Nations and that it should not contain elements from any one member of the United Nations Security Council. Does the Government not see the danger to which it is subjecting our forces in the belief that the only way to solve the problem is to have a force virtually under United States control? We all know that the United States has pressured this Government into joining the Sinai peacekeeping force.

It appears from the statement made by the Prime Minister that he is not worried about any leaks. He is more concerned to announce quickly that he will go to the Sinai if the two other Governments will go. His announcement will not influence those other governments to make a decision that they will go. I find outrageous the suggestion that we have any clear national policy of our own. How much more constructive it would be if we passed a resolution this evening to the effect that we welcome peace in the Middle East, we recognise the right of Israel to exist, we recognise the right of the Palestinians to exist, we accord with the principles of peaceful co-existence, and urge that there be some discussion with the Saudis on the eight-point plan put forward by the Crown Prince in the first week of August.

Why does the Government have to be beholden to Begin in what he has said? He has lost his reputation in the eyes of the world. Nobody in the world would support the bombing of Beirut or the destruction of the Iraqi reactor-not even right-minded Israelis, certainly those in Australia. They do not accept Begin as a leader. He is somewhat irrational from the point of view in his understanding of the problems of his own people. Whilst it is his conviction that he will survive by getting the United States to come in alongside him with a peacekeeping force, that has doubtful value for the reasons that I have mentioned. How in the name of fortune can the Government say to the Australian people that everything will be all right when we know that every Arab state is against what we are about? How can we destabilise Saudi Arabia and jeopardise the Saudi's chance to do something about the situation?

The Government is talking about oil. The Saudis have made it very clear that if war breaks out in the Middle East they will first destroy the oil wells. The Saudis have made it very clear that they want a solution to the Palestinian problem. Why does this Government run away from it and then try to hawk its principles for trade? It is worried about trade which amounts to a measly few dollars, but it is not worried about the lives of our servicemen. Are those the standards of the Government? Is that how honourable members opposite want to carry on this debate? Clearly, trade does not come into it. The issue is one of principle and peace in the Middle East-the lives of people. That is what comes into it. I ask honourable members opposite whether they heard the Lebanese tonight talking about 100,000 dead in recent years. Yet we talk about peace in that area. If the Government wants to buy oil why does it not take some notice of the Saudi's proposition? Why does the Government not take a stand and say what we are about? We will support it in any multinational peacekeeping force that is under the United Nations.

TALK.START.PARA: —As long as the Russians agree.

—It has nothing to do with the Russians. The Minister is fearful of facing the truth. He is the fellow who is worried about trade. He will not solve anything. When the casualty lists come in showing our dead he will remember what he said. That is the issue for him. That is the problem he is facing. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
'the House condemns the Government for
(a) abdicating its responsibility in allowing the commitment of Australian forces to the Middle East to be subject to the decision of other governments;
(b) its provisional decision to commit Australian forces in the Middle East without any real prospect of a lasting solution to the Palestinian issue; and
(c) its failure to actively pursue diplomatic initiatives which would contribute to a Middle East settlement by provision of a United Nations sponsored peacekeeping force.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Mr R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this statement of the Prime Minister (Malcolm Fraser) because it indicates Australia's support, even if it is conditional, for a peace initiative of great importance to the whole world. We are talking of a small contribution to a force established for peaceful purposes at the request of two countries at peace to be located on peaceful territory, which makes any analogy with Vietnam, to which many opponents of this force in the Australian Labor Party have alluded, absolutely ludicrous. To say that the force is therefore not necessary is to ignore both the history of the Sinai and the history of relations between Egypt and Israel. These two countries were at war for decades with the Sinai as the battleground, and the Sinai itself is an area of great strategic importance to both countries.

SPEECH.PARA: Given these circumstances, this history and the sacrifices made by both these nations-Egypt in its relations with the Arab world and Israel in its major territorial concession-it is only natural that they should request a matchmaker and monitor in the nature of this force while this most important part of the peace treaty is being implemented. It is only natural that they and we would want this force to be of sufficient international representation as to give their initiatives the credibility and international status and confidence required to proceed in their bid for peace in a region where so many of the countries see the only peaceful solution as being the obliteration of Israel and to visit yet another holocaust on the Jewish people. We, by this statement, are showing to the world that there has to be a peaceful settlement, recognising the right of Israel to exist in peace with secure boundaries.

This is not just a moral commitment to the state of Israel as the only true democracy in the area-a state a quarter of the size of Tasmania existing precariously in an area surrounded by implacable enemies committed to its ultimate destruction. There is more than that compelling moral justification. Our participation is justified and made necessary on other grounds also. This force, requested by both Egypt and Israel under United Nations sponsorship or otherwise, was the subject of an important part of the Camp David agreements which the Australian Government and the Australian Parliament fully supported. Last year, following the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, this Government's diplomatic actions against the Soviet Union were defended by indicating that peace and stability in the Middle East was very much a part of Australia's security interest. That position has not changed. More than this, our regional security interests do not alter the fact that Australia is part of the Western alliance. That alliance, which includes our South East Asian trading partners, has a vital strategic interest in supporting free world interests and peace in the Middle East.

I let the Labor Party ponder on what would happen if all countries adopted its position on this matter. It would enable the Arab world, particularly the hard line rejectionist states, to assert that there was no comprehensive international support for Camp David, that Sadat's death was justifiable, that Sadat was wrong and that peace cannot be achieved if we recognise the right of Israel to exist. This Labor Party approach would dangerously isolate both President Mubarak's Egypt, when he desperately needs support for continuing the peace initiative, and Israel, when it is forsaking valuable territory. I ask members of the Labor Party: Do they want to isolate the two countries who have made the only bid for peace in the Middle East and the two countries whose strength and peaceful relationship is vital to Western interests in the Middle East? If all middle power countries adopted the Labor Party's view, would they not be encouraging, by their non-participation, American and super-power unilateralism in the Middle East? That is hardly a recipe for peace in the region or in the world.

Then, of course, we have the Labor Party attitude, with a few exceptions, of now reacting almost automatically against any foreign policy initiatives of the United States of America and now against Israel, ignoring many of the counterveiling forces at work. Why does the Labor Party never criticise the Soviet Union? Why does it not sometimes criticise the Palestine Liberation Organisation in debates such as this? Whether we like it or not, there happens to be two super-powers in this world-the Soviet Union, totalitarian, suppressive of human rights and militarily aggressive internationally; and the United States, militarily strong, but supportive of free world principles. In the final analysis I know where I stand and where our interests lie, but that does not mean that we support the United States blindly or lose our independence in foreign policy initiatives. We have already shown that by not responding to this issue immediately and without careful consideration and satisfaction of our own interests. We have shown it by our decision not to participate in the United States rapid deployment force and by the conditions of our participation outlined by the Prime Minister.

But when we agree with the United States on initiatives such as Camp David, surely we should not continue to say to the United States: 'You bear the burdens; you pay all the costs'.
