Once again there would not be a concerted resolve and a willingness within the Western alliance to work together and share the burdens involved in maintaining peace and protecting Western interests and initiatives. Would we not, by failing to participate, jeopardise the whole Israeli-Egyptian peace bid and increase further the potential for conflict in this region and between those two countries? Would we not instead, by accepting the Labor Party line, accept the views of nations such as Syria, Iraq, Libya, Ethiopia and the Soviet Union and the PLO, most of which accept the destruction of Israel as the only peace solution.

I agree that United Nations sponsorship of this force would have been desirable; we all do. But let us look at the appalling logic of the Australian Labor Party on this issue. It comes to me that many of those who do not support our participation would agree to it if it were under United Nations sponsorship. In other words, the concept of the force itself is not necessarily open to question. To these people I just say that the peace treaty documents made specific provision for the United States to organise and maintain an alternative force in the absence of United Nations support. The peace treaty itself is based on United Nations Resolution 242 which we accept as the basis for a negotiated settlement to the Arab-Israeli dispute. More than that, a failure to mount a credible force, if due to an absence of United Nations sponsorship, will amount to abandoning a peace initiative at the request of the Soviet Union which has a vested interest not in peace but in tension in this area. It is the Soviet Union which has prevented this force from being a United Nations sponsored force.

On the autonomy question, we all agree that a lasting peaceful settlement in the Middle East requires a solution of the Palestinian problem. This Government, through United Nations Resolution 242, has always accepted that proposition. Progress must be made in this area, but it does not involve concessions coming just from Israel. The Arab world must also make some concessions, as President Sadat did. People seem to forget that the hard line Arab world opposes this force because it opposes Camp David. It opposes Camp David because Camp David recognises the right of Israel to exist. That is why the PLO has not allowed any West Bank Palestinians to be involved in the autonomy process. The Arabs are going to have to make concessions too. The Labor Party has not recognised that fact so far in this debate.

People seem to forget also that Israel took the West Bank from Jordan and the Gaza Strip from Egypt in a defensive war. The two areas had been under Arab rule for 19 years with no thought being given to establishing a Palestinian state. The Arabs rejected a Palestinian state when the United Nations proposed it in 1947. If Israel has an obligation, as it does, to negotiate about the West Bank, it is certainly with the party from which it took the West Bank-Jordan. There is no question that the autonomy talks must proceed. They are the key to a lasting peace, and Israel must make major concessions. But I think it ironic that Arabs demand that Israel do for the West Bank and Gaza what they were unwilling to do at a time when Israel had no say in the matter. Neither should we forget that although the Arab world objects to Egyptian-Israeli negotiations for Palestinian autonomy, Saudi Arabia, Jordan and other moderate Arab states have consistently taken the position that Egypt has the right to negotiate for the return of its sovereign territory. Surely if this force is an internationally credible one, we and other nations and the United States are in a better position to influence both Israel and the moderate Arab world to make the necessary concessions on the autonomy issue. But the Labor Party does not allow for that in its position on this issue.

Certainly it was a condition of the peace treaty that the autonomy talks should proceed. This acknowledges the link between the two accords. It also acknowledges that the autonomy discussions will be long, complex and difficult, with even the Arab world undecided as to the most appropriate solution to the Palestinian problem. But this peace initiative between Egypt and Israel must not be thwarted by continuing delays in the autonomy talks which deal with the more fundamental and more complex peace negotiations and which are of much more concern to the Arab world. Furthermore, Sadat was also frustrated by the delays in this autonomy process. He would not sacrifice the peace treaty on these grounds and therefore, neither should we. Everyone says that Egypt had had enough of war when it came to the negotiating table. Believe me, so has Israel. It has had enough of it too, and it will make reasonable concessions if the Arab world will. But we cannot blame Israel for being a little nervous, given the current attitudes of the rejectionist Arab states. The Labor Party does not seem to concede this, and has not done so to date in this debate.

There is every indication that Israel now wants to make further progress in these negotiations. It will rightly come under increasing pressure to do so. Sharon, the Israeli Defence Minister, has been undertaking initiatives to convince Arab leaders in the administered territories to join in the negotiating process, but concessions have to be made by both sides and Israel cannot be expected to withdraw from strategic territory to make it easier for some Arab states to destroy her. It is up to countries such as Australia and all who may participate in the force to make it a condition of our participation that progress be made on the entire Camp David peace process, and the Prime Minister has clearly stated this in his statement to the House.

I welcome these conditions in the statement and also the condition against any involvement in the Rapid Deployment Force. I must say that in my view there has been an exaggeration in public debate as to the way in which participants in this force could become involved in a wider conflict involving the United States. This force simply does not have the capacity to be involved in that kind of conflict. The major powers maintain their military presence in the region in other ways-by arming their allies, by access to defence facilities in friendly nations in the region and, of course, by maintaining a naval presence in the north-western Indian Ocean and in the Mediterranean. The nature of this force and the conditions of participation outlined by the Prime Minister provide the appropriate safeguards for this matter.

In summary I want to say that I support this statement. It recognises that we all have a role to play in assisting the peace initiatives undertaken courageously by both Sadat and Begin. It may not be the perfect peace solution, but in the Middle East surely we do what we can when we can where we can to secure peace, to encourage further peace and to encourage the major participants to make the necessary concessions and to seek to replace attitudes of mindless violence with reason and realism, as Sadat did. I support this statement as a very small step in that direction and I deeply regret the position taken by the Labor Party in abandoning this peace process because of its ideological, unbalanced and dangerous attitude towards Israel. In all my time in this Parliament I have never heard a more disgusting, unbalanced and outrageous diatribe against the state of Israel, against the United States and, by strong implication, in favour of the PLO. It was totally unbalanced, blaming Israel and Begin for all the sins of the Middle East. But did we hear the Opposition leaders talk about Gaddafi? Did we hear them talk about Arafat? They did not rate a mention. The rejectionist states did not rate a mention. Of course, they blamed the terrible United States and the terrible Israel. I want to know where the so-called moderate members of the Australian Labor Party stand on this issue. I challenge them to stand in this Parliament and to say that they still support the state of Israel. Will the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke), a friend of Israel, privately stand in this Parliament to state his position on this issue?

TALK.START.PARA: —Your policies come straight from Washington.
— Order! The honourable member for Hindmarsh will remain silent and the honourable member--
—This is the only time the state of Israel has come to us for assistance and what has the honourable member done?

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I object to the gratuitous introduction of my name into this debate. I simply make it clear that if the Government allows sufficient time for me to speak I will be speaking and I will be heard. The honourable member for Perth should just complete his own speech and leave me out of it. I am quite capable of looking after myself.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! That is not a point of order.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.
—I want the honourable member for Wills and the other moderates to say they support the state of Israel.

—Order! The honourable member for Perth will resume his seat. I had already called the honourable member for Perth to order. Before the point of order was taken I had called the honourable member for Hindmarsh to order for interjecting. I had called the honourable member for Perth to order. He obviously did not even hear.
—He was speaking and had the call. Why should you call him to order?
—The honourable member for Macarthur will remain silent or I will deal with him. The time of the honourable member for Perth has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment and oppose this Government's decision which will regrettably lead to another needless division in the Australian community. The Middle East is the most unstable region in the world. Let me say honestly that we all seek a peaceful solution. We tend to underrate or fail to understand the enormous complexities of the problems in the Middle East. The difficulty with the proposed Sinai force is that the reasons for it and the debate about it consider only the current strategic preoccupations of the United States and much of the West. These have to do with maintaining the limited achievements of the Camp David process towards peace and, with it, the influence of the United States upon both Israel and Egypt. The United States Middle East preoccupation is not with the settlement of the Arab-Israeli conflict per se, or rather what we should call the Palestinian problem, but with achieving a strategic consensus about what the United States regards as the major threat to the Middle East region, namely, the threat of Soviet influence and expansion.

SPEECH.PARA: The United States, therefore, in its Middle East policies is, to coin a phrase, fighting the wrong war. In its global preoccupations it has lost sight of the central regional issue of the Middle East which is the Palestinian question and Arab nationalism which can be summed up as much of the region's desire to solve its own problems without the involvement of outside global powers. The Middle East conflict is, therefore, a conflict about the Palestinians first and foremost. It is not primarily an extension of superpower conflict in the region as the countries of the region have made abundantly clear. At the time of the announcement of the Carter doctrine and its Rapid Deployment Force post-Afghanistan, the Arab countries rejected the proposition that a Soviet threat to the region was the major factor threatening its security and stability. They protested that for them it was the Palestinian issue that is first and foremost. But still the Reagan Administration insists that it is external threats to the region from the Soviet Union or its proxies which are the key and it has sought a strategic consensus accordingly.

The trouble with the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is that it accepted the United States view of the Middle East which is one which holds that the root of the problem is the Soviet Union. The Soviet Union participated in the Geneva meetings which were the major agency for the search for a Middle East peace until Carter initiated the Camp David Accords. The Middle East peace process then became an American preserve, when I believe it ought to remain an international one to avoid the introduction of global conflict and to give the Soviet Union, as well as the United States, a vested interest in its success. By remaining an issue of general international concern and responsibility, the suspicion of individual and particular interests, so strongly held in some quarters, would have been removed. I believe that the Arab countries reject this priority. They believe that the United States is fighting the wrong battle in the region and has contributed to their suspicion of a United States inspired and led Sinai peace force. They fear that, first and foremost, its purpose will be to serve United States global interests, which may or may not include those of the region. The Sinai force is, in any case, a product of the Camp David Accords, which the Arab countries reject, not least because they fail to address the central issue, namely, the Palestinian question.

Most people associate the creation of the state of Israel with the atrocities that were perpetrated against the Jews during the Second World War. In that sense Israel and the support for it-and I support Israel-is at least in part a salve to our consciences for the recent period of history. The creation of the state of Israel dates back beyond that. Biblical Israel was settled upon primarily on account of the eventual support of the British Government for the creation of a homeland for the Jews in Palestine. It is unquestionably clear that Britain's reasons for supporting Israel were not in any way altruistic. Its motives were strategic and imperialistic. Although there were serious misgivings in the governing circles of Britain at the time, the Balfour Declaration of 1917 committed the British Government and thus the West to a course of action, the consequences of which remain with us today. The Palestinians were displaced by the eventual creation of the state of Israel, and this has led to enormous political, social and strategic problems. It was, perhaps, not until oil gave the Arabs the capacity to command some influence, more than a decade later, that we began to consider in a serious way the case of the people dispossessed in the enthusiasm to create a homeland for the Jews.

I suggest to honourable members opposite that the force of nationalism is a factor which must be taken into account in dealing with the Middle East. We failed in 1956. It is surprising that the British took so long to face this. After all, they had the benefit of their Irish, South African and Burmese experiences. In the end, they learned that economic betterment makes no appeal whatever to nationalists as an alternative to self-determination. Birthrights are not to be sold for a mess of pottage. If anything, economic betterment merely stimulates the passion for freedom. The whole train of events in Palestine since 1917 confirms this. A study by the Carnegie Foundation for International Peace on the economic consequences of Israel's occupation of the Gaza Strip and the West Bank of the Jordan similarly concluded that 'although these territories had become much richer, the improved economic situation in no way abated or will abate nationalist demands'. The whole question went deeper than the wording of the intention of the Balfour Declaration. On the one side there was a minority determined to become a majority; on the other side, a majority determined to remain one. The political history of Palestine between 1917 and 1948 was a ruthless struggle for mastery between an indigenous population and a people whom they saw as invaders. A durable peace is secured by justice and what is seen to be justice by both sides.

In their fabulously long history the Jews have suffered many hideous and horrible injustices. The state of Israel will feel neither secure nor durable until the Palestinian people feel that the injustice done to them has been redressed. For them too there must be a national home. Two wrongs never make a right. The Jews were wronged and, with the creation of the state of Israel, the Palestinians were wronged. The Middle East conflict today stems essentially from that simple fact. It is a Palestinian conflict about Palestinian rights. Slowly the world is coming to accept that fact. It is reflected in the increasing international recognition of the Palestine Liberation Organisation. That recognition has been growing among European Economic Community countries, which believe the Palestinians must be brought into the peace negotiations, as did, more recently, the participants at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Melbourne. The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics has granted diplomatic recognition to the PLO. The United States Administration has been closely associated with support for Israel. Before President Sadat's death, on a visit to the United States he urged President Reagan to recognise the PLO as part of the new effort to achieve lasting peace in the Middle East. The United States has continued to insist, and I agree, that the Palestinians must recognise Israel's right to exist. While that is so, United States diplomats and others are privately conceding the necessity to bring the PLO into the peace negotiations.

The efforts of the international community must therefore be concentrated on encouraging this development, which is as crucial as a Sinai force can ever be. The Sinai force is the product of the Camp David Accords, which most of the Arab world rejects because, regrettably, they do not take into account the Palestinian question. The credibility of the Camp David Accords is hence seriously in question. This is the first and foremost reason why Australia should not become involved in the peacekeeping force of their making. The terms of the treaty of peace require that an international force be in place by March of next year. In spite of the efforts, only the governments of Fiji, Colombia and Uruguay have announced that they will join the force. There are rumours that France will participate. There is a strong possibility that Canada and England will join the Sinai peacekeeping force. That will be well and good if it dilutes the United States component of the force. One observer has written:
Since the Reagan Administration came to power, there has been an impasse in the Middle East because the Americans, who have the power, are operating-like Eden 25 years ago-without any firm principle.

This provides an opportunity for Britain, which lacks the power (and this may be an advantage) but does have the experience and a degree of influence which could be used to good effect in support of a policy which can be seen to be clearly and firmly based on principle.
Britain's obligation is an inescapable one because of our past association with Palestine.

I refer honourable members to the time of the McMahon papers in 1915, to the Sykes-Picot Agreement, and to the statements by Wilson just after the First World War on what a disaster the British and French influence was, that it was intended merely that Britain should get control of Palestine and France control of Syria. Finally, there was a declaration by Wilson in which he referred to 'the whole disgusting scramble' for the Middle East and the mandates for former Turkish territories which were alloted at the San Remo conference in 1920-Syria and Lebanon to France, Palestine and Mesopotamia to Britain. I will quote a recent article by Naham Goldman in the Guardian this year: It is ironic to recall what he said. He stated:

On the United Nations debate on the partition of Palestine and the creation of Israel, the Soviet Union and the Eastern bloc countries voted in favour of such a move and helped to provide the necessary 2/3 majority. Shortly afterwards when the American Government was toying with the idea of reversing the United Nations decision and setting up a new mandate Gromyko threatened to use his veto in the Security Council.
We ought to remember that. The same man also stated:

I've been a Zionist politician now for more than 60 years. But there is one stand I've always taken since I was 17, and that is that there can be no future for the Jewish state unless agreement is reached with the Arabs.
The world is now obliged to grapple with a colonial and political legacy which will require tact, understanding, tolerance and diplomacy if we are to avoid disaster.

I conclude by making a number of observations. Australian participation in the Sinai force would tie it to the Camp David Accords when it appears that there is less and less international support for them. More importantly, the Arabs, who must accept them if there is to be Middle East peace, do not accept them because they do not take into account the Palestinian factor. Whatever might be said about the Israeli Government's policies, the bedrock understanding amongst Jews is that Israel lives on a very narrow margin of security. It is extremely difficult, unless one is there on the front line, to make a responsible judgment about what will or will not affect the security of that country. Jewish criticism of Israel is always tempered by the conviction-we should remember it-that Jews had better not do anything that would endanger the survival of Israel. We ought to acknowledge that simple fact.

The British, as does the rest of the West, continue to act with ignorance of the future when the Middle East of tomorrow is being contemplated. Present actions by the West may appear to be for the best. The Koran says: 'Had I known the unknown I would have done more good'. If the West wants oil in the right quantity and at the right price and expects the Gulf to champion big production and moderate pricing; if it wants trade and development on its own terms largely dictated by the petro-dollar cycle; if it wants political stability in the region; if it, or at least the United States, wants to avoid a painful decision on Palestine; and, finally, if Washington, in particular, wants to pull together a tough regional line against the Soviet Union it must surely be accepted that, of all these interests, political stability is paramount, not that stability which freezes regimes, blocking necessary internal change and development. Single-minded peddling of reform in the Gulf is not the answer either. The West must not foist on the Gulf governments demands that they play an economic, commercial, political or military role which will undermine their chances of coming to maturity as governments and societies. I oppose the Government's initiative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMahon The Rt Hon Sir W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I emphasise that ever since I have been in politics-certainly during the time when I was the Minister for Foreign Affairs-my sympathies have gone out, above all, to the Israeli people and to Israel because I have thought that the Israelis are the pivotal point in the defence or the security of the Middle East. Therefore, unless they could get an assurance under resolutions 242 and 337 of the United Nations--
—Resolution 338.
—There was no way in which we could ask them to make any concessions at all.
—You had better correct it, Bill.
—I do not want to hear the honourable member, please.
—He just corrected it.

—The honourable member can have a go in a minute. Sir, will you cut that interruption off my time? That abominable creature will always do something stupid. I have been associated with this matter for a long time. I came into politics shortly after Israel became a state. I well remember having to participate in the Suez Canal debates when it was thought that the late R. G. Menzies would be able to get accommodation of his ideas. Regrettably, because of the actions of John Foster Dulles he was not able to do so. Equally, I remember the other problems that occurred with the attack by Israel and the corresponding attack by Egypt.

SPEECH.PARA: I have long since come to the conclusion that there are three areas of vital importance. I touch on one that has not been mentioned; that is, the Arabian Gulf. The Americans at the time of the Carter Government stated: 'The Arabian Gulf is vital to our existence. We will protect our rights to the limit'. Therefore, the Americans are very interested in it. I have mentioned Israel. My support for the Israelis is still as strong as it was before. There is also the case of Egypt. Who are the people who are inviting us as a country to come in to make our contribution to the success of the Camp David concepts? Those countries are none other than the United States, Egypt and Israel. Against that background it would be unbelievably difficult for us to resist the opportunity to go in to help, providing certain conditions were met.

I have to answer immediately the statement that was made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) who obviously did not know what he was talking about. He said, first of all, that there had to be a total solution to this problem. We are not looking for a total solution in one go; we think that Israel should leave the Sinai and that Egypt should move in to occupy the country that is certainly its own. We should play our part there. Then, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said that we would be the ones to go in first but that others would determine what is to happen. Obviously, he did not understand what the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) said when he pointed out that practical commitment will depend upon the decision of other governments. I believe it is probable that we will get Canada, the United Kingdom and New Zealand to come in. Of course, Monsieur Mitterand, the President of France, is a very great admirer and supporter of Israel, so we can rely on the French to come in to support if it is necessary.

What do I think will happen immediately after the Israelis move out and the Egyptians move in? This will certainly strengthen the position of Egypt because it will not have to worry about its rear. It can pay greater attention to the problems that arise because of Libya. Exactly the same situation applies on the other side-there will be tremendous savings for Israel because it will not have to occupy territory and be continuously worried about what happens there. I come back to the simple facts. It would have been a matter of unbelievable shame for me if we had not taken some action to join in what will be the beginning, I hope, of further action to try to ensure a greater degree of peace in the Middle East, particularly the Arabian Gulf area. I do not believe for a moment that we will get a complete solution. Nobody can control Iran; nobody can do very much concerning other countries immediately to the north. The people in those countries cannot very easily be relied upon and they can change very much over the course of time.

We have stated our position. I think it is critically important that we give leadership to bring in other countries-and bring them in very quickly. I think particularly the United States will be pleased because we have shown leadership. Only this morning I was able to put to the Prime Minister in a question that I hoped he would provide leadership shortly. He immediately said yes but he would be making a statement later in the day. I feel proud of being an Australian. We put ourselves into that position and did exactly what the Australian people will, over the passage of time, regard as being absolutely essential.

Let me turn to other things that were said. Firstly, there was criticism of Mr Begin. Obviously, the people on the other side cannot really know what Mr Begin is now doing. He clearly indicated that his attitudes have had to change since the regrettable death of Anwar Sadat, one of the great people in this world. It was a tremendous loss when he left us. We have to start all over again. To be critical of Begin against that background is something which I think is detestable and ought to be criticised bitterly. He will be playing a much better part now that his rear is secure than he was able to play before. Again I emphasise that he will give away nothing unless there is an agreement by the Palestine Liberation Organisation and a commitment by others to ensure that resolutions 242 and 337 are observed.

The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) said that this was a very volatile area. Obviously, he does not know where the troops are going to. It is not troops who are involved anyhow but the transport section. It will be able to move quickly at any tick of the clock. The honourable gentleman should realise that there is the Mediterranean Sea to the north, Egypt to the west, Israel to the east and the desert immediately south. What prospects will there be for serious danger to our troops? It is obvious that whoever drafted the Leader of the Opposition's speech really did not know what he was talking about.

He then went on to speak about the United Nations. Everyone knows that there is no way in which the United Nations can operate because the Soviet Union is still bent on ensuring that the greatest damage is done in the Middle East in the hope that, over time, the Soviet Union will be able to occupy areas that it regards as vitally important to it and, particularly, that it will be able to surround Iran. He then spoke about this small Australian community. I do not need to deal with that. But I do make it abundantly clear that it must be now obvious to the world, and to Australians in particular, that the Australian Labor Party has shown its contempt for and its dislike of Israel.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—Get up and say something nice about it, and learn to speak a bit of English before you shout at the top of your voice. I challenge the new honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) to tell us exactly where he stands so far as Israel is concerned. I challenge him to say that because we all know that his commitment to Israel is just as great as mine is and that he could not agree to anything that was said either by the leader of the Opposition or the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. So that is the kind of case I wanted to put in the 10 mintues made available to me. I have taken only 10 minutes to allow other honourable members to speak. But above all I must make it abundantly clear that I believe that this is one step forward to ensuring that further actions can be taken to try to get peace in the Middle East. It will not happen in our time; that cannot be expected. But at least it will give far better opportunities for peace to be attained than we have ever had before. I believe that the memory of Sadat will be kept in mind. One of the contributions we can make to show that we respect that man and his ideals and objectives is to move progressively towards peace and to do so in a way that will make us in Australia proud of what we have done. The Labor Party has gone on in as despicable a way as I have ever known it to since I have sat here in this Parliament. I challenge the honourable member for Wills to deny that statement that I have made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I really think that the Government members who have spoken in this debate ought to modify the intensity of their rolling rhetoric and thundering hyperbole. When one looks at what is actually being proposed here, great statements of principle are made that we must not retreat from under any circumstances: but then we are told that they will be retreated from, however, if the Canadians and British do not agree to join the peacekeeping force. I think that sort of commitment deserves a slightly lower level of rhetoric and a slightly more temperate argument than we have had to this point. The second point I want to make-I do not make it in any defence of the Soviet Union, but it is necessary to correct one factual error-is that there has been no veto by the Soviet Union of this force. There was no majority on the Security Council for its creation. The veto may well have been exercised but I simply say, as a factual statement, that there was no majority on the Security Council compelling the Soviet Union to follow such a course.

SPEECH.PARA: There is much in the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) foreshadowing an Australian commitment to the Sinai peacekeeping force which is unexceptionable, and some of it is praiseworthy. In particular, he has for the first time stressed the overriding importance of a resolution of the issue of Palestinian autonomy on the West Bank. He also expressed a commitment to peace, rightly pointing out the dangers to global peace that have arisen from crises in the area. The action he has foreshadowed of committing Australian forces to the multilateral force is, however, based on an exaggerated assumption of the significance of that force and its composition to the peace process and the possibilities that involvement with it presents for Australia to play a role in concluding hostilities in the Middle East.

The Government's miscalculation has probably hindered our capacity to play a role in the future peace-making process. It has done so unnecessarily within the terms of its own analysis of the situation. In the first place, the Camp David process has largely run its course. It is impossible not to admire the courage of the principal participants-Begin, Sadat and Carter-in the negotiation of the Accords. It is important to recognise that Israel took substantial risks in giving up the Sinai, denying itself defence in depth and trusting continued Egyptian non-belligerence beyond the period of the leadership of President Sadat. However, it has been very evident for some time now that the Camp David process brought no progress whatsoever toward a wider settlement of Middle East issues. If anything, coincidental with and possibly partly as a result of the Camp David process, tensions have been exacerbated on Israel's other borders. A successful resolution of the Palestinian question which is central to a final peace settlement seems even more distant. Israeli settlement in Arab territories on the West Bank has continued unabated with every settlement reducing the flexibility of and options open to the current and future Israeli prime ministers. The saliency of the moderate Arab position has been reduced by the effective deprivation of the moderate Arab bloc of Egyptian leadership.

The effect of these trends has been that the only moves towards a Middle East settlement, since the Camp David Accords that have had any real value, have been the efforts by some countries not party to it to broaden the base of the peace settlement. Saudi Arabia has been obliged to put forward, and be the advocate of, the moderate Arab position, though, despite its oil wealth, it is not a substantial power in the region. The Europeans have also sought to play a part. Indeed, it is significant that most assessments of whether the new Egyptian President will be successful in broadening the base of the peace settlement are based on the assumption that he is better placed than the late President Anwar Sadat to move outside the framework of the Camp David Accords to reunite moderate Arab opinion both to create the components for a complete settlement and to press Israel to accept it.

There is an indication that the United States would not be unhappy were such a role to be played by Egypt. President Reagan fights desperately for his airborne warning and control systems deal with Saudi Arabia, at least in part, in the hope that the moderate bloc can be re-created with the United States still influential within it. Rather than this peacekeeping force being one which monitors a satisfactory settlement, it is being thrown into a cauldron of uncertainty at best to complete a process which, as a contribution to the future peace in the area, has run its course. It is in this light that the true significance of the peacekeeping force must be seen. It is not the fulcrum around which a peace settlement will revolve. It is peripheral to what will be the great issues in the Middle East in the future. It needs to be absolutely clearly understood also that Australia's participation is not vital to the success of the creation of the force and, by implication, the Government admits it when it says that it will not participate in the force if the Canadians and British do not participate.

Irrespective of this Government's final decision, the force will be in place and will perform its function. Unquestionably, our participation would be welcomed by the United States, Israel, Egypt and anyone else participating. Australia has some credibility as a democratic and constructive power in international affairs. In addition, all three nations have experienced intense criticism for the partial peace they have negotiated. They will greet with relief anyone else prepared to take the heat. But we are welcomed in this context: As a supporter of the actions of the major actors. We are not invited to play a major role. Even more important than that we are not vital to the creation of the force and, therefore, the success of whatever of the objectives it seeks to serve.

This leads to the question of whether it is in Australia's interests to participate. As we are not vital to the success of the force and as the force itself is not central to the next moves for a Middle East peace, we have to have very good reason to be there. Realistic analysis teases forth no such good reasons. We do have an overriding interest in a Middle East peace. We have very little capacity to influence nations towards that course. What little influence we have will be worthless if we are unable to influence both sides. Whatever the Government might think of the private posture of Arab governments, as opposed to their public posture of extreme hostility to the Sinai peacekeeping force, that public posture has been held remarkably strongly for some years now. It is a hostility reflected more extremely in the proliferating Islamic fundamentalist movements which are placing pressures on all Arab states in the region, including Egypt, and to which the Egyptian Government will begin, as it is now, to respond.

It is possible for the United States, France or Britain to run a two-track Middle East policy. Geographic proximity, historical involvement, power and weight in the international community mean those states will influence Middle Eastern affairs irrespective of their decisions on the Sinai force. Australia will not. We do not have the tradition of involvement, we do not have the power or the proximity to the area of these great states. We do not have the massive markets and technical expertise to offer the Arab states. All we have is an international reputation of sympathy with Third World concerns, nurtured amongst others by our current Prime Minister. This is not enough. That reputation, which would have been of value in placing our contribution on the agenda of a broader Middle East settlement, will be squandered by the decisions announced here tonight.

Our force will be the object of the hostility of dissident elements in Egypt. It will be part of a force, significant participants in which will have their own fish to fry. It will be the hostage to the good will of a wide variety of countries and movements which feel matters in the area with an intensity, complexity, sophistication and beligerence scarcely comprehendable to the average Australian. If honourable members do not think that an American-based force, whatever the good reason for its presence in the Sinai, will not be the target of Islamic fundamentalist terrorists in Egypt or the PLO passing through to conduct operations in Israel, they are living in a fools paradise. It will achieve nothing that has not been achieved by others. It will involve us in the policies of others compelling us to unacceptable options of compromising our position or withdrawing. The independence the Prime Minister seeks for the Australian part of the force is a phantom.

What are we going to gain, having compromised our capacity to play any role in the next stage of a Middle East peace settlement? The odious suggestion has been put forward by some that we have made a negative gain by demonstrating again to the United States that we are a reliable ally and worthy of protection. This argument really needs to be knocked on the head. I suspect that in the months ahead, as the Government abandons the high road in explaining its policy and takes the low road, it will feature a little more prominently than it has to this point, although it was beginning to be picked up. The tom toms are out among the Government back benchers in this debate, if not their leadership. If the alliance is not guaranteed by the significant role we play in the south-western Pacific and South East Asia, if it is not guaranteed by the significance of the joint facilities in this country for the United States strategic deterrent, if it is not guaranteed by the other offers of co-operation made by the Government at Cockburn Sound and Darwin, it will not be guaranteed by a 200 to 300 man force in the Sinai. So let us get rid of that nonsense straight away. Whatever we feel about the future, the balance of advantage in the alliance to this point has been with and continues to be with the United States.

For this chimera, for this deprivation of a role in the next phase of a Middle East peace settlement, we jeopardise real Australian interests. The first of these is our overriding obligation to plan, structure, equip and deploy our forces for the defence of Australia and the stability of our immediate area of strategic concern. We have come a long way since the days when we chased the tails of our allies all over the globe. Under the Whitlam Government, and to an extent under this Government as well, we have sat down to plan our capacity to stand alone and contribute to the security of our immediate region. This commitment is a throwback to days left behind. Some 200 to 300 men may not sound like many. It is, however, considerable when taken out of a readily available Australian force of a few thousand. As yet we do now know the costing arrangements. Whatever they are they will at least be a moderate subtraction from the focus of what our defence expenditure should now be on our maritime strike capacity. It would be useful if for a couple of clear decades we could abandon the conservative romanticism and idealism which has so obscured our capacity to get to grips with and sustain public interest in our real, hard interests in this country.

The Middle East has been an expanding area of economic interest to Australia. This is particularly the case in my home State of Western Australia with which the Gulf states are now the third largest and most rapidly expanding trade partners. There has been much cynicism suggesting that opponents of the commitment within the Government ranks have been prepared to sacrifice peace for trade. What a terrible thing to say of the National Country Party! Our only influence with the Arab bloc is largely due to our economic links-the food and technical assistance we provide. Without question, a significant role has been played by the current Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) in expanding those links. We may or may not jeopardise the economic gains we make from our Middle East trade; we will certainly jeopardise what influence the trade process gives us with the Arab governments on Middle East peace questions that this commitment will entail.

This is an unnecessary commitment. It is unnecessary within the terms of the government's own analysis of the situation. It is conditional upon the involvement of the Canadians, the British and a number of other factors. If the Government is serious that it will do all the things the Government suggests it will do, we can only assume, from the Government's own logic, that whether we, the Canadians or the British participate, all those objectives which the Government sought via the Sinai Accords will be achieved. If this is not true a number of Ministers in the Government and their back benchers will have conscience-stricken sleep tonight. So I will take the Government at its word on this matter and support its analysis of the situation-the subterranean analysis that is, of the Government's position-if not its overt rhetoric. It is a debilitating commitment in terms of our reputation for independence. Its only saving grace is that the Prime Minister's qualifications still leave him with an out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter The Hon R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I consider this to be a very solemn occasion indeed. It is rather remarkable that it comes on a day which has been set down by the United Nations as the national and international day of peace. Could a greater contribution have been made to the whole concept of peace-peace in its purest sense-than the proposition that was put before us today by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in such splendid and excellent terms? While I am on that subject, I think tribute should be paid to both our Prime Minister and our Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony). The Prime Minister has become an international figure representing humanitarianism on the African continent. The Deputy Prime Minister has become synonymous with peace and trade in the Middle East. I do not think there is a person in this chamber who does not acknowledge that the Palestinians should have land in which to settle. But I cannot agree in any way with the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) who presented the proposition that suggests that if we go into the Sinai to try to fill the vacuum left by the Soviet Union, which is supposedly the great champion of peace, yet vetoed the establishment of a peace force--
—It did not veto.

—The honourable member can support the Soviets, if he wishes. The facts are that the Soviets in effect vetoed any attempt by the United Nations to provide a peacekeeping force in the Sinai. Let us look at this situation. If this whole proposition falls apart, if the peacekeeping force suggested for the Middle East is not available, there has to be some peacekeeping force there. So we fill the vacuum. The world is clamouring for peace. In the hearts of each and every person throughout the length and breadth of all nations must inevitably be the desire for peace.

SPEECH.PARA: If we examine the two addresses which were made to this chamber prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner, we see that one was a plea-a plea even to the Opposition-to face up to the only proposition that has ever come forward which really establishes a peacekeeping force. I am sure that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) astounded and embarrassed many honourable members on his side of the House with his tirade against Israel. He made no suggestions and put forward no proposition concerning establishing a land for the Palestinians. All he did was to attack the Prime Minister the Begin Government and just about everybody else. At no stage did he suggest that President Sadat had made a contribution, or that the Egyptian people, the Israeli people, the Lebanese people and the people in Iran and Iraq had bled enough and yearned for peace.

What is Australia to do? Senator Church was out here within the last 24 hours. His visit and his lecture tour were sponsored by the Jewish community. He is no friend of President Reagan and he makes no secret of that fact. Yet he, of all people, applauded President Carter and the United States of America and those who are game enough and have the guts enough to stand with them and proclaim a genuine effort for peace. This is what it is all about. We have been asked to confine our remarks to a very limited period. One could speak on this subject for a long time and one could become understandably emotional. Does the House not think that the people in that area have bled enough-I mean bled enough? Tens of thousands of people in Lebanon have been slaughtered and will be slaughtered. Strangely, not very much mention has been made of that carnage, which is what it is.

I conclude with this remark, regrettably, because I have so much to say: I remember well a discussion I had with a very senior person at Whitehall, a Mr Tyrrell. He said: 'We support the Camp David agreement on the understanding that it is the first step towards peace in the Middle East. Once that has been established we will then turn to the autonomy of the Palestinians, the Left Bank, Gaza'. The extraordinary aspect of the speech by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) was that he talked about us supporting Israel right down the line. Good heavens, where is the land going back to? It is going back to Egypt. Israel is losing the land and it is going back to Egypt. After that has been settled, the next logical step will involve the Palestinians, the Left Bank, Gaza. I am sure the whole world was thrilled by the courage of Sadat. His name was on the lips of just about everybody throughout the world. His memory will be tarnished and Australia will stand condemned if it says to the United States: 'We want your support; we want you to protect us at a time of emergency, but you go it alone in the Sinai'. That is just not on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) informed the Australian people of his decision to have Australia participate in the Sinai peacekeeping force, subject to certain conditions. But 10 days ago, on 12 October, the Prime Minister informed the President of the United States of America, and no doubt the Governments of Egypt and Israel, of that decision. He also confessed to having had discussions with the Prime Ministers of Canada, New Zealand and the United Kingdom at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting which ended on 7 October. The Australian people and this Parliament were the last to know that Australian forces were again to be committed overseas by a Liberal government. The Prime Minister has treated the Australian people and the Parliament with the contempt for which he is renowed. The only reason he came in here this afternoon, 10 days after telling President Reagan and more than a fortnight after letting everybody else in the world know of his decision, was that he was scared that news of the commitment would leak out. It is a national disgrace.

SPEECH.PARA: The terms of the announcement are a further national disgrace. What they prove is that the Liberal Party of Australia is incapable of making a decision in Australia's national interest. For decades conservative governments have taken their cue from great and powerful friends. This occasion is no exception. The Prime Minister, obviously unsure of his capacity to make an Australian decision, has hedged his bets by making Australian participation conditional upon the agreement of Britain and Canada to participate. This preposterous condition makes a farce of the Prime Minister's assertion that:
Australia's decision was taken on a completely independent basis.

If the Prime Minister really believed his rhetoric, he would have had no hesitation at all in making a commitment. He would not have had to wait for a ring-around for supportive advice. The manner of this agreement indicates in the most compelling terms both his inadequacy and the inadequacy of his arguments. Let us strip to the bare facts the histrionics of the Prime Minister's statement, accompanied as it was by constant references to spurious and irrelevant arguments about what constitutes peace in the Middle East. The bare facts are that the peace treaty between Israel and Egypt has as its objective the return to Egypt of the Egyptian territory that Israeli forces occupied during 1967 and which Israel has held ever since. In return for that, Egypt recognised the right of Israel to live in peace, with secure and recognised boundaries, free from threats or acts of force.

I agree with the Prime Minister that the two Accords that make up the Camp David Accords are 'not separate and discrete but interconnected two parts of a total and very carefully negotiated package'. Where I differ from the Prime Minister is with the jump in his argument that the Sinai peacekeeping force is directly relevant to both the treaty between Egypt and Israel and the Accords on the framework of peace in the Middle East. The two questions that we in this Parliament and the Australian people have to address are simply: What is the purpose of the peacekeeping force and is it necessary for Australia to participate? Article VI of the Annex to the peace treaty in the Camp David Accords states:
The Parties will request the United Nations to provide forces and observers to supervise the implementation of this Annex and employ their best efforts to prevent any violation of its terms.
Those are the terms of the peace treaty between Israel and Egypt. In explanation of the procedures, the appendix to the Annex states:
As Israeli forces withdraw, United Nations forces will immediately enter the evacuated areas to establish interim and temporary buffer zones.

Let us put this into perspective. The peacekeeping force is to monitor the compliance of both parties to the peace treaty on the withdrawal of Israeli armed forces and civilians from the Sinai-no more and no less. If it is meant to be more, as the Prime Minister suggests, we are talking about another and quite separate concept of security to which I will refer later. Both parties have solemnly agreed to accept their responsibilities. Both parties have a vested and vital interest in ensuring that the treaty works. Earlier this year I asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) at Question Time whether, as both Israel and Egypt had a direct and significant interest in ensuring that the peace treaty was successfully implemented, he would urge both governments to assume full responsibility for managing the withdrawal of Israeli forces, removing the necessity to create a multinational force. It seems rather strange to me that tonight neither the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) nor the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the two Ministers of this Government directly involved, are on the speaker's list. To give the Minister for Foreign Affairs due credit, he did acknowledge the strength of the argument. The Minister put the argument to the United States Secretary of State in this way:
A continuation of these arrangements--
He was referring to the procedures for the withdrawal that had taken place already in the Sinai--
has the advantage that it would pre-empt any suggestion that the proposed multi-national force would have a role beyond that of peace-keeping in the Sinai.

This is not the Labor Party talking, this is the Minister for Foreign Affairs in a communication to United States Secretary of State Haig. He had the perspicacity to see the nub of the argument. We should realise that a major part of the withdrawal from the Sinai has already taken place under the supervision of a small group of some 200 United States civilians, known as the Sinai Field Mission. It seems to me that the mission, perhaps enlarged, could handle the final stages as effectively as, or perhaps more effectively than, a multinational force. The important point is that the main purpose of the peacekeeping force is to ensure that both sides to the treaty keep their commitments. Surely they should readily accept that responsibility and so obviate the necessity for a peacekeeping force which may add to, rather than subtract from, the problems of the Middle East.

I want to take up this question of United States involvement. This has already been alluded to by the Minister for Foreign Affairs in his original concern about the peacekeeping force. I want to make it plain from the very start that we readily acknowledge and applaud the honest broker role played by the United States under President Carter in bringing Egypt and Israel to the conference table and assisting in the negotiations of the Camp David Accords. What primarily concerns me is the injection into the Middle East of the military forces of one of the super-powers. I submit that behind the requirement in the original Camp David Accords that not only should the peacekeeping force be under the United Nations but also that the permanent members of the United Nations Security Council, which of course, means the United States and the Soviet Union in this context, should not contribute to the force, is a realisation that there was a danger arising from the presence in the Middle East of the forces of one of the great powers.

Mention has been made of a desire by the United States to put in place in the Middle East a rapid deployment force. I merely flag that possible motive. What has not been mentioned is the motive of the Begin Government in seeking a deeper and more direct involvement of the United States in the Middle East. From the Israeli point of view, of course, this is what it is all about and what it has been all about. I submit that the Camp David intention, and subsequently the Israeli intention, has been to involve the United States and its forces directly. I suspect that if I were Minister for Defence in Israel that would be my perception. But we are looking at this question, I hope, from an Australian viewpoint, what is in the best interests of Australia. Lest there be any doubt about the Begin Government's intentions to commit the United States into the security operations in the Middle East, let me quote from Mr Begin himself in his speech to the Knesset on 5 August 1981. He said:

Of great importance is the announcement, reiterated a number of times by the President of the United States, that Israel is a strategic asset of the United States in the Middle East, that Israel is a friend and ally of America, that Israel performs an important role in blocking Soviet expansionism.
He went on:

I have been asked more than once by American statesmen whether we would wish or be prepared to sign a written defence pact with their country. I have answered them consistently: 'If you make such a proposal to us, I shall recommend to my colleagues in the Government to sign such an agreement'.

So we get to the nub of this whole concept. Israel had gone through the United Nations process in the Middle East before and was dissatisfied with the role of the United Nations; but the object of Israel is to bring the United States into the area of the Middle East as a guarantee of its security. As I have said, if I was an Israeli that would be my argument. That is what I would be seeking to do. But, for goodness sake, let us at least know what the facts of the situation are before we get ourselves involved in the humbug that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) went on with tonight.

So far, big power involvement in the Middle East, although of immeasurable significance, has not been direct. The Soviet Union-let us face up to the facts-has been circumspect in seeking to exploit the situation in Iran following the fall of the Shah and the United States discomfiture over the hostages. Both sides have shown commendable restraint in practice although, as in all things political, the rhetoric has run hot. But the deployment of the forces of one of the super-powers, in whatever form it takes, can only exacerbate what we all recognise to be an unpredictable situation and could lead to a reciprocal escalation. Therein lies the great danger of the proposal that the United States not only send in troops for the peacekeeping force but also, quite obviously, take a leading part in the instruction of those forces. If the United States forces are committed to the area the Soviet Union will doubtless seek to respond in a more direct way, and the very conflagration that we are seeking to avoid could, in fact, become the consequence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment on the amendment which has been moved. In particular I reject paragraphs (b) and (c). Paragraph (b) states:

SPEECH.PARA: its provisional decision to commit Australian forces in the Middle East without any real prospect of a lasting solution to the Palestinian issue.

I ask the Opposition-it is in full flight tonight-how in God's name it expects to solve the Palestinian issue in the long run if it does not take an initial short step? Unless we take our place and play our part in the first step in this long and tortuous process, which I suspect will go on for many years, how will we ever come to a final solution? Paragraph (c) states:
its failure to actively pursue diplomatic initiatives which would contribute to a Middle East settlement by provision of a United Nations sponsored peacekeeping force.
Again I ask: How is that possible? It is impossible. The Opposition knows very well that there is absolutely no prospect of a United Nations force going in to the Middle East.

I support the Government's decision. It has been a difficult decision. I personally have had some difficulty in arriving at a decision myself. I freely admit that in the period before President Sadat's death I was, if not opposed, at least diffident on the subject of whether we should contribute to this peacekeeping force. It seemed to me at that time, that Israel and Egypt had come a long way together since the initiative of President Sadat in 1978. It seemed to me that there was every prospect that they could go the rest of the way down this long road without help from outsiders. Ultimately, it is the countries in that region which will find the solution. It seems to me in the short term that we are committed as friends and allies towards a world of peace, to give assistance if required. Let there be no mistake. The two protagonists in this area, Israel and Egypt, have both sought our assistance in this peacekeeping force.

I turn to the assassination of President Sadat by a bunch of murderous thugs and their cohorts, who have celebrated non-stop since his death. He was a brave man with foresight and initative who started the peace process. I am unlike a lot of other people in that Sadat's death convinced me that we should go to the Sinai. I fairly acknowledge that his death has convinced a lot of people that we should not go. But it seems to me that when there was a real prospect of peace without outside interference that prospect was shattered when Sadat was assassinated. It became our responsibility and the responsibility of other countries who so far have not declared whether or not they will be involved to play a part in an attempt to find a peaceful solution to this troubled part of the world.

There has been a lot of loose talk tonight by the Opposition to the effect that our involvement in this part of the world is tantamount to starting war. I remind the House that what we are really talking about tonight is not war but peace. Many honourable members in this chamber have experienced war. Anyone who has would never want to see it repeated. I believe that we have a very strong responsibility to play our part at the request of our allies to try to find a solution to assist Egypt, whose late President Sadat started this process-the country of Sadat-and to assist Israel, a country that has been beleaguered for so many years. I acknowledge the argument that Israel, in its bombing of Beirut and other recent actions, may have exceeded the bounds of what we would call respectability. But it would have been very difficult to have been an Israeli in Israel in the last 30 years and being subjected to something like four major assaults on their country. It would be very difficult, for a very small country which is surrounded not to believe that there may be a chance to stop all the nonsense and remove the threat to its very existence by a pre-emptive strike. I do not excuse what has been done but I understand it. Israel is the second country that has asked us to be involved in a peacekeeping force.

I take great exception, as I know honourable members of the Opposition do-I hope that the Australian people will have this brought to their attention-when the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) gets up in this House and condemns Israel and Begin out of hand. I think I am correct in stating that he said that Begin was the greatest threat to international peace in the world. Is that or is that not what he said? Are we to believe that Begin for all his faults is a greater threat than some madman such as Gaddafi or Castro and all the rest of those murderous thugs? I hope that the Leader of the Opposition has the decency and grace to apologise for those remarks.

We are going to the Sinai to assist Egypt and Israel. We are going there also at the request of the United States of America to join it in a peacekeeping effort in a vital part of the world. It must be said that we have supported the United States in other places. But honourable members should never forget that at the start of this most recent alliance the United States came to this country in 1942. If people think that we do not owe the Americans not only a debt to try to find a solution to world peace but also a debt of gratitude to keep together with old friends and allies, then I believe they are making a great mistake. We are going there on pragmatic grounds to assist Egypt, Israel and the United States. Last but not least, we are going there in an honest attempt to assist the process of world peace. That anyone can lightly put aside an attempt to assist in the process of peace in a troubled world I find very difficult to believe.

I think it is wrong to call this force a peacekeeping force. The sooner that we get away from those particular words the better it will be. It is an observer force. It is not going there equipped to fight but to assist in the process of peace. If we can adjust to the thought that it is an observer force that we are sending in, as we have done successfully in so many other places-in the Middle East before, in Cyprus and in Zimbabwe-I think we will have the whole involvement in a much better perspective.

I have spoken at some length-no doubt, too long for the Whip-about why we should go in the interests of assisting peace in the world. But, of course, it should not be forgotten that it is very much in our interests as well to go there. I will not dwell on the subject. I do not have to; it has been covered before. But it should not be ignored that we are also helping to secure our oil supplies and the very important trade that we carry on with Middle East countries.

I find it very strange that some honourable members of the Opposition have been gagged from speaking in this debate. The honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke), a man who always prides himself on his honesty, who is always very critical when he feels someone else has not been completely honest, said that he will speak if he gets the time. The fact is that he will not be allowed to speak. Why have all the backbenchers had an opportunity to speak, yet a member on the front bench is gagged?

TALK.START.PARA: —He will have his time.

—If he does I look forward to hearing him. This is a divisive issue. The debate in this House is only reflective of the debate that will go on in the community. We all acknowledge that. It is a risk that we have to take. People are concerned that we will become involved in another Vietnam. I come back to the point that we are not going into a war; we are sending an observer force to attempt to prevent a war. There has been some talk about the risk to our troops and the risk of a wider conflict. The Leader of the Opposition dwelt on that matter tonight. No one denies that the risks are there. Of course they are there. But I ask: Has any great enterprise ever been undertaken without risk? We are seeking to help in the securing of a just and permanent peace. Many will disagree with this decision. I understand their point of view. On balance, having weighed up the arguments on both sides, I believe that the decision is right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There can be no doubt that the Government, like the Opposition, has agonised over this decision for some months. People hold very strong views about the deployment of Australian troops in the Middle East. I do not decry the views held by anybody on this question. I think, after our experience of the 1970s, every member of parliament must examine his or her conscience before he or she puts up his or her hand to commit troops from Australia to any theatre overseas, whether those troops be described as a peacekeeping force or a rapid deployment force.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.
Mr Sinclair-I require the question to be put forthwith.
Question resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr YOUNG

TALK.START.PARA: —Because views are held strongly on this subject and because we have now embarked upon a great debate in Australia, no honourable members on this side of the House will be gagged. Honourable members will express their views as they wish, as time is allowed by the Government for a debate on this matter to take place. It is of such importance-we see it as being of such importance-that we hope that everybody who wishes to speak on the subject will be given the opportunity to do so. As is the case with conservatives, of course, the charge against the Australian Labor Party will be that we are being unpatriotic, that we are not being as patriotic as the conservatives and are not considering what is in the best interests of our allies. We are not here to determine what is in the best interests of the United States of America, we are not here to determine what is in the best interests of Egypt and we are not here to determine what is in the best interests of Israel; we are here to determine what is in the best interests of Australia and Australians. That has to be foremost in the thinking behind the decision which is to be taken by this Parliament.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) asked us not to be divisive on the issue. If all 124 members of this House were to vote in favour of sending Australian troops to the Middle East this would still be a divisive issue because the majority of people in Australia would not accept that the decision we were making was in the best interests of Australia. The majority of people in Australia have already expressed the view that a decision of this nature would not be in our best interests and have rejected it. A divisive issue is being imposed on the Australian electorate by this Government. We know that the views held by those on the Government benches are diverse, just as the views held on the Opposition benches are diverse. There are degrees to which people commit themselves on issues of this nature.

We have heard much about the Begin Government. I have never spoken with a member of the Begin Government but I have spoken to many colleagues in the Israeli Labor Party. Their views on many of these issues do not separate them from the views of the Begin Government. The people of Israel on many occasions cannot afford the luxury of speaking with two voices. They have to present a united front. In these talks our Israeli Labor Party colleagues have expressed the view that they think it important that Australia join the so-called peacekeeping force to go to the Middle East. I say to them as I say to the Parliament now that I do not see how under any circumstance I as a representative of the people of this country can put up my hand in favour of sending troops to the Middle East in the belief that that commitment will play any noticeable part in bringing about peace in that area.

We have heard tonight from some Government speakers that they expect us to believe that we can isolate the region to which this peacekeeping force is to be sent and expect that it will be cut off completely from whatever else may happen on the other borders of Israel. That cannot be done. When we are talking about the conflict in the Middle East we are not talking about just the Sinai; we are talking about all of the Middle East. There is no doubt, as the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley) quite correctly pointed out to the Parliament tonight that the interests of many people will be served by disrupting this so-called peacekeeping force. Many people will be interested in disrupting it and provoking it and perhaps getting it more greatly involved than was the original intention.

I do not decry the Camp David Accords. If Egypt believes in them, Israel believes in them and the United States believes in them, it is for those countries to decide; I do not decry them if they want to take steps in accordance with the Camp David Accords. I am voicing my opinion on behalf of the people that I represent about what is the best for Australia. I say that what is best for Australia, based on the experiences of the 1960s and 1970s, is that we vote to keep the troops at home in Australia. The same people who have made the announcement tonight, the same people who have told us that only a few people will be involved, that the commitment we are making tonight is not all that consequential, are the people who lied to Australia about our commitment to Vietnam in the mid-1960. All the young Ministers who sit on the front bench tonight as party to the announcement, including the Prime Minister, are the people who told us that we were being requested to sent troops to Vietnam. We were never requested to send troops to Vietnam, as evidence now shows. The Australian Government wanted to send troops to Vietnam in order to keep United States forces in the region to protect us. That is the truth about Vietnam.

Some people say that it is wrong to compare the Middle East with the Vietnam experience. The situation may not be the same. Perhaps it is stretching the bow to compare Vietnam with the Middle East, but surely we should learn something from our experiences in Vietnam. We may not determine our attitudes by our experiences in Vietnam but we should learn from them and we should be influenced by what occurred there, because 510 Australians died there. Thousands of Americans died in Vietnam. Now we are being asked to send people to a far more explosive situation then was the situation in Vietnam when the late Robert Menzies made the announcement to the House of Representatives in the mid-1960s. There is no overriding evidence, as was also pointed out by the honourable member for Swan, that this commitment in some way will strengthen the alliance with the United States. This commitment is again evience of how closely we want to be attracted to that alliance. The conservatives of this country have always bent over backwards to answer the call from the great United States, but it was President Reagan himself who told the Prime Minister on the lawns of the White House that we could be a good friend if we told the United States when it was wrong. I do not want to take it even that far. I do not want to tell the United States that it is wrong. If it feels that the role that ex-President Carter played in bringing Sadat and Begin together was taking steps towards peace in the Middle East, let it continue to do so. But it is wrong, and we should say so in this Parliament, to add Australia's name to the list. France may want to send troops there; Canada may want to send troops there. But the commitment to Vietnam never depended upon France and Canada committing troops. We die not sit in Australia waiting for some other great nation to add its name to the list. We had South Korea going with us to Vietnam.

The same people have told us tonight that all is innocent and that if there is any escalation our troops will be coming home. It is too hard to believe and I expect that we owe to the Australian people the decency and the leadership to say to them that it is not in their interest for us as parliamentarians to put up our hands in favour of sending what may be an initial commitment of 200 to 300 people. I cannot promise them that those 200 to 300 people will not be engaged in some hostilities. I cannot promise them that the 200 to 300 people in 1981 may not be 5,000 or 6,000 in 1983 when a further commitment is asked from us. I cannot promise them that they will not become involved in the rapid deployment force of the United States. It is one thing to say that we are following President Reagan on the Camp David Accords because he is following what President Carter started at Camp David, but it is about the only matter in relation to which Reagan is following Carter. He is not following Carter-we have asked the Prime Minister about this-in condemning the violation of human rights in El Salvador. He is not following Carter in his condemnation of the violation of human rights in Chile. He is not following Carter in putting pressure on the South Africans to get out of Namibia. In all of these measures the Prime Minister and his Government take a different line from that of the Reagan Administration. But when it comes to the Middle East, because we have been asked by the United States to send troops, we have to commit ourselves.

It is ludicrous, as has been pointed out by every speaker on this side of the House, for the Prime Minister to say: 'We will maintain sovereignty over the troops we send over there. We will not allow them to become involved where we do not think it is necessary. It will be under Australian control'. But the initial statement reeks of throwing our sovereignty out the window when the Government says that it is waiting for Margaret Thatcher and Pierre Trudeau to tell us whether they will send troops there also. There is something very disconcerting about a statement which says: 'When the British and the Canadians tell us what they are going to do, we will follow suit'. If the Prime Minister was being honest with the Parliament tonight, I would think he knows what the British and the Canadians are going to do, and one can only guess at the reasons that he is trying to keep it a secret from this Parliament. What I say tonight on behalf of the people I represent is no challenge at all to my conscience.

As I said earlier, if all the Labor members said to the Government 'We will go along with you, we will give it a try and perhaps we can play some part in bringing about peace in that part of the world', the branches that we go home to would never accept it. They just would not allow us to put up our hands in that way. In some ways we are only reflecting the views they express and in other ways we are reflecting the attitudes which have been ingrained in us as a result of what the conservatives did to this country in the 1960s and the 1970s. The Government has imposed a very divisive issue on Australia, an issue which in the weeks ahead it will be sorry it imposed. It has done it in a manner which has thrown out the sovereignty of Australia by making it depend on other nations to make the decision for us. We hope the Australian people will support us in stopping those Australian troops from going to the Middle East in the first place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.
