TALK.START.PARA: —I am impressed by the persuasive arguments of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) today on Australian participation in a Sinai peacekeeping force on the conditions mentioned by the Prime Minister. I am just appalled at the attitude of members of the Opposition in this place on this subject. All we have heard from them is negativism. There has been nothing positive at all. I see a positive trend towards isolationism in the Opposition's foreign policy. The Opposition has knocked the commitment to the Sinai peacekeeping force. It has knocked the Camp David Accords. It was negative about the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. It knocked CHOGM. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) was against the whole concept of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. The Opposition wants to opt Australia out of the real world. There is no positive contribution to Australian policy from the Opposition in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: Time and again in relation to the Sinai peacekeeping force members of the Opposition have tried to raise the analogy of Vietnam. That is totally and utterly false. The Vietnam situation was completely different. It was a war situation. That is a question to one side. Here we have two countries at peace trying to continue that peace. Israel has given up two-thirds of the Sinai, that buffer zone that it needs for the early warning against an attack by an Arab nation. That was very courageous on the part of Israel, but no credit for that was given by the Opposition. We want to give moral force and support to the Camp David Accords which provide for an international peacekeeping force. What does the Opposition do? It is against it. The Opposition is completely hypocritical because in its amendment condemning the peacekeeping force it has tried to attack the Government for its failure actively to pursue diplomatic initiatives which would contribute to a Middle East settlement by provision of a United Nations-sponsored peacekeeping force. The Opposition in this place is trying to blame the Australian Government for the Soviets' threatened veto in the Security Council of a United Nations peacekeeping force. I have never heard so much hyprocrisy and rubbish in my life.

Time and again the Opposition has tried to tie this peacekeeping force in with the Rapid Deployment Force. That also is totally and utterly false. Australia has said that it will not participate in the Rapid Deployment Force. I think the Government is to be congratulated on that. But the Opposition is trying to confuse the Australian public by throwing these two things together. This is a peacekeeping force to enforce peace. After all, peace is what we are after in the Middle East. As I have said, Australia has decided not to participate in the Rapid Deployment Force, and no member on the other side should try again to confuse the issue. Why are we talking about a multinational force and not a United Nations force? We are talking about it because, as I said a minute ago, the Soviets have clearly indicated that they will veto participation by a United Nations force in the Camp David Accords. This suits the strategy of the Soviets. It maintains their strategy of instability in the Middle East.

We heard the honourable member for St George (Mr Morrison) mention the Soviet Union, and I congratulate him for that. He said that the Soviet Union had been circumspect in Iraq, but he did not mention, and no other member of the Opposition mentioned, the pact between South Yemen, Ethiopia and Libya that is encircling the Gulf and threatening Egypt. We did not hear from the Opposition about the thousands of Cubans in South Yemen and about the East German advisers and security police running the security in that country. We have not heard from the Opposition about Iraq and Syria. Not one member of the Opposition-I will stand corrected if I am wrong-mentioned South Yemen, Ethiopia, Libya and Syria. There is a dull silence. We could hear the pins drop because members of the Opposition know the truth of the matter. I am looking forward to hearing some of the so-called friends of Israel. The honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) has been mentioned. I am looking forward to hearing the honourable member for Henty (Mrs Child) and the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen) to see where they stand on this issue. It is clear to me that the Australian Labor Party is on the same side as the Palestine Liberation Organisation and the Soviets. The Opposition has not mentioned the threat to Egypt from the Libyan-backed Chad and Sudan. Is Gaddafi in Chad? Is he threatening Sudan? Deny that. Is that the truth?

I like to think I have an open mind. I appeal to Australians to have an open mind on this question. As the Prime Minister said today so adequately, it was a difficult decision to make. He said that the tragic assassination of President Sadat has added greater need for international recognition of the conditions for peace in the Middle East. That consideration has weighed with the Government and has been significant in tipping the balance in favour of participation in a peacekeeping force. The balance has tipped by that tragic event because it is more imperative and urgent than ever before to support a stable regime in Egypt, the Government of President Mubarak. The Sadat legacy of the Camp David Accords and peace must be supported. We must strengthen President Mubarak in power at this time in Egypt.

A number of Opposition speakers in this place today also supported Crown Prince Faud's guidelines of August 1981. I take it-I challenge the Opposition to deny it-that they support item 6 of those guidelines, the establishment of an independent Palestinian state with Jerusalem as its capital. I challenge every member of the Opposition from now on to say that he is in favour of an independent Palestinian state with Jerusalem as its capital.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is different from resolution 242.

—As the honourable member for Perth said, that is different from resolution 242. Let us hear the so-called friends of Israel explain that one away. I was appalled by the speech of the Leader of the Opposition today because he attacked Prime Minister Begin. I give some slight credit to the Leader of the Opposition because at least he acknowledged that Israel was a democracy and the only one in the area. But he said that the Camp David Accords had been discredited internationally. He had not heard about the peace prize awarded to the late President Sadat and Prime Minister Begin. He had not heard about the support for the peacekeeping force that is now arising. The Leader of the Opposition said that Prime Minister Begin was the greatest threat to peace in the world today. I want to repeat that: The Leader of the Opposition said in this place that Prime Minister Begin was the greatest threat to peace in the world today. I point out to the Leader of the Opposition that Israel has just had an election and that that democracy re-elected Prime Minister Begin. So we have to translate and read from what the Leader of the Opposition said that Israel is the greatest threat to peace in the world today. That is what the Opposition is saying in this place. That is the truth of the matter. That is the Opposition's attitude. I totally reject it. I challenge speakers from now on to align themselves with the Leader of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) said that Israel needs peace and that, therefore, it must withdraw. He made no mention of Egypt or the other Arab states acknowledging the right of Israel to exist. He said that the peacekeeping force would be overrun. I ask: By whom and when? Obviously, I am concerned that the poll figures show a lack of support for the Sinai force, but those polls were taken before the tragic assassination of President Sadat. I believe that the courage of the Government today in making this decision and its concern for the peacekeeping process in the Middle East will be recognised by the Australian people. It is a tragedy that the Opposition has been divisive in this House tonight.

I conclude by referring to the United States attitude. I think there is, by and large, a bipartisan attitude in that country and in the Congress between the Democrats and the Republicans on the value of the Camp David Accords and the peacekeeping force. This Parliament in the last 12 months has had the greatest contact and the greatest opportunity to talk with members of the United States Congress it has ever had in its history. Delegations have come to Australia such as the one led by the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Tip O'Neill, and including prominent Democrats and Republicans such as Chairman Rostenkowski of the Ways and Means Committee. Another delegation was led by Senator Mark Hatfield, a Liberal Republican who, I think, was against the Vietnam war. He was accompanied by Senator Paula Hawkins. Chairman Clement Zablocki of the House of Representatives Foreign Affairs Committee also came. Members of the Parliament and the parliamentary committees have had wide ranging discussions across the board with members of the United States Senate and House of Representatives. I am convinced that there is bipartisan support in the United States Congress for the Camp David Accords and the Sinai peacekeeping foce. I think it is a tragedy that the Labor Party cannot adopt a bipartisan attitude on this issue and that it seeks to divide Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have often been accused of being emotional about Israel. I do not resile at all from that position. I believe it is fair to say that the major reason why I joined the Australian Labor Party was that I become emotional about many things, including poverty and suffering. I believe that being Jewish is one of the factors that influences my emotionalism. If I did not speak tonight I would find it very difficult to live with myself. However, I hope that being emotional does not make me irrational. I have tried desperately over the years to be objective about Israel because I think the future of Israel is better served by objectivity. My concern is very simple. It is the survival of the state of Israel. In my view, that can occur only if there is peace in the Middle East. Peace can occur only by two things happening-a recognition of Israel's right to exist behind secure borders, and a solution to the Palestinian problem.

SPEECH.PARA: It must not be forgotten that the same resolution that created the state of Israel included the creation of a Palestinian state. That did not happen because of the attempt of the Arab nations to destroy Israel at its birth. From 1948 to 1967 the opportunity presented itself to the border states and to many other Arab states, including those now described as the rejectionist states, to form a Palestinian state. The West Bank and Gaza were in the hands of Arab nations. They did not take that opportunity. Instead, they waged constant war from 1948 to 1973 against the state of Israel. They had a preoccupation with destroying it. That is the major reason for the failure to create a Palestinian state.

The first sign of change in the Middle East came with President Sadat's recognition of Israel-the Camp David Accords. Much has been said about them. I know that they are not perfect, but I reject the proposition that they are a failure. I cannot believe that anyone would seriously suggest that a treaty that brought about peace between two nations that had been at each other's throats for 30 years and had been involved in four wars, could possibly be a failure. It seems to me to be inconceivable. However, the Camp David Accords envisaged a solution to other problems. Amongst them was a homeland for the Palestinian people, a solution to the problem of East Jerusalem and the Golan Heights. They also included a recognition of Israel's right to exist.

If there is a difference between me and my colleagues it is that they, including the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden), believe that the only way peace can be achieved in the Middle East is by a total package. I do not believe that the Camp David Accords ever envisaged that overnight there would be a total package solution in the Middle East. I am sure we are all aware in this House of the bitterness, hatred and distrust that has existed in that region for 30 years. Anybody who is aware of that would find it impossible to envisage one package solution. I have always seen it as a step by step process. The withdrawal so far, I believe, is part of that process. I do not believe there is any difference between the goals and objectives of me and some of my colleagues. There is a difference only in the strategy. They are seeking a package. I believe the solution has to come from a step by step process.

I refer to the question of Australia's involvement. A person would have to be dumb not to have read in the newspapers some months ago when this matter was raised within the party that I supported Australia's involvement. I did not think it was vital that we be involved. I would like to see it, but the party said no and I accept that. What I think is vital is that we support the multinational force in principle, whether or not Australia is involved. I have been to Israel many times. I know the way the Israelis feel. Israel needs an assurance from the rest of the world that it has its support. Anybody who knows the history of the Jewish people, particularly in the last hundred years, will know that throughout that history it has been the failure of the rest of the world to come to its support that has led to such monstrosities as the holocaust. Any Jew knows that that is deeply ingrained in the psyche of the Jewish people, particularly the Israelis. They are the remnants of the holocaust. They are the sweepings of the concentration camps. They are the people who were forced out of Russia and Poland in the last century. They could find a home only in Israel. They were forced to flee the Arab countries after 1948. They do not believe and have never believed that the world will come to their rescue. They have recent experience of this, such as the events of 1956 and 1967, not to mention the world turning its back on them in 1938 and 1939. I believe that trust needs to be built up in Israel that the rest of the world is really prepared to help the Israelis in a crisis.

There was a fear in Israel when I was there a few weeks ago about what would happen after Sadat. No one was to know that we would soon be in that period. People wondered what would happen after 1982. They desperately want to believe that the Egyptian's intentions are honourable. I certainly do. What if there is a change of government? What happens if, after 1982, President Mubarak changes his views, takes a harder line? That is why this multinational peace force is essential. It will build up confidence in the Israelis to take the next step, which, I hope, will be the establishment of a Palestinian state on the West Bank and in Gaza. I do not want to strengthen those forces in Israel which will use any excuse not to withdraw. There are forces like that. I believe we must press for the next step by having, first of all, a multinational peacekeeping force in that region.

It has been said that Prime Minister Begin is intransigent. I must say that I did not agree with the Leader of the Opposition's statement that he was the greatest threat to peace in the world. If anybody believes the statements made by Prime Minister Begin are intransigent I suggest that he or she should read the Palestine Liberation Organisation covenant and the repeated assurances from people like Kaddoumi and Arafat that they will never renounce the PLO covenant. There is intransigence on both sides. I remind people also that it was Prime Minister Begin who said: 'I will never give up one inch of the Sinai'. Those who quote his statements that he will never give up the West Bank or Gaza must remember that this is the man who said that he would never give up one inch of Sinai. He is just about to give up the whole lot.

I reject, of course, the claim by Prime Minister Begin that there is a right to Judea and Samaria on biblical grounds. I think that is nonsensical. I support the Israeli Labor Party's view that its only concern on the West Bank and in Gaza is security. I think what we in Australia and the rest of the free world must do is to convince Prime Minister Begin, after we have given him the security that he wants, that he has to change his views on the West Bank and Gaza. I think that was implicit in the statement made by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) tonight.

It is true to say that the Australian people do not want Australian participation. It is not for me to go against those wishes. My party has decided one thing. Probably a few of us think differently. I accept that view. At least we should not be involved in the multinational peacekeeping force for the wrong reasons. I reject totally the suggestions that somehow or other there is an analogy with Vietnam. I opposed Vietnam from the beginning. How can one compare a situation in which both the countries seeking to gain peace are inviting a multinational force to come in with Vietnam, when clearly Vietnam did not want anybody to be involved? I point out also that Australia was involved in that region from 1976 to 1979. The only reason we really are not supporting the force is that it is not a United Nations peacekeeping force. The reason that there is not a United Nations peacekeeping force is that the Russians have made it perfectly clear that they would veto it.

I come to the question of trade. I think that it would be very immoral of us to go to Sinai for the sake of shekels. I spoke to many officials in the Middle East recently. It was made perfectly clear to me by our Department of Foreign Affairs people that we had trailed our coat all over the Middle East asking whether, if we went in, we would lose trade. It was made perfectly clear to them that we would not. Nevertheless, I think it would be a very immoral proposition for Australia to make a judgment on this matter purely on the basis of trade. I reject also the argument that this force is part of a rapid deployment force. It is clear right from the beginning that what is envisaged is such things as helicopters, troops with side arms, communications, some transport and a few other things like that. Anyone who has read a description of what is envisaged for a rapid deployment force-divisions, aircraft carriers, squadrons of planes-could not possibly compare this monitoring observer force with a rapid deployment force.

I conclude by repeating what I said at the beginning. I cannot stress enough the need to bolster those forces in Israel which are seeking to continue the peace process. If there is no multinational force there will be no withdrawal. There is no chance then to proceed to the next step. I bow to no one in my desire to see peace in the Middle East. I bow to now one in my desire to see a homeland-a state, if you will-for the Palestinian people. Not only do I have a lifelong commitment to the survival of the state of Israel but also I have family there-I have uncles, cousins and my son is there at the moment. Whilst I support the Labor Party's position on this, I support wholeheartedly the principle of a multinational force in the Middle East. I regret that it appears that this will cause a great deal of division in the community. What strikes me throughout the whole of the Parliament is that everybody seems to be agreed on the same basic objectives; yet we are fighting over the strategy to get to those objectives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen) for a very personally honest and courageous speech in this debate. The most serious and significant international commitment by this Government to a Sinai peacekeeping force was obviously neither automatic nor easy for the Government to make. It is apparent that the views of the representatives of the majorities of the countries of the world are against Camp David as a reasonable basis for peace in the Middle East. One has to look not just at the Arabs but also at the European Economic Community and Canada. The Australian decision was difficult, particularly in light of the changing situation in the volatile Middle East area, the adventures of the Begin Government in Lebanon and Iraq and finally the tragic death of President Sadat. The decision now made adds to the credibility and merit of this Government. The decision was obviously not taken because of United States pressure. If it had, it would have been made far earlier. It was obviously not taken because of the pro-Israel lobby in this country and in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has weighed our responsibility as a respected nation of the world community against the possible short term disadvantage to our commercial interests, against the views of many people in the Government who believe that the Camp David Accords by themselves are not an acceptable basis for an overall peace in the Middle East. The Government has weighed the genuine and persistent requests for involvement from the two parties in particular-Israel and Egypt. It has particularly weighed the request of Egypt since the assassination of the man who has done easily the most for peace in the Middle East. It has weighed the need to hold the fragile advance for peace that Anwar Sadat made and his efforts to support Egypt against those who are wanting to bring down that country.

The fact is that certain EEC countries and Canada which have had doubts about the value of the Camp David Accords as a basis for peace in the past are obviously thinking again. They are thinking again in spite of reservations, particularly their belief in the need to include the Palestine Liberation Organisation and the Palestinians in any settlement. They now believe, as we in this Government do, that what has been achieved and what is now at risk must be supported and buttressed.

The conditions attached to Australian participation are most important. There are four of them in particular. They have been clearly spelt out by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). They are that Britain and Canada also agree to participate; that the Australian contribution be limited to the contribution we are initially called on to make and that the contribution be of a limited duration to be agreed on; that the Australian commander not agree to any order which he believes is contrary to the agreed purposes of the force until he has consulted the Australian authorities; and that no part of the peacekeeping force, including the United States component, have any association with a United States rapid deployment force.

There are two further general conditions that the Prime Minister has indicated in his letter to President Reagan: First of all, that he is looking to the United States to exert and sustain the strongest pressure to ensure that effective progress is made in implementing the Camp David Accords as they relate, not only to the Sinai, but also to Palestinian autonomy; that participation will be on the understanding that all the parties to the Accords abide by word and deed with their provisions and press forward with a continuing peace process in the Middle East. These conditions are of crucial importance to Australia for a balanced and clearly defined participation in the peacekeeping force. The two general points in the letter are of equal importance to the specific, for Australia expects the full Camp David Accords to be implemented. They are that beyond Camp David there must be a continuing peace process and that the Camp David signatories must be part of it.

I am personally encouraged by other comments made in the Prime Minister's speech concerning the responsibility now resting on Prime Minister Begin and the Israeli Government to ensure that the autonomy talks are meaningful and that there are positive results. This is heartening because I believe that in the past the Government has not been completely fair and objective on this issue. Adequate emphasis has not been made of the fact that there cannot be a complete or lasting peace until the Palestine Liberation Organisation and the homeland rights of the Palestinians are recognised. It is the view of the majority of Western and moderate powers in the world that Israel cannot expect a guarantee of the security of its borders from the Palestinians until Israel in return is prepared to guarantee a homeland for those Palestinians; that Israel, under Prime Minister Begin, has not complied with the full intent of the Accords and as far as I am concerned, it gives no impression of doing so; that Israel, at the moment, is more of an aggressor than an injured party in the area; that Israel is attempting to influence improperly decisions of the United States Congress which affect the legitimate priorities of the United States-for example, the AWACs which are being sold to Saudi Arabia.

Israel exists today because of the United States shield and massive support. The United States is the only country which can make the Israeli Government accountable to its neighbours, to the homeless Palestinians, to the Camp David Accords, to the continuation of the present leadership in Saudi Arabia and to the long term peace in the area. The Prime Minister has indicated by his letter and his comments that the Australian Government intends to apply pressure to both Israel and the United States Government on some of these issues. I applaud that and acknowledge that, without our participation in the peacekeeping force, this pressure would not be possible. Britain and France-two countries that belong to the European Economic Community-are two other likely participants in the force. I hope that if we participate along with Canada, Britain, France and possibly others, the pressure can be successfully maintained for Camp David and beyond. I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

Clause 3 (Interpretation).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes clause 3. The Non-government Schools (Loans Guarantee) Act is a perfectly sensible statute which gives the Government power to guarantee loans for the extensions to non-government schools; that is, existing schools. The Act was legislated to facilitate the loan raising capacity of schools involved in extra capital expenditure. This Bill proposes two changes. Firstly, it will extend the guarantee to include interest payments outstanding as well as the principal. We have no objection to that. But it also proposes that the guarantee be available to new or proposed schools. That is what clause 3 deals with and that is why we are opposed to it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Education (Mr Fife) has said that some groups anxious to establish schools, cannot obtain loans because they are considered bad risks by lending institutions either because they lack the ability to meet repayments or because of their lack of collateral. A government guarantee, of course, will turn a bad risk into a good risk. New schools which are a part of a system-that is, the Catholic system or some other established system-will not be affected by this clause. Neither will new schools backed by well organised community or parent groups. They already have the ability to obtain loans with or without a government guarantee.

The schools which this measure will encourage will be just those schools which are causing so much alarm in the community currently. They are schools not attached to mainstream churches or not backed by established communities or parent groups but, on the other hand, seek to follow fairly offbeat curricula or educational practices. There is increasing alarm about schools, the educational inspiration of which comes directly out of the fundamentalist tradition in the United States. The curriculum of these schools is a matter of great concern as are the teaching methods and the teaching conditions. Attention has been drawn to this problem, not only by teachers' unions but also by State Ministers who have expressed serious concern about the proliferation of these schools. The problem is that the State governments are pretty powerless to do much about them, given their existing registration procedures. These schools are entitled, once established, to receive automatically recurrent funding from the Federal Government-that is, as soon as they receive State government registration.

The problem is that the existing registration procedures in most States do not exist to judge the educational performance of those schools but in some cases just deal with such matters as the public health questions which are involved in the establishment of new schools. But, as I said, as soon as they are registered those schools automatically become entitled to recurrent subsidies from the Schools Commission. It is one thing-this is perfectly acceptable-to encourage diversity in our education system. Indeed, if this proposal were not enacted, it would in no way prevent the establishment of some of these schools. After all there has been a proliferation of these schools without the existence of this guarantee. Our view is, however, that the unplanned expansion of some of these rather crackpot schools is something which should not be encouraged by this Government. State Ministers are currently meeting with the Federal Minister in Surfers Paradise. One of the questions which they are addressing themselves to is this question-the registration procedures to be adopted by State governments prior to these schools becoming eligible for Federal Government funding.

I repeat that our opposition to this proposal will not affect those schools which are part of established school systems; that is, systems which already have no difficulty in obtaining loans when they need them. Our opposition is directed towards the proliferation of these sorts of schools, the educational merits of which are highly dubious to say the least. When the Commonwealth and the State Ministers have agreed on new registration procedures and when the educational merits, educational performance and teaching methods and conditions of these schools have been worked out, when there are acceptable registration procedures-then, of course, the Opposition would reconsider its view about this matter. But in the absence of any sort of requirement for these schools to meet basic standards in relation to curriculum, teaching methods and teaching conditions, we will oppose this clause of the legislation because, I repeat, it provides quite specific encouragement to the proliferation of these schools.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Swan-Swan?
—Fremantle.
—The honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins)-he has had so many seats in this place in a handful of years-
—How many have you had?

—I changed seats voluntarily. I went from one seat to the other, the honourable member went out. Mr Deputy Chairman, I did not mean to cause an explosion. The comments of the honourable member for Fremantle indicate that he has little appreciation of the importance of diversity of education. He said that when these schools have proved themselves the Government should look at them. I believe that the benefit of a dual education system is that the experimentation which goes on more in the non-government sector in the long term feeds the government sector and both systems improve from their dual existence. The concern of the honourable member is that the Government is going to go off-I think he used the term ratbag schools-
—Crackpot schools.
—Crackpot schools, it was not much different. He was concerned that the Government would fund crackpot schools. I remind the honourable member that clause 4 of this Bill provides:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . continues to provide that a guarantee will not be given by the Treasurer unless the Minister certifies that, (i) the terms and conditions of the loan agreement are satisfactory, (ii) in the absence of a guarantee a school authority would not be able to obtain a loan on satisfactory terms and conditions, and (iii) a guarantee will not cover any part of the cost of a project that is or is likely to be the subject of a Commonwealth grant, including a grant under the advance approval scheme.
I go back to the first condition which is that:
The terms and conditions of the loan agreement are satisfactory.

I believe that judgments will be made. In my electorate is a school which at this very moment is being born as the result of the efforts of many individuals in the community. It is located in an area called Daisy Hill and it will be called the John Paul College. There is a screaming need for a non-government secondary school in that area. It will become the first and only non-government school in the Logan city area.

Under the Catholic education system it was decided that the application for a school, to be known as the John Paul College, was low on priority and the Catholic education group said that the establishment of a new school shall be in Beenleigh. That was its decision, but the people in this particular area believed that they needed a school. This new school started off and it has now ceased to be of Catholic denomination. It has become Anglican, Uniting Church and Catholic. The three religions are working together in the creation of something which the honourable member described as crackpot, and I do not think he would have been aware of this when he used the word.

The amendments to this Bill allow the emergence of schools like the John Paul College. While the previous speaker, the honourable member for Fremantle made some critical comments, he should be qualified to do so to the extent that perhaps some schools that he will regard as being strange may emerge, but this Bill will also ensure the emergence of many schools based on a most solid foundation. I regret that the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) is not at the table to allow me to congratulate him for this amendment because it was very much through the problems confronted by the John Paul College that this particular amendment was made.

I just cannot let pass the comments of the honourable member for Fremantle that this amendment will suit only crackpot schools. Many good schools will benefit. In my electorate this new school already has students in Grade 8, which is the first year of secondary school. It is waiting at this stage on three classes. I think the list for students for the second year of secondary school is also filled. So there was a need, and that need is being met by the dedication of a handful of people who recognised that the area would be enriched by the creation of a representative school of the other system of education.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education (Mr Fife), who left during the dinner break to travel to Queensland to attend the Australian Education Council, has asked me to respond to this matter. I wish to make the Government's position very clear. I remind the House that the purpose of the legislation is to amend the provisions of the Non-government Schools (Loans Guarantee) Act in two respects. Firstly, it extends the coverage of the Act to include proposed as well as existing non-government schools. Secondly, it extends the scope of the loan guarantee to cover repayment of interest moneys in addition to repayment of principal for purposes of expenditure on approved projects.

SPEECH.PARA: The effects of these amendments will be to bring the arrangements for loan guarantees more into line with those for non-government schools in the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory which have been contained in the Independent Schools (Loans Guarantee) Act since 1969, to widen the definition of a non-government school to be similar to that used in the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act, to assist proposed schools which do not have access to large assets for collateral or to an extensive parent body which can support heavy loan repayments and to make the scheme more attractive to both existing and proposed non-government schools which are faced with increased enrolment pressures. The Government, therefore, does not agree with the proposed amendment.
Question put:
That clause 3 be agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blewett Dr N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 10 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his Department investigated the feasibility of having a three-tier structure of health fund contributions-single, couple, family.
(2) What would be the likely change in contribution rates if this change was to occur.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A three-tier structure of health fund contributions has not been considered as it is not regarded as being consistent with the community rating principle, which is the basis of the health insurance arrangements. The application of the principle does accept that single people pay half the family rate but any acceptance of family size as a factor in setting contribution rates would be regarded as contrary to the principle. It is of significance to this question that, for the majority of couples, the community rating principle would have worked in their favour at some stage during their period of insurance coverage e.g. before their own children became independent. The principle, therefore, not only works to keep contributions within reasonable reach of all persons at any point in time but also provides, during the contributor life of an individual member, for an even spread of contributions regardless of varying potential benefit utilisation.

(2) It could generally be expected that, under a system that took family size into account as a factor in determining contribution rates, families with dependants would pay relatively higher rates than they do at present. Further, the greater number of dependants could mean further higher contribution rates; a situation which could well disadvantage large families. However, data are not available to my Department that would enable an accurate assessment to be made of the effects of such a change. It is also likely that the effects would vary between health funds, depending on the composition of their membership.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 16 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to allegations that Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd is negotiating for the De Beers organisation to gain control over the marketing of diamonds from the Argyle project; if so, is it a fact that (a) such a contract will mean that Australians will lose control over the pricing, production and marketing of these Australian minerals, and return to Australia prices substantially below world prices; (b) the extent and value of Australian diamond resources at Argyle are unknown to any Commonwealth agency and (c) the Argyle deposit is substantially foreign-owned with its value being at least $1,000 million.

(2) Has his attention also been drawn to an article in Barrons magazine of 6-12 September 1981 intimating that Australia now represents the greatest single challenge to the De Beers stranglehold on the international diamond wholesaling business and that Australia could set up its own marketing mechanism which might some day rival De Beers.

(3) If so, will he take immediate steps to establish an inquiry into the ownership, the conditions of development, the proposed marketing contract and the value of the deposit to ensure that development will be conducted in Australia's interests.
(4) Will he also take immediate steps to ensure that no contractual arrangements are entered into until an inquiry of the type referred to in part (3) is concluded and its report tabled in the House.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. However, the Ashton Joint Venture management stated publicly on 28 August 1981 that no decisions had been taken about possible arrangements for the marketing of diamonds from the Argyle deposit.
(a) Since no contract with the De Beers organisation has been negotiated or is in the process of being negotiated, any statement about the possible effects of such a contract is speculative.

(b) The extent and value of the Argyle deposit will not be able to be estimated until the evaluation of the deposit is completed. What can be said on the basis of the evaluation to date is that Argyle is a large, high grade deposit but the average quality and size of the diamonds is low by world standards so that the return from their sale can be expected to be below the world average. A large proportion of the diamonds so far recovered is of industrial quality with a value far less than gem quality diamonds.

(c) The major partners in the Ashton Joint Venture are substantially foreign owned but the two companies involved have been granted naturalising status. As well as having given the required undertakings to increase the level of their Australian equity to 51 per cent, the companies were also required as a pre-condition for the granting of naturalising status to have ensured that their company articles of association provide for a majority of Australian citizens on their board of directors. This is in line with the Government's intention that a naturalising company should be able to operate with a predominantly Australian board and should be controlled by that Board.
(2) Yes.

(3) and (4) It is not intended to conduct any such inquiry. The partners in the Ashton Joint Venture are well aware of the general Government objective that resource development should be conducted in the national interest as well as in the interest of the companies and shareholders involved. The AJV partners have been advised that the arrangements for the marketing of output from the project and the question of any effect that may have on the equity and control will be examined by the Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 16 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: It is a fact that (a) the date of the authoritative environmental impact statement associated with the development work on Brisbane's International Airport is March 1974 and

(b) since March 1974 his Department has not produced a Draft Environmental Impact Statement which specifically addresses the next stage of the project, namely, further dredging and Site Reclamation; if so, when will a report on the next stage be made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) No. A draft environmental impact statement (EIS) covering the Airport Development Works was prepared by the Department of Transport in 1978 and released for public comment in December 1978 in accordance with the requirements of the Commonwealth's Environment Protection Administrative Procedures. This document was available to the public through the Australian Government Bookshops. The final EIS was published by the Department in February 1979 following review of public comments received.

Commencing in 1974, a series of studies was undertaken by Commonwealth and State government authorities and academic institutions to assess the potential environmental effects associated with proposals for the redevelopment of Brisbane Airport. Reports on those background studies were published as Volumes 1-5 of the Brisbane Airport Development Project Environmental Study in 1977. A further volume of reports on continuing studies was published as Volume 6 in June 1979.

(b) No further environmental impact statement has been published since 1979. Major sand dredging and site reclamation were considered in the 1979 EIS. Current proposals for further dredging and site reclamation associated with the proposed 14/32 cross runway were the subject of a Notice of Intention submitted to the Department of Home Affairs and Environment on 30 September 1980 in accordance with the requirements of Paragraph 2.1 of the Environment Protection Administrative Procedures.
The Department of Home Affairs and Environment advised the Department of Transport on 17 November 1980 that preparation of a further EIS would not be required.

No further EIS will be published on this aspect of the Brisbane Airport Redevelopment Project. However, the effects of sand dredging and site filling are being monitored as part of the environmental monitoring program associated with the airport redevelopment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 22 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the Australian Book Publishers' Association has stated that book prices in Australia could rise by up to 15 per cent as a result of the Budget imposition of 2.5 per cent sales tax on books.
(2) What was the estimate of his Department in respect of the anticipated cost to the Australian public from the imposition of the sales tax.
(3) Has the Australian Book Publisher's Association estimated it would cost the Australian public $50m a year.

(4) Has the Association stated that the book trade will incur considerable administrative costs in reconciling exempt and non-exempt book orders and processing credits, and that this cost would be passed on to the public.
(5) What is the purpose of the imposition of the sales tax on (a) books, (b) magazines and (c) newspapers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, according to news media reports.

(2) The incidence of a wholesale sales tax as between the suppliers and the final consumers of the taxable article depends on the extent to which suppliers are able to pass the tax forward to consumers. This, in turn, depends on the degree of competition among suppliers and the level of demand among consumers. Against this background, it would be impracticable to attempt to estimate the aggregate cost to consumers of the proposed 2.5 per cent sales tax on books. At the same time, having regard both to conventional mark-up practices and to the additional administrative costs which the Association claims the new tax will impose on the book trade, I have difficulty in reconciling a 2.5 per cent increase in price at wholesale level with a 15 per cent increase at retail level. Such a movement suggests that the book trade would pass forward to the final retail purchaser up to 12 times the tax imposed at wholesale level.
(3) and (4) Yes, according to news media reports.

(5) Books, magazines and newspapers are not the only goods now exempt that are to be brought under tax at 2.5 per cent and it is quite misleading to refer to them in isolation. The fact is that a major element of the 1981-82 Budget strategy was to reduce the overall deficit by almost $1,000m. As I said in my Budget Speech, this is a decisive move which symbolises the Government's determination not to endanger the gains already made with regard to containing and reducing inflation and to sustaining growth in the private sector. To ensure that reduction in the deficit, it was found necessary to raise additional revenue. This is to be done in part through increases in the existing rates of sales tax and the subjection to sales tax at 2.5 per cent of a range of currently exempt items including books, magazines and newspapers. This move also accords with the Government's view that such a change in the mix of direct and indirect taxes will increase the potential for desirable reductions in direct taxes, and particularly personal income tax as future economic and budgetary conditions permit.

(3) Are inspectors in his Department aware of the practice referred to in part (2).
(4) Has any action been taken against the medical practitioner in this practice; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) My Department has no knowledge of the particular practice referred to in the question.

However, following initial investigation of a somewhat similar case by officers of my Department in Queensland, the matter was referred to the Australian Federal Police for further action. I understand that the police investigations are not yet finalised.

Should the honourable member have further details of the case or cases referred to in his question and the names of the medical practitioners involved, I would be pleased to have those details further investigated.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Compensation Claims by Persons Affected by Government Actions

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon Notice, on 23 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the total number of claims which had been made for compensation by 12 December 1980 from persons affected by the governments actions in respect of the situation in (a) Afghanistan and (b) Iran.
(2) What was the total value of claims in respect of (a) Afghanistan and (b) Iran.
(3) What is the percentage of approvals to the (a) number of claims and (b) value of claims, as at 22 September 1981.
(4) What parameters were applied in determining approval or rejection of claims.
(5) Were loss of profits compensated or were only costs actually incurred or revenue forgone compensated.
(6) Do any provisions exist for appeals against rejection of claims.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As at 12 December 1980, a total of 109 claims from 63 individuals and firms had been received. A further three claims were accepted after 12 December 1980, because of special circumstances applying in each case. 4 of the claims received were from travel agents, representing claims both on their own behalf and on behalf of their clients who, as Olympic tourists, forfeited travel deposits.

Of the 112 claims which were accepted, 62 were related to the Government's actions in respct of the situation in Afghanistan, and 50 were related to the Government's actions in relation to the situation in Iran.
(2) The amounts originally claimed were:
(a) In respect of Afghanistan: $8.6m
(b) In respect of Iran: $7.3m
(3) (a) Of the 75 claims for which payments had been approved or disallowed as at 22 September 1981, 66 claims or 88 per cent were approved.

(b) For the 61 claims approved as a 22 September 1981 for final payment, the amount approved was 68 per cent of the amount originally claimed in respect of those claims. Interim payments have also been made on 5 claims.
(4) Claims are being considered on the basis announced by the Prime Minister in his statement of 13 June 1980 and outlined in my response to Question No. 3107. (Hansard, 23 September 1981, p1723).
(5) Compensation is paid in respect of unrecouped expenditure (excluding overheads or profits forgone).

(6) Where claims have been disallowed, claimants have been advised of reason for disallowance and told that, if they can provide further information which would affect the basis for disallowance, their claims would be further considered by Ministers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that booksellers claim that book prices in Australia will rise by up to 15 per cent as a result of the Budget imposition of 2.5 per cent sales tax on books.
(2) If so, is this multiplier effect also likely to occur with all the other consumer goods on which sales tax has been increased by 2.5 per cent to 17.5 per cent.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I understand from news media reports that claims have been made that the imposition of a 2.5 per cent wholesale sales tax on books will result in price increases at the retail level of up to 15 per cent. Given conventional mark-up practices and even allowing for the additional administrative costs which the book trade alleges it will suffer in consequence of the new tax, I have considerable difficulty in accepting such claims. If they proved correct, it would mean that a 2.5 per cent tax was magnified up to 12 times between wholesale and retail levels within the book trade. Such a magnification would reflect more on practices within that trade, I suggest, than on the Government for proposing to tax books at far more modest rates than are imposed and generally accepted as proper in many other advanced Western countries.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 23 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact as reported in the Age of 17 July 1981 that Singapore National Iron and Steel Mills, as at June 1981, had 100 steel drums of radioactive material, for which Australia had previously agreed to provide a disposal site within Australia; if so, what were the circumstances which produced this agreement.

(2) Is there any substance to the Age report in attributing to a spokesman of the Australian High Commission, a statement that all problems in connection with the radioactive waste have been solved at the diplomatic and political level between Canberra and Singapore.

(3) Is it a fact that a site for the disposal of this waste has been provided in Western Australia; if so, where is that site located precisely and has the Government of Western Australia, and relevant local government authorities, been informed of the decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) In September 1978 a smelter belonging to the Government-owned Iron and Steel Mills (NISM) of Singapore was contaminated by radioactive material. Contamination was thought to have resulted from the inadvertent inclusion of an industrial radioactive source in a consignment of scrap metal from the Kambalda plant of Western Mining Corporation. After decontamination of the smelter, NISM was left holding a quantity of waste material containing radioactive caesium. The bulk of this material is contained in 119 steel drums.

Following protracted negotations between the Australian and Singapore companies regarding disposal of the material, the Singapore Government formally sought Australian assistance in February 1981. In late March 1981 the Singapore Government was advised that the Australian Government and the Western Australian State Government had agreed in principle to provide the necessary approvals which would allow the companies involved to transfer and store the material in Western Australia.
(3) A site approximately 29 kilometres in a direct line south-south-east of the Kambalda Post Office has been proposed by Western Mining Corporation for disposal of the material.

The Western Australian Radiological Council has approved the suitability of this site and its proposed method of use from a radiological point of view, and the Western Australian Government is arranging for company use of the site. The relevant Local Government authority, the Shire of Coolgardie, has been advised.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: National Acoustic Laboratory: Referrals by Repatriation Hospitals

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 27 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that veterans referred to the National Acoustic Laboratory by Repatriation Hospitals have encountered delays in arranging appointments of up to 3-4 months; if so, what are the reasons for such lengthy delays.
(2) What other referrals are received by the National Acoustic Laboratory.
(3) Do all referrals encounter the same delays.
(4) What steps will he take to reduce these delays.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Clients referred to the National Acoustic Laboratories (NAL) by the Department of Veterans' Affairs may encounter delays of 3 to 4 months in obtaining appointments at some NAL centres throughout Australia. In the past Veterans' Affairs' clients were given a higher priority than those of the Department of Social Security (i.e. pensioners). It has now been necessry to bring the priority allocated to the former into line with that allocated to pensioners. (This has taken place in all States except New South Wales where it will be implemented as soon as possible). As a consequence, Veterans' Affairs' clients now experience waiting times longer than formerly. The need to rearrange priorities stems from the increasing demand for NAL services placed on finite staff resources.

(2) Other referrals to NAL include: children (up to 21 years) with confirmed or suspected hearing loss, many of whom are fitted with hearing aids; and small groups such as Department of Transport and Commonwalth compensation clients.

(3) In all hearing centres the delay encountered by pensioners is either equal to or exceeds the delay encountered by Veterans' Affairs' clients. In most hearing centres the delay encountered by eligible adults with NAL aids (this includes both pensioners and Veterans' Affairs' clients) is equal to or less than for new Veterans' Affairs' clients.
In all hearing centres children 4 years and under and children over 4 years with an aid encounter less of a delay than veterans' Affairs' clients.
In all hearing centres children 4 years and under and children over 4 years with an aid encounter less of a delay than Veterans' Affairs' clients.

The comparison of delays encountered by Veterans' Affairs' clients to those for children in this group wait an equal or lesser period of time than Veterans' Affairs' clients. However there are a few centres where this group of children is waiting longer than Veterans' Affairs' clients.
The other small groups of clients experience delays equal to or only slightly less than those ecnountered by Veterans' Affairs' clients.

(4) Following a Joint Management Review of NAL activities a number of its recommendations for a more efficient service have been implemented and further recommendations will be progressively adopted. However, with the ever increasin demand on NAL services, it is inevitable that there will be some delays in providing appointments to clients.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Social Security: Reciprocal Arrangements between Australia and Belgium

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wallis Mr L.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 10 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have any negotiations taken place between the Australian and Belgian governments regarding reciprocal arrangements for the payment of social security benefits such as pensions in these countries; if so, what has been the result of these negotiations; if not, will satisfactory arrangements be negotiated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Exploratory discussions and correspondence took place between representatives of the Australian and Belgian governments in the second half of 1972, with a view to negotiating a social security agreement for reciprocal portability of pensions.

In view of planned amendments for general portability of Australian pensions, in February 1973 the Belgian authorities were formally advised that Australia did not wish to proceed to conclusion of an agreement of the type then contemplated. Belgium did not respond affirmatively to a subsequent Australian invitation in July 1973 to consider the possibility of entering into a comprehensive reciprocal agreement, but a brief exchange of information between officials occurred on a courtesy basis in June 1975.

The general matter of reciprocal agreements on social security is currently under consideration. As part of that process, the possible terms upon which Australia might be prepared to conclude agreements with a number of countries (which could include Belgium) are being examined.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 22 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the procedure used by the Commonwealth to determine recommendations for imperial honours.
(2) Are nominees' names subject to recommendation for specific awards.
(3) Do criteria exist for this classification.
(4) If so, who applies the criteria.
(5) Does the final prerogative for the submission of recommendations reside with him.
(6) Who else is consulted at a political level as a right.
(7) How many persons have been nominated for imperial honours by the Commonwealth in each year since the change of Government in 1975.
(8) What and how many recommendations were made in respect of each award.
(9) How many in each category were granted.
(10) How many persons were granted honours at (a) lesser; and (b) higher level than that recommended by him.
(11) Are recommendations for awards made by political party organisations, accepted for consideration.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (11) The granting of awards under the imperial honours system is the Queens's prerogative. Recommendations are made by the Prime Minister of the day and forwarded through the Governor-General. There is a limit on the number of awards that may be made at various levels; recommendations specify the level of award recommended.

Nominations for honours are sought from a wide variety of people in the community, including members of parliament. These nominations are examined by the Prime Minister, who may consult with others but who is not obliged to do so. There are no restrictions as to the organisations or individuals who may make nominations.

Nominations may be made at any time. Awards are announced in the New Year and Queen's Birthday lists. To be eligible for an honour the nominee must be a citizen of a country of which the Queen is Head of State. Nominations are received on the Prime Minister's behalf by the Honours Secretariat, Department of Administrative Services. Eligibility criteria and other conditions of honours and awards are laid down in the Statutes of the various Orders and in Royal Warrants and Regulations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 22 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the $4.3m promotional campaign launched by Rexona Pty Ltd to establish its new toothpaste Aim in the Australian market.
(2) Has his attention also been drawn to the claim of Rexona's advertisements and counter claims lodged by Rexona's competitors in the Sydney Federal Court.
(3) If so, has he referred Rexona's advertisements to the Trade Practices Commission.
(4) If he has not referred the advertisements to the Commission, will he do so, if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (4) The alleged conduct by Rexona Pty Ltd is currently the subject of litigation in the Federal Court commenced by a competitor, Colgate-Palmolive Pty Ltd, in which an application has apparently been made for injunctive and other relief based on provisions of Part V of the Trade Practices Act. An interim injunction has already been granted, and the Federal Court proceedings, when fully heard, are expected to canvass the question of whether any contravention of the Act has occurred, without the need for the Trade Practices Commission becoming involved.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Experimental Building Station at North Ryde, Sydney

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 22 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the Government proposes to close the Experimental Building Station at North Ryde, Sydney.
(2) Is the Experimental Building Station the only independent fire testing laboratory in Australia.
(3) Does it undertake applied research and development on the structural properties and structural behaviour of buildings particularly under cyclonic and earthquate conditions.
(4) Does it undertake applied research and development in the efficiency of buildings, thereby enabling energy savings.
(5) Does the Station codify technical information for building regulations and building standards leading to the acceptance of the Australian model plumbing code and the uniform testing procedures.
(6) Will the Government reconsider proposals to close the Experimental Building Station; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The Government will be disposing of the Experimental Building Station (EBS) and advertisements calling for expressions of interest for the purchase or lease of the Station appeared in the national press on 11 and 12 September. The Government's aim is for EBS to be taken over as a going concern.
(2) Yes.
(3) Yes.
(4) Yes.

(5) The station conducts research and provides information and advice to the Australian Uniform Building Regulations Co-ordinating Council in regard to the further development and maintenance of the Australian Uniform Building Code and to the Standards Association of Australia in regard to the formulation of building standards. The Station also assists the Standing Committee on Plumbing and Drainage in the further development and maintenance of the Australian Model Plumbing Code and a Manual of Uniform Testing Procedures.
(6) See the answer to (1) above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 24 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have instructions been given to restrict the importation of certain firearms; if so, which firearms will be restricted.
(2) What consideration has been given to ensure that bonafide sport shooters have suitable firearms available so that their sporting activities can continue.
(3) If the importation of certain firearms is to be restricted, what procedures should bonafide sport shooters go through so as to obtain their required firearms.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Following a request from the Australian Police Ministers' Council to the Commonwealth Government import restrictions were extended on the following types of firearms:
firearms of a machine gun construction, and
any semi-automatic firearm, not being a pistol, which incorporates a pistol grip in its design or which incorporated a pistol grip in its design when originally manufactured.
(2) Other firearms will continue to be available for sporting activities.
(3) The types of firearms defined in (1) above are not permitted importation for civilian use or for private firearms collections.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 24 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that Australian seamen arriving from overseas are permitted to bring only $200 worth of duty free goods, one litre of liquor and 200 cigarettes into Australia per year.
(2) If so, when was the ceiling of $200 last adjusted to bring it into line with inflation.
(3) If the position is as stated in part (1), how does this privilege compare with that of airline pilots and the travelling public.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The $200 ceiling was set on 1 March 1975 when the amount was increased from $100. In September 1978 a survey on use of the concession was conducted by the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs; it was found that while approximately 40 per cent did not avail themselves of any part of this allowance, only approximately 2 per cent exceeded the $200 provision. The allowance was therefore regarded as quite adequate and in fact compares favourably with that available in other countries.

(3) Airline pilots and aircrew ordinarily domiciled in in Australia receive the same concession as seamen. This is the same concession as allowed to passengers except that the concession is only available to crew members once in each year.
